* The text discusses the estimation of the gravitational wave (GW) background produced by double neutron star (DNS) coalescences using Monte Carlo simulations.
* The simulations take into account the cosmic star formation rate, the fraction of binaries that remain bound after the second supernova event, and the mass distribution of stars.
* The results show that the maximum of the GW emission occurs around 670 Hz (630 Hz for sfr1) and that about 96% (94% for sfr1) of all events contribute to a continuous background, while sources in the redshift interval 0.01-0.03 (0.069-0.1 for sfr1) produce a popcorn noise.
	+ The density parameter of the GW background has a maximum around 670 Hz (630 Hz for sfr1) and a low frequency cutoff around 1.2 kHz.
	+ The computed signal is below the sensitivity of the first and second generation of detectors but could be detected by third generation interferometers like LCGT and EGO.
	+ The popcorn noise is one order of magnitude higher than the continuous background and can be distinguished from the instrumental noise background using adequate data analysis strategies.

- The text describes a bidirectional relay network where two users exchange information via a relay node using different protocols: traditional two-way relaying, time division broadcasting (TDBC), and multiple access broadcasting (MABC).
- The traditional two-way relaying protocol consists of four successive point-to-point phases, while TDBC and MABC exploit the broadcast capability of the wireless medium and combine phases.
- TDBC protocol uses self-interference cancellation for each user to recover its intended information from the superimposed codeword in the broadcast phase.
- MABC protocol allows both users to transmit to the relay in the multiple-access phase, which decodes both messages using successive interference cancelation.

- The optimal mode selection and power allocation policy is given by the selection metric, which includes the instantaneous capacity of the mode and the allocated power with a negative sign.
- The simulation results confirm that the proposed protocol outperforms existing protocols in terms of average sum rate.
</summary>

• The sound horizon, which is the comoving distance that a sound wave can travel between the end of inflation and the epoch of recombination, depends only on the baryon-to-photon ratio and the redshift of equality.
• The baryon-to-photon ratio is exquisitely well measured in the CMB power spectrum using the ratios of odd and even acoustic peaks and the silk damping tail.
• Other cosmological measurements, such as measurements of the potential envelope and the matter power spectrum, can also be used to measure the actual densities and thereby constrain the presence of unknown relativistic species.
• The acoustic oscillation standard ruler method depends only on the redshift of equality, but other cosmological measurements are well-poised to measure the actual densities and thereby provide additional constraints.

<summary>
• The text discusses the proposal of an ansatz for the neutrino mass matrix in the context of neutrino oscillations and their potential connection to a deeper theory beyond the Standard Model.
• The ansatz is motivated by the observation of neutrino oscillations in various experiments, including Super-Kamiokande and solar neutrino experiments.
• The proposed ansatz is a symmetric complex matrix, which can be derived from an SO(10) grand unified model with some assumptions.
• The consequences of the ansatz are investigated, including its combination with experimental information to get an idea of neutrino masses and their "texture."
• The text also discusses the relevance of the ansatz to the seesaw mechanism and the potential implications for neutrino-antineutrino oscillations and neutrinoless double beta decay.
</summary>
• Motivation and Experimental Evidence:
  • Neutrino oscillations have been observed in various experiments, such as Super-Kamiokande and solar neutrino experiments.
  • These observations suggest that neutrinos have mass and mix with each other.
  • The proposed ansatz is motivated by these observations and the hope that they may provide insight into a more fundamental theory beyond the Standard Model.

• Ansatz and Consequences:
  • The proposed ansatz is a symmetric complex matrix for the neutrino mass matrix.
  • It can be derived from an SO(10) grand unified model with some assumptions.
  • The consequences of the ansatz are investigated, including its combination with experimental information to get an idea of neutrino masses and their "texture."
  • The ansatz is also relevant to the seesaw mechanism and has potential implications for neutrino-antineutrino oscillations and neutrinoless double beta decay.

<summary>

- The contact pattern among individuals is crucial for the spread of infectious diseases, and can be modeled using contact rate functions or network analysis methods.
- Scale-free networks, which have a power-law degree distribution, are common in many real-world networks, including human sexual contacts and animal movements.
- These networks have a high degree of heterogeneity, with many vertices having a low number of contacts and a few vertices having a high number of contacts.
- Simulating the spread of diseases on these networks can provide insights into prevention and control strategies.
- In this study, the authors investigated the impact of different structural properties on the dynamics of epidemics in scale-free networks.
- The networks were generated using the Barabasi-Albert (BA) algorithm and compared to networks generated using other methods (MA, MB, MR, and Kalisky algorithms).
- The results showed that networks generated by the MB algorithm were decentralized and had a larger number of components, smaller giant component size, and lower efficiency compared to BA networks. The other three models generated networks with intermediate characteristics.

</summary>

- Scale-free networks:
  * Power-law degree distribution
  * Many real-world networks are scale-free
  * High degree of heterogeneity

- Simulation study:
  * Investigated impact of structural properties on epidemic dynamics in scale-free networks
  * Generated networks using BA, MA, MB, MR, and Kalisky algorithms
  * Compared networks with same degree distribution but different topological structures

- Results:
  * BA networks are more centralized and efficient than other networks
  * MB networks are decentralized and have a larger number of components, smaller giant component size, and low efficiency
  * Other three models generate networks with intermediate characteristics

- Implications:
  * Simulating disease spread on networks can provide insights into prevention and control strategies
  * Heterogeneity in connections between vertices influences spread of infectious diseases
  * Increase in number of edges leads to increase in prevalence of diseases on networks
  * Prevention of potentially infectious contacts can help control diseases

- Methodology:
  * Generated scale-free networks using BA algorithm
  * Varying number of vertices, edges, and network direction
  * Used SI and SIS epidemic models

* The LC spacetime, described by the Levi-Civita metric, presents challenges to its interpretation, particularly regarding the meaning of the constants @xmath3 and @xmath0.
* The constant @xmath3 is related to the topology of spacetime and the deficit angle, possibly related to the gravitational analog of the Aharonov-Bohm effect.
* The constant @xmath0, which has serious obstacles to its interpretation, describes the spacetime generated by an infinite line mass with mass @xmath0 per unit coordinate length.
* For small @xmath0, LC describes a flat spacetime, but for larger values, circular timelike geodesics exist only when becoming null and being spacelike for certain values.
* The absence of circular test particle orbits and the fact that most known material sources require @xmath17 led to the belief that LC describes the field of a cylinder only if @xmath0 ranges within the (0, @xmath10) interval.
* However, interior solutions matching to LC exist with test particle orbits, and the absence of circular orbits may be due to the required velocities being greater than the speed of light.
* The acceleration of a test particle in a circular geodesic increases with @xmath0, and the effective mass per unit length of an anisotropic fluid matched to LC has a maximum at @xmath20.
* The tangential speed of a test particle in a circular geodesic increases with @xmath0, remaining cylindrical for the source studied in @xcite.
* The effective mass density of the cylindrical distribution of mass raises a disturbing situation of not curving spacetime exactly at its maximum value.
* There is an asymmetry between the negative and positive mass cases for the plane source, with LC with @xmath14 interpreted as the gravitational field produced by an infinite sheet of negative mass density.
* However, in this case, the space is not flat, unlike the @xmath1 case.
* The interpretation of the coordinate @xmath2 as an angle coordinate is questionable in some cases.
* The authors propose to analyze a gyroscope circumventing the axis of symmetry to provide additional elements for the interpretation of LC.

<summary>
• Quantum channel estimation: determining the properties of a quantum channel is essential for reliable quantum communication and quantum error correction.
• The text focuses on estimating the parameters of a quantum channel using a finite number of qubits and partial knowledge of its properties.
• The text introduces two cost functions for quantifying the quality of channel estimation protocols: statistical error and fidelity error.
• The text discusses the parametrization of quantum channels and the estimation protocols for one-parameter channels, specifically the depolarizing, phase damping, and amplitude damping channels.
• Entanglement is explored as a powerful resource for quantum channel estimation.
• The text compares the performance of entangled qubit pairs and separable qubits in estimating the parameters of a qubit Pauli channel.
• The text also discusses the extension of the estimation strategy to higher dimensional quantum channels.
</summary>
• Quantum channel estimation:
  • Essential for reliable quantum communication and quantum error correction
  • Focus of the text: estimating parameters with finite qubits and partial knowledge

• Cost functions for quantifying quality:
  • Statistical error: measures difference between estimated and true parameters
  • Fidelity error: measures overlap between estimated and true channels

• Parametrization and one-parameter channels:
  • Parametrization: describing a quantum channel with a set of parameters
  • Depolarizing, phase damping, and amplitude damping channels: specific types of one-parameter channels

• Entanglement as a resource:
  • Superior estimation performance with entangled qubits compared to separable qubits

• Comparison of estimation schemes:
  • Qubit Pauli channel: comparison of entangled and separable qubit estimation schemes

• Extension to higher dimensional channels:
  • Strategy: looking for a state that satisfies the set of conditions for error operators
  • Generalized Pauli channel: example of a higher dimensional channel and its estimation using entangled states.

• The text discusses issues and findings related to high-energy nuclear collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and Large Hadron Collider (LHC), focusing on the role of collision centrality, underlying event (UE), dijet production, and a nonjet azimuth quadrupole component in 2D angular correlations.
• Centrality is a relevant concept, but its relationship to the low-x gluon transverse structure of the proton and the UE is incomplete. Current theoretical and experimental descriptions of high-energy collisions appear to be inadequate.
• The text establishes a more complete mathematical model for phenomenology based on the xA dependence of single-particle spectra and 2D angular correlations. It explores the connection between xA and centrality, the nature and systematics of the UE, the systematics of dijet production, and the existence and phenomenology of a nonjet azimuth quadrupole component.
• The study presents measurements of 2D angular correlations for 200 GeV collisions and performs parametric fits to the data. It also discusses jet-related and nonjet data systematics, the role of the UE in hadron densities on pseudorapidity, and systematic uncertainties. Additionally, it reviews same-side "ridge" properties and a proposed mechanism.

* The text discusses a method to understand Lindblad evolutions as averaged random unitary evolutions using stochastic methods and operator techniques.
* The main result is that any Lindblad evolution with selfadjoint Lindblad operators can be understood as an averaged random unitary evolution.
* The paper provides a method to solve Lindblad master equations using this result and discusses its implications for intrinsic decoherence models and the Jaynes-Cummings model.
* The flexibility of the mathematical language employed allows for the derivation of Markovian and non-Markovian master equations, and the result has implications for understanding the origin of the Lindbladian structure of master equations.
* The paper also includes a comparison with existing models of stochastic evolution in Hilbert space and discusses future prospects.

* Proof of the main result:
  * The Lindblad equation is derived by adding a stochastic term to the argument of the evolution operator and taking the stochastic average.
  * The result holds for both Markovian and non-Markovian Lindblad evolutions.

* Consequences of the result:
  * A very fast method to solve Lindblad master equations is provided if the unitary solutions are known.
  * The result shows that the Lindbladian structure with selfadjoint Lindblad operators has an origin independent of the Markov approximation.

* Generalization of intrinsic decoherence models:
  * The flexibility of the mathematical language employed allows for the natural generalization of some intrinsic decoherence models present in the literature.

* Comparison with the Jaynes-Cummings model:
  * The result is used to propose a slight generalization of the Jaynes-Cummings model and compare it with experimental results in optical cavities experiments.

* Accounting for reported exponential decays of Rabi oscillations in ion traps:
  * The proposed formalism is used to account for reported exponential decays of Rabi oscillations in ion traps.

* The text discusses the study of the localization length in one-dimensional disordered photonic systems using metamaterials with negative refraction indices.
* The authors calculate numerically the localization length for a one-dimensional arrangement of layers with alternating refraction indices and thicknesses, introducing positional disorder to introduce disorder in the system.
* For homogeneous stacks of traditional right-handed materials, the localization length is analyzed in detail in the allowed bands and gaps, and a quadratic dependence on wavelength is found for long wavelengths.
* The text also explores the behavior of mixed stacks of alternating left- and right-handed materials, finding a linear dependence on wavelength for low-disordered systems in the long-wavelength limit. The localization length is also shown to be modulated by the corresponding bands and decreases as the disorder increases.
** Homogeneous stacks:
*** Detailed analysis of localization length in allowed bands and gaps
**** Quadratic dependence on wavelength for long wavelengths
**** Modulation by bands and decrease as disorder increases
** Mixed stacks:
**** Linear dependence on wavelength for low-disordered systems
**** Modulation by bands and decrease as disorder increases
**** Localization length is not constant for all wavelengths and disorders, but rather shows an irregular form in the transmission spectrum for non-symmetric band distributions.

The text discusses the current understanding of the universe's content, focusing on dark matter and dark energy. Dark matter, which makes up about 27% of the universe, is non-baryonic and non-relativistic at the time of galaxy formation. It is crucial for explaining the formation of large structures and is hypothesized to be made up of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs). Simulations suggest that it follows a specific density profile, and it manifests as a flat rotation curve in galaxies. Dark energy, which makes up about 68% of the universe, is a mysterious form of energy that causes the universe's expansion to accelerate. It is believed to be a constant energy density that violates the usual energy conditions and may be related to the cosmological constant. Its origin and nature are unknown.

<summary>
• Half-metallic ferromagnets with high Curie temperatures are ideal for spintronics applications.
• Cr-doped dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMS) and Cr-based alloys, particularly CrAs and CrSb in zinc blende (ZB) structure, have attracted attention due to their possible complete spin polarization and high Curie temperatures.
• Akinaga et al. grew ZB thin films of CrAs on GaAs (001) substrates, which showed ferromagnetic behavior above 400 K and magnetic moments of 3 μB per CrAs unit.
• Theoretical calculations by Akinaga and others have verified the half-metallic character of CrAs and its high Curie temperature.
• Thin films of CrSb grown by solid-source molecular beam epitaxy on GaAs, AlGaSb, and GaSb have been found to be of ZB structure and ferromagnetic with Curie temperatures higher than 400 K.
• Galanakis and Mavropoulos examined the possibility of half-metallic behavior in ordered ZB compounds of transition metals V, Cr, and Mn with the elements N, P, As, Sb, Se, and Te.
• Their theoretical study shows that the half-metallic ferromagnetic character of these compounds is preserved over a wide range of lattice parameters.
• Yamana et al. studied the effects of tetragonal distortion on ZB CrAs and CrSb and found the half-metallicity to survive large tetragonal distortions.
• The ground states of many of these compounds in the bulk are known to be different from the ZB structure, with the most common structure being the hexagonal NiAs-type.

* The text discusses the study of the transverse distribution function of a three dimensional wormlike chain with a fixed orientation using the exact solution of the green s function of the quantum rigid rotator in a homogeneous external field.

- The text discusses the concept of closed graphs and their properties, specifically in the context of binomial edge ideals.
- A closed graph is a graph with a closed labeling, which is a bijection between the vertices and the set {1, ..., n} that satisfies certain conditions.
- A labeling is closed if it is closed and whenever distinct edges uv and wz have either u = w or v = z.
- Closed graphs have several desirable properties, including being chordal and claw-free, and having a narrow property called narrowness.
- Narrowness means that every vertex is distance at most one from every longest shortest path.
- The text also discusses an algorithm for labeling connected graphs and uses it to prove that a graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.
- The text also mentions some related results and papers on binomial edge ideals and closed graphs.
- The text is based on a senior honors thesis and acknowledges funding from Amherst College and thanks Michael Ching for a remark.

<summary>

- Cosmic rays are high-energy particles discovered in the early 20th century, with a power law energy spectrum that decreases as approximately the cube of the primary energy.
  * Discovery of cosmic rays led to the birth of particle physics.
  * Spectrum has a featureless continuum at all energies, with the highest energy particles known to mankind.
  * Diffusive propagation in the galactic magnetic fields explains the isotropic distribution of arrival directions for energies above a few tens of GeV.

- New progress has been made in understanding different features of cosmic rays, particularly inclined showers.
  * Inclined showers can contribute to the composition issue by providing information on the arrival directions and energies of particles.
  * A recent analysis of inclined data in Haverah Park showed that muon density patterns can be accurately modelled and used to study the composition of cosmic rays.
  * The study of inclined showers has the potential to double the acceptance of air shower arrays and provide valuable insights into photon composition.
</summary>

- The high energy end of the cosmic ray spectrum presents a complex puzzle, with evidence suggesting a change in spectral slope and composition above a few hundred GeV.
  * The absence of a gzk cutoff in the observed cosmic ray spectrum is a major challenge to theory.
  * Many possible scenarios for cosmic ray acceleration are being discussed, including young pulsars, gamma ray bursts, our own galaxy, active galaxies, and the local group of galaxies.
  * Knowledge about composition is crucial for understanding the origin and nature of cosmic rays.

- The study of cosmic rays has attracted the attention of many fields in physics, including particle physics, magnetic fields, and astrophysics.
  * Conventional approaches suggest that cosmic rays are nuclei accelerated through stochastic acceleration in astrophysical plasmas.
  * Alternative scenarios propose different particles or interactions, such as annihilation of topological defects, heavy relics, non-thermal particles, or wimpzillas and annihilation of relic neutrinos with messenger neutrinos.
  * The issue of cosmic ray composition is far from being resolved and requires further research to fully understand the nature of these enigmatic particles.

• Optical lattices are artificial crystals of light formed by interference of laser beams.
• Atoms can be cooled and trapped in these lattices, creating a crystal of quantum matter.
• The success of observing Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) led to the discovery of the superfluid to Mott insulator (SF-MI) transition.
• BEC was first predicted by Satyendra Nath Bose in 1924, and later realized in rubidium atoms in 1995.
• The SF-MI transition is significant in condensed matter physics as it allows for the investigation of various phenomena using ultracold atoms in optical lattices.
• A double-well potential (DW) is a simple experimental setup for studying spin Hamiltonians in optical lattices.
• The DW can be completely controlled and measured in an arbitrary two-spin basis by dynamically changing the lattice parameters.
• The DW is a one-dimensional optical lattice with strong confinement in the transverse directions, leading to a two-mode approximation.
• The potential bias or tilt of the DW can be introduced by changing the relative phase of the two potentials, which can be realized by applying a magnetic field gradient.

• Calculations were performed self-consistently and fully relativistically, using the Munich SPR-KKR program package.
• The orthorhombic, antiferromagnetic phase of iron pnictides was investigated in its experimentally observed stripe spin state.
• The impact of disorder due to substitution was dealt with using the CPA method.
• The magnetic moments were found to decrease continuously with increasing co substitution until the antiferromagnetic order collapsed.
• The study found good agreement with experimental data on the magnetic order and the evolution of magnetic moments with co substitution.
• The study also identified surface states and their dependence on surface termination.
• The results suggest that an as-terminated surface is most likely for iron pnictides, but some ba adatoms might still be present.

- XB158 is a neutron star low mass X-ray binary (LMXRB) in the M31 globular cluster B158, with an X-ray period of 50.008 minutes and an optical period of 50.458 minutes.
- It exhibits periodic X-ray intensity dips due to absorption by material in the outer disk, with an amplitude that varies over 10-1100% on a 14-day precession period.
- The authors modeled the 2004 July 17 XMM-Newton PN spectrum of XB158 with a blackbody and a power law, finding a photon index of 2.0 and a luminosity of 1.5 erg s-1.
- The authors conducted 3D smoothed particle hydrodynamical (SPH) modeling, estimating the disk precession period to be 29 times the orbital period, i.e., 81 hours.
- The authors observed 30 Swift XRT observations of XB158, finding evidence for a super-orbital period of 16 days.
- The authors found no evidence for a dependence of luminosity on off-axis angle, but a significant variation in instrumental correction factors. They fitted the lightcurve with a constant intensity and a sinusoidal variation, finding a 5.65-day super-orbital period and a luminosity that varied by a factor of 15.

<summary>

- The text discusses methods to calculate the energy and lifetime of resonance states in quantum systems.
- Complex scaling method is used to reveal resonance states by the appearance of isolated complex eigenvalues in the non-hermitian complex scaled Hamiltonian.
- Numerical results require careful analysis to decide which result is most accurate due to the complex nature of the eigenvalues and the variational basis sets that depend on non-linear parameters.
- Complex virial theorem and graphical methods are used to pick the best numerical solution.
- Complex absorbing potential method produces nonphysical complex energy stabilized points that must be removed to obtain only physical resonances.
- Density of states (DOS) method is used to obtain resonance energies and widths by fitting the DOS with a Lorentzian function.
- The feasibility of the DOS method to calculate resonance lifetimes depends on the availability of a known lifetime value.
- The text also discusses the convergence properties of real basis set methods to obtain resonance energies and lifetimes, and presents a prescription to pick a set of states with linear convergence properties for small width resonances.

</summary>

* Methods to calculate energy and lifetime of resonance states
* Complex scaling method: reveals resonance states by complex eigenvalues in non-hermitian Hamiltonian
* Numerical results require careful analysis for accuracy
* Complex virial theorem and graphical methods used to pick best numerical solution
* Complex absorbing potential method: produces nonphysical complex energy stabilized points
* Density of states (DOS) method: obtains resonance energies and widths by fitting DOS with Lorentzian function
* Feasibility of DOS method to calculate resonance lifetimes depends on known lifetime value
* Discusses convergence properties of real basis set methods and presents prescription to pick states with linear convergence for small width resonances.

Additionally, the text may pave the way for further considerations of two-dimensional and three-dimensional symmetric lattice systems.

• The cataclysmic variable HU Aqr consists of a 0.80 white dwarf and a 0.18 main-sequence companion star in a tight orbit.
  • Two planets have been detected: a 5.7 planet in a 0.013 orbit with an eccentricity of 0.21, and a 7.6 planet in a wider and more eccentric orbit.
  • The presence of these planets allows for the reconstruction of the binary's history and the derivation of the rate of mass loss during the common-envelope phase.
  • The two-planet configuration is dynamically unstable on a 100,000-year timescale, but some numerical simulations exhibit long-term stability.

• The discovery of planets around cataclysmic variables is peculiar due to their catastrophic evolutionary history.
  • The presence of planets around HU Aqr and other cataclysmic variables could be a natural consequence of their formation or quite common.
  • The planets around HU Aqr can be used to constrain the evolution and history of the inner binary.
  • The common-envelope phase, during which the primary star loses its hydrogen envelope, leaves an imprint on the white dwarf's mass and composition.
</summary>

<summary>
• The NCSM/RGM approach, a microscopic cluster method, was presented as a promising technique for treating both structure and reactions in light nuclear systems.
• It combines a cluster technique with realistic interactions and a consistent description of nucleon clusters.
• The method has been successfully applied to two-body cluster systems but cannot describe three-body cluster states.
• Recent work introduced three-body cluster configurations into the method and presented results for the ground state and continuum states of the triton within a helium-2+n+n basis.
• The set of equations was mapped onto a system of coupled-channel integral-differential equations and solved using the microscopic r-matrix method.
• The approach is ideal for studying systems with three-body configurations, such as halo nuclei, resonant systems, and transfer reactions.
• The results for the triton ground state energy within a helium-2(gs)+n+n cluster basis were compared to NCSM calculations and showed good agreement, with a difference of approximately 1 meV due to core excitations.
</summary>

• The text discusses the concept of core entropy for complex polynomials and its relation to the Mandelbrot set.
• The main goal is to prove that the core entropy function extends continuously from the Mandelbrot set to its boundary.

• The text introduces the Hubbard tree, a finite topological tree that is forward invariant under a postcritically finite map, and the concept of core entropy as the topological entropy of the restriction of the map to its Hubbard tree.
• The text also discusses Thurston's algorithm for computing core entropy and how it can be extended to any angle using labeled wedges and infinite graphs.

• The text proves that the growth rate of the infinite graph associated to a labeled wedge coincides with the core entropy for rational angles, thus proving the first part of the main theorem.
• The text also discusses the continuity of the core entropy function at angles which are not purely periodic and shows that purely periodic angles have well-defined left and right limits of the core entropy function.

• GRBs are believed to be of cosmological origin based on the detection of X-ray, optical, and radio afterglows.
• The fireball model is favored, but the degree of beaming is still uncertain.
• Three methods have been proposed to determine the degree of beaming in GRBs.
• The first method suggests a break in the light curve during the relativistic phase, but the smoothness of the break and other factors make it inconclusive.
• The second method suggests strong polarization in optical afterglows, but the conditions for observing polarization are specific.
• The third method suggests the detection of orphan afterglows, which are not associated with any detectable GRBs. However, there is a difficulty in distinguishing an fGRB orphan and a jetted GRB orphan.
• fGRBs are proposed to be baryon-contaminated fireballs with initial Lorentz factors less than 100 but greater than unity. They can manifest themselves as fast X-ray transients or x-ray-GRBs, and their afterglows can be used to test the fireball model under different conditions.

• First method:
  • Proposed that optical afterglows from a jetted GRB should have a break in the light curve during the relativistic phase.
  • Some GRBs such as 990123, 990510, and others are considered good examples.
  • However, detailed numerical studies show that the break is usually quite smooth and may occur at the trans-relativistic phase instead.
  • Many other factors can also result in light curve breaks.

• Second method:
  • Optical afterglows from a jet can be strongly polarized, up to tens of percent.
  • Positive observations have been reported, but polarization can only be observed under specific conditions.

• Third method:
  • Due to relativistic beaming effects, most jetted GRBs cannot be observed directly, but their corresponding late-time afterglow emission, called orphan afterglows, can be detected.
  • The ratio of the orphan afterglow rate to the GRB rate might allow measurement of the GRB collimation angle.

• Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) produce x-ray afterglows that can be detected for several hours to days after the burst.
• Two GRB afterglows were observed with XMM-Newton: GRB 011211 and GRB 001025.
• GRB 011211 was the longest and faintest event localized with BEPPOSAX, and its afterglow was identified with an optical transient at z=2.14.
• GRB 001025 was detected by RXTE All-Sky Monitor and its afterglow was not detected optically down to r=24.5. XMM-Newton observed the location of GRB 001025 and detected two x-ray sources, with the brighter one identified as the afterglow.

- AI3, a layered organic material, has attracted renewed interest due to the presence of low-energy massless Dirac fermions under hydrostatic pressure.
- AI3 is different from graphene in several ways, including the tilt of Dirac cones, anisotropy in the Fermi surface, smaller average fermi velocity, and the presence of additional massive carriers.
- The smaller fermi velocity in AI3 leads to a larger effective coupling constant for Coulomb-type electron-electron interactions.
- Recent ab-initio band-structure calculations have identified the presence of massive carriers near the Fermi level, but the interplay between massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers has not been proven experimentally.
- The authors present magneto-transport measurements of AI3 crystals under hydrostatic pressure, revealing the existence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes.
- The interplay between both carrier types at low energy is the main result of the study.
- The measured mobilities for the two carrier types hint at scattering mechanisms due to strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers.
- The analysis of the data is based on the study of the magneto-conductivity and is similar to the one presented in ref. for multi-carrier semiconductor systems.
- The magneto-conductivity is obtained from the measured resistivity tensor and reveals the existence of two different carrier types with significantly different mobilities.
- The strong temperature dependence of the carrier density is a signature of the absence of charge inhomogeneities and the absence of a third "plateau" in the magneto-conductivity data allows for the consideration of two types of dirac carriers (electrons and holes) in addition to massive holes.

• Fe-based superconductors (FEBS) are a class of high-temperature superconductors with unconventional superconducting states.
   • FEBS can be divided into two subclasses: pnictides and chalcogenides, both with a square lattice of iron as the basic element.
   • The superconducting state origin is still debated, and the Fermi surface (FS) is formed by Fe 3d-orbitals, excluding cases of extreme hole and electron dopings.

 • The FS consists of two hole sheets around the M point and two electron sheets around the X and Y points in the two-dimensional Brillouin zone (BZ), with one Fe per unit cell.
   • In the 2-Fe BZ, electron pockets are centered at the Γ point.
   • Nesting between these two groups of sheets leads to enhanced antiferromagnetic fluctuations with maximal scattering near the wave vector equal to X or Y in the 1-Fe BZ or to Z in the 2-Fe BZ.

 • Different mechanisms of Cooper pair formation result in distinct superconducting gap symmetries and structures.
   • The RPA-SF approach gives the extended s-wave gap that changes sign between hole and electron FS sheets (d-wave state), while orbital fluctuations promote the order parameter to have sign-preserving s-wave symmetry.
   • Probing the gap structure can help elucidate the underlying mechanism.

 • Inelastic neutron scattering (INS) is a useful tool for studying the gap structure as the measured dynamical spin susceptibility carries information about the gap structure.
   • There have been reports of a well-defined peak in neutron spectra in 1111, 122, and 11 systems appearing only for Tc or around Tc.
   • The common explanation is that the peak is the spin resonance appearing due to the d-wave state, but recent ARPES and Andreev spectroscopy results suggest at least two distinct gaps present in 11, 122, and 1111 systems, and even three gaps in LFeAs.

• The text discusses the effect of a short-range correlated disorder on a 2D Bose gas using a 2D extension of the random dimer model (2D-DRDM).
• In the non-interacting regime, the 2D-DRDM introduces delocalized states if the resonance energy characterizing these structures belongs to the spectrum of the unperturbed system.
• The presence of weak interactions drives the density spatial fluctuations, and a mode-matching argument shows that the resonance energy is at the origin of these phenomena. The results reveal that short-range correlations in a disordered potential can modify and enhance the coherence of a many-body system in the weak interacting regime.

• Effects of the 2D-DRDM on a 2D Bose gas:
  • Introduces delocalized states in the non-interacting regime
  • Drives density spatial fluctuations in the presence of weak interactions

• Mode-matching argument:
  • Reveals that the resonance energy is at the origin of the observed phenomena
  • Demonstrates the role of short-range correlations in modifying and enhancing the coherence of a many-body system in the weak interacting regime.

• The text discusses the maximum independent set problem in the context of generalized Petersen graphs, which are a class of graphs with even and odd numbers of vertices.
• For even numbers of vertices, the text provides an upper bound and lower bounds for the maximum independent set size, which are close to each other.
• The text also presents a construction for finding an independent set in generalized Petersen graphs with even numbers of vertices.
• The text also mentions that the independence number of generalized Petersen graphs with fixed numbers of vertices can be found in linear time using an algorithm based on tree decompositions.

• Upper bound: For even numbers of vertices, the maximum independent set size is at least the number of spokes in the graph.
• Lower bound: For even numbers of vertices, the maximum independent set size is at least the size of an independent set obtained by choosing one vertex from each segment of size equal to the number of vertices modulo the number of spokes.
• Construction: The text provides a construction for finding an independent set in generalized Petersen graphs with even numbers of vertices by choosing a subset of vertices from each segment and adding certain vertices from the remaining segment.
• Algorithm: The text mentions that the independence number of generalized Petersen graphs with fixed numbers of vertices can be found in linear time using an algorithm based on tree decompositions.

• Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) using Measurement Device Independent QKD (MDIQKD) is a secure method for distributing encryption keys, but it requires certain assumptions and countermeasures against practical attacks.
• MDIQKD is based on the reversed EPR-based QKD protocol and eliminates all potential loopholes of detectors without sacrificing performance.
• The only assumption needed is that the preparation of quantum signal sources by Alice and Bob is almost perfect and carefully characterized.
• Two schemes of phase encoding MDIQKD have been proposed: one using phase locking of two separate laser sources and the other using the conversion of phase encoding into polarization encoding.
• The security of these schemes has been proven with basis-dependent flaw using the quantum coin idea.
• The first scheme covers shorter distances and may require less accuracy of the state preparation, while the second scheme can cover much longer distances when the state is prepared very precisely.
• The key generation rate of each scheme has been simulated with realistic parameters, considering the basis-dependent flaw due to imperfect phase modulators.
• The simulation results imply that the first scheme may not be feasible with current technologies due to the basis-dependent flaw, but it can tolerate some extent of imperfect phase locking errors.
• The second scheme is more robust against the degradation of the fidelity of single-photon components of density matrices in two bases, but it requires a photon source with a very high fidelity and very accurate estimation of the fidelity of the single-photon subspace.
• The accurate preparation of the state is crucial not only in MDIQKD but also in standard QKD, where Eve can enhance the imbalance of the quantum coin exponentially with the increase of the distance.

</summary>

• Eliminates all potential loopholes of detectors without sacrificing performance
• Only assumption needed: preparation of quantum signal sources by Alice and Bob is almost perfect and carefully characterized
• Two phase encoding MDIQKD schemes proposed: phase locking and conversion of phase encoding into polarization encoding
• Security proven with basis-dependent flaw using quantum coin idea
• First scheme covers shorter distances, may require less

<summary>

- Massive stars play a crucial role in galaxy evolution, but their formation process remains unclear.
- Recent high-resolution observations using michelle on the Gemini North Telescope have revealed individual massive protostellar systems, providing evidence for accretion as the primary formation mechanism.
- These observations include the detection of Keplerian disks surrounding massive young stellar objects and a Salpeter-like mass function for protostellar dust clumps.
- The methanol maser emission, which exclusively traces massive star formation, is not associated with UCHII regions and is found closest to the brightest mid-infrared point source in protoclusters.
- Monte Carlo simulations suggest it is difficult to generate the observed mass distributions for the most massive cluster members from the gas in the core using a standard form of the IMF, implying that the mass distribution of the most massive stars may not be produced by sampling a standard IMF from the available gas.

</summary>

- High-resolution observations using michelle on the Gemini North Telescope have uncovered the environment surrounding individual massive protostellar systems.
  * Detection of Keplerian disks and Salpeter-like mass function for protostellar dust clumps point towards an accretion formation scenario for massive stars.
- Methanol maser emission, which exclusively traces massive star formation, is not associated with UCHII regions and is found closest to the brightest mid-infrared point source in protoclusters.
  * Maser sites with weak radio continuum flux are associated with massive, luminous, and deeply embedded cores, indicating an earlier evolutionary stage than UCHII regions.
- Monte Carlo simulations suggest it is difficult to generate the observed mass distributions for the most massive cluster members from the gas in the core using a standard form of the IMF.
  * This implies that the mass distribution of the most massive stars may not be produced by sampling a standard IMF from the available gas.
- Further studies with high spatial and spectral resolution observations are needed to determine whether the multiple sources are physically bound.
- The time scale for a source at the core edge to migrate to the centre is comparable to the hot molecular core lifetime, so it is not possible to rule out large protostellar motions within the core.

• Modified theories of gravity have gained attention due to the discovery of an expanding, accelerated universe.
• The mysterious dark energy responsible for this change is a repulsive force called dark energy.
• The promising scenario for exploring dark energy's characteristics is the modified gravity approach.
• Lovelock theory of gravity is a modified theory that generalizes general relativity in higher dimensions and is free from spin-2 ghost instabilities.
• The Gauss-Bonnet invariant is a quadratic curvature invariant that is a topological term in 4-dimensions and possesses trivial contribution in the field equations.
• Two scenarios for discussing the dynamics of the Gauss-Bonnet invariant in 4-dimensions are:
  • Coupling it with a scalar field
  • Adding a generic function in the Einstein-Hilbert action
</summary>
• Coupling with a scalar field:
  • Naturally appears in the effective action in string theory
  • Discusses late-time cosmological evolution successfully
  • Endowed with a rich cosmological structure and consistent with solar system constraints
• Adding a generic function (Gauss-Bonnet gravity):
  • Introduced as an alternative for dark energy
  • Yields non-zero covariant divergence of the energy-momentum tensor and an extra force
  • Massive test particles follow non-geodesic trajectories while dust particles follow geodesic lines
• Reconstruction and stability analysis of cosmological models in modified theories of gravity are important issues in cosmology.
• The reconstruction technique involves using known cosmic solutions in the modified field equations to find the corresponding function that reproduces the given evolutionary cosmic history.
• Stability analysis examines the background stability of isotropic and homogeneous perturbations in the hubble parameter and energy density.
• The stability of de Sitter and power-law solutions is investigated using the perturbed field equation and continuity equation.
• The results indicate that some models are stable against linear perturbations while others are unstable.

• Majorana fermions (MFs) are real solutions of the Dirac equation and their own antiparticles.
• Proposed as a model for neutrinos, MFs have been predicted to occur as quasi-particle bound states in engineered condensed matter systems.
• MFs obey non-Abelian statistics, which is important for decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing.
• Recent focus has been on hosting MFs in exotic solid state systems, specifically topological superconductors.
• Various platforms including topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains have been proposed to support majorana states.
• MFs manifest themselves as characteristic zero-bias peaks (ZBPs) in tunneling spectroscopy experiments.
• Theoretical predictions of ZBPs have been observed experimentally in semiconductor nanowires, interpreted as signatures of MFs.
• Experimental evidence for MFs is still a challenge to obtain, with zero-bias conductance peaks also appearing from other mechanisms.
• An alternative all-optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs in iron chains on a superconducting Pb surface via a coupled hybrid quantum dot (QD) - nanomechanical resonator (NR) system.

• Iron chains on the superconducting Pb surface are ferromagnetically ordered with a large magnetic moment, which takes the role of a magnetic field in nanowire experiments.
• A two-level QD is implanted in the NR to form a coupled hybrid QD-NR system.
• The interaction between MFs in iron chains and the QD in the hybrid system is mainly due to the dipole-dipole interaction.
• The change in the coherent optical spectrum of the QD can serve as a possible signature for MFs.
• The vibration of the NR acting as a phonon cavity enhances the exciton resonance spectrum significantly and makes MFs more sensitive to detection.
</summary>

- Hadronic degrees of freedom are useful in nuclear physics tests of time reversal symmetry due to the moderate energies involved.
- Effective one boson exchange potentials can be used to treat nuclear structure part and extract effective hadronic coupling constants.
- To compare upper bounds on a more fundamental level, it's necessary to relate hadronic degrees of freedom to quark degrees of freedom.
- The text focuses on estimates of hadronic matrix elements for charge type exchange and axial vector type exchange nucleon-nucleon interactions.
- The text also discusses the use of quark models to relate quark operators to effective hadronic operators and evaluate matrix elements.
</summary>

• Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are characterized by no hydrogen lines but strong silicon lines in their spectra, are brighter than most other types, and exhibit uniform light curves. They are used as standard candles to measure distances to remote galaxies.

• The accreting white dwarf (WD) model is a plausible explosion scenario for SNe Ia, in which a WD in a binary system accretes material from the companion, increases its mass, and then explodes. The model has been improved by considering the stellar wind from the WD during the accretion process.

• Two main evolutionary paths leading to SNe Ia are the super soft X-ray source (SSS) channel and the symbiotic channel. The SSS channel involves a WD accreting material from a red giant companion, while the symbiotic channel involves a WD accreting material from a companion star that is a red giant or a white dwarf.

• Observational confirmation of the companion star in the vicinity of a SNe Ia explosion site is necessary to validate the evolutionary scenario. A potential method to prove the presence of the companion star inside the ejecta is by observing absorption lines with broad blue wings in the companion star's spectrum. This absorption feature is caused by Fe I in the ejecta and is only present on the blue side when the star is inside the ejecta. However, factors such as the number of ionizing photons and the ionization state of the shocked ejecta may affect the distinct absorption features.

• Quantum entanglement is a physical resource in quantum mechanics, characterized by conservation laws and manipulated independently of its physical realization.
  • Measuring entanglement is challenging due to the interaction of quantum systems with their environment, leading to mixed states.
    • Entanglement measures, such as entropy of entanglement and entanglement of formation, have been proposed to quantify entanglement.
      • Entanglement of formation is the minimal amount of entanglement required to form a density operator, while entanglement of distillation is the guaranteed amount of entanglement that can be extracted.
• The text discusses the entanglement dynamics of a cascaded qubit system, which produces unconditional entangled states as the steady-state solution to a master equation.
  • The system exhibits bimodal behavior, where it either evolves into a maximally entangled bell state or an entangled-state cycle involving stochastic switching between two bell states.
    • The entangled-state cycle is a result of the commuting jump operators and the competition between the periods of evolution between quantum jumps and the jumps themselves.
</summary>

• Continuous Variable Quantum Key Distribution (CVQKD) between Alice and Bob has seen improvements in theory and experimentation, with practical implementations such as fiber-based Gaussian-modulated and coherent-state systems.
• The security of these systems has been confirmed through the analysis of equivalent entanglement-based schemes, but traditional security analysis does not consider the local oscillator (LO), which is necessary for balanced homodyne detection and within Eve's manipulating domain.
• The necessity of monitoring LO intensity for security proofs in discrete QKD protocols has been discussed, and excess noise caused by imperfect subtraction of balanced homodyne detector in the presence of LO intensity fluctuations has been noted and quantified.
• In practical CVQKD systems, LO intensity is monitored by splitting a small part with a beam splitter, but the effect of LO intensity fluctuations on the secret key rate is not yet fully understood.
• Eve can exploit LO intensity fluctuations to reduce channel excess noise and get partial secret keys without being detected if Bob does not scale his measurements with the instantaneous LO intensity values.
• The secret key rate for reverse reconciliation decreases rapidly over long distances or small channel transmissions when Eve attacks the intensity of LO during key distribution.
• Eve can intercept partial or full secret keys by controlling the different transmissions of LO and making the overall estimated excess noise by Alice and Bob lower than the real one.

</summary>

<summary>

- The text discusses the phenomenon of high velocity ionized hydrogen (HI) supershells in galaxies and the two main explanations for their formation: internal (starbursts) and external (infall of massive gas clouds).
- The text presents the case of the galaxy NGC 3556, which challenges both explanations due to its large and energetic supershells located at the opposite edges of the disk, marked by steep density gradients.
- * Internal source model difficulties: Creating the eastern supershell alone would require a star cluster populated by an implausible number of massive stars, and no evidence of such a starburst is present.
* External source model difficulties: The galaxy appears isolated, making the source of the putative clouds puzzling. An infalling cloud of the required mass would easily be detected, yet none is seen. Additionally, it is unlikely that two massive clouds just happened to fall in parallel to the major axis at opposite ends of the galaxy, roughly at the same time.
- The text proposes a new explanation for the origin of these two supershells: they have been formed by radio jets which plow through the interstellar medium (ISM) of the disk of NGC 3556.
- * Jet inflated HI bubbles: The jets undergo a rapid flaring as they encounter the region of large scale density decline near the outskirts of the galactic disk, causing the hot plasma bubble to expand and sweep the gas-rich ambient medium into the shape of the HI supershells.
* Implications: The presence of supershells is expected to correlate with the existence of a nonthermal radio halo, and the locations of the anchor points of the two supershells suggest that the blasting of each supershell would have occurred at a galactocentric distance just past the peak of the HI rotation curve.
</summary>

• Leo i is a unique dwarf spheroidal (dsph) galaxy in the Local Group, lacking a conspicuous old population and having a larger fraction of intermediate-age and young stars compared to other dsphs.
   - The star formation in Leo i seems to have continued until almost the present time without distinct bursts.
   - Important questions about Leo i remain, such as the existence of a very old stellar population, variations of star formation across the galaxy, and the absence of a horizontal branch in the outer parts.

 • The text discusses the results of HST observations of Leo i, which reveal a wide range of stellar ages and a lack of a prominent horizontal branch.
   - The authors suggest that the absence of an old population and the presence of intermediate-age and young stars may be due to a delayed onset of substantial star formation in Leo i compared to other dsphs.
   - The text also mentions the discovery of bright, yellow stars in Leo i, which may be classical cepheids in the lower extreme of mass, luminosity, and period.
   - The authors plan to use synthetic cmds to quantitatively study the star formation history of Leo i and address remaining questions about its stellar populations and evolution.

* The text discusses a result from Berestycki et al. about the principal eigenvalue of the Laplacian perturbed by a divergence-free drift in dimensions 10 and higher.
* The result states that the principal eigenvalue remains bounded as the drift strength increases if and only if there exists a first integral of the flow that satisfies certain conditions.
	+ The first integral functions are constant along the flow and allow for flow lines to be contained in the domain.
	+ The absence of such functions results in the flow leaving the domain with speed proportional to the drift strength.
* The text aims to extend this result to the fractional Laplacian in place of the classical Laplacian.
* The main difficulty in the development is the roughness and non-locality of the fractional Laplacian.
* The authors use conditioning suggested by Bogdan and Dyda, approximation techniques for flows given by Diperna and Lions, and properties of the green function and heat kernel of gradient perturbations of the fractional Laplacian obtained by Bogdan, Jakubowski, and Chen et al. to define and study the principal eigenpair for the fractional Laplacian and the advection operator.
* The main result states that if the domain is a simply connected, bounded domain with a regular boundary, and the drift is of zero divergence, then the principal eigenvalue and infimum are attained.

• The text discusses quantum cloning machines (QCMs) and their applications, focusing on partial cloning of one constituent of two-partite qubit states.
• QCMs can be symmetric, producing identical copies, or state-dependent, with the quality of copying depending on the initial state. They can be used for eavesdropping quantum channels by copying specific parts of the quantum signal.
• The text describes a symmetric, state-dependent QCM for cloning one qubit of a two-qubit state, using a unitary operator and the concept of fidelity as a measure of closeness between initial and final states.
• The QCM's parameters are determined by minimizing the integral average of the distance between the initial and output states, resulting in a state-dependent cloning machine with higher fidelity than universal cloning machines for pure states.
• The text also discusses the cloning of mixed qubit states using the purification of the mixed state and partial cloning.
• The choice of QCM parameters depends on the eavesdropping strategy.
• The text mentions several papers for further reading on quantum cloning and related topics.

- Colloidal suspensions can form novel materials through self-assembly, with colloidal crystals of particular interest due to their iridescent colors and potential for producing photonic crystals
- Colloidal crystals have well-defined thermodynamic temperatures, making them mesoscopic "model atoms" for studying condensed matter systems
- Recent advances allow for tunable colors through control of lattice spacing with an external field
- Ac electric fields can induce dipolar interactions between colloidal particles, leading to exotic crystal structures and direct observation of phase transitions
- Direct microscopic observation at the single-particle level provides unprecedented detail, potentially tackling long-standing problems in condensed matter
- A rotating ac field introduces even more possibilities, with dipolar interactions leading to attractions in the plane of rotation and repulsions above and below
- Experiments with a rotating magnetic field on granular matter produced disc-like patterns, but colloidal dispersions exhibit Brownian motion, allowing for thermodynamic equilibrium structures (i.e., crystals) to be obtained
- Previous work showed that lattice spacing within quasi-2D colloidal crystals could be controlled in situ using a coplanar rotating electric field
- The interparticle dipolar interactions in the plane of the electric field may be treated as a circularly symmetric attraction due to time averaging effect of a rapidly rotating field
- The system consists of two charged particles in a surrounding medium, with a repulsive interaction and an attractive interaction induced by the rotating electric field. The attractive potential is treated as a dipolar interaction, and the renormalized charge is calculated from the strength of the electric field and the Clausius-Mosotti factor.

• Aql X-1 is an active Soft X-ray Transient (SXT) with several X-ray and optical outbursts, an orbital period of 19 hours, and a companion star identified as V1333 Aql.

	+ The outburst evolution of low mass X-ray transients (LMXTS) presents important differences from those containing black hole candidates (BHCs), including the steepening in the X-ray flux decrease and the larger luminosity range between outburst peak and quiescence.
	+ The most appealing mechanism for the marked steepening and spectral hardening in the outburst decay is a transition to the propeller regime, where most of the inflowing matter is stopped at the magnetospheric boundary.
	+ The observed ratio of the luminosity when the QPO at 45 Hz were detected and the luminosity when the centrifugal barrier closes provides information on the neutron star magnetic field and spin.
	+ The quiescent X-ray luminosity is probably lower than the minimum magnetospheric accretion luminosity allowed in the propeller phase, and the X-ray spectrum shows a pronounced decrease in the power law to black body flux ratio, suggesting a transition to shock emission from the interaction of a radio pulsar wind with the matter outflowing from the companion star.
	+ The black body-like spectral component observed in quiescence could be due to the streaming of energetic particles that hit the polar caps or the residual neutron star accretion in the propeller phase.
	+ Aql X-1 likely represents the first example of an old fast rotating neutron star undergoing a transition to the propeller regime at first, followed by a transition to the radio pulsar regime, as the transient X-ray emission approaches its quiescent level.

* The text discusses the investigation into the apparent faintness of the X-ray transient source igr j170913624, which exhibits similar variability patterns to the enigmatic black hole binary GRS 1915+105.
* The authors used simultaneous spectral fitting of RXTE and XMM-Newton data to put better constraints on the system parameters, as the system parameters cannot change over the phase of the oscillations.
* The results suggest that the faintness of igr j170913624 is due to its low or negative spin, which is in contrast to the high spin of GRS 1915+105.
* The authors also found that the oscillations were more pronounced in the XMM light curve, indicating that the accretion disk radiation was primarily participating in the oscillations and not the comptonized emission from the corona.
* The authors used the "heartbeat" pattern as a potential standard candle to estimate the distance for a given mass, which can be used to constrain the parameters. They found that the points within the possible range correspond to inclination angle < 60° and spin < 0.2. However, they also found a lower limit of 76.6° on inclination angle and a lower limit of 10.53° on inclination angle from the 90% upper confidence limit of diskpn normalization. The points requiring spin < 0.2 exclude the possibility of high spin. The 66 Hz hfqpo of igr j170913624 may also be considered as an independent constraint on black hole mass, which requires the black hole mass in igr j170913624 to be 39. The authors suggest that the basic accretion process giving rise to the apparent similar variability of GRS 1915+105 and igr j170913624 has to be different if the 66 Hz qpo is related to mass. However, it is more likely that the 66 Hz hfqpo is not directly related to the black hole mass, and the inference of low or negative spin remains valid.

* The tQD system consists of three coherently coupled quantum dots with a single electron spin on each dot. The exchange interactions between the spins are described by an effective Heisenberg Hamiltonian.

	+ The doublet blockade is related to an asymmetry of tunnel rates from source and drain electrodes to the tQD and the inter-channel Coulomb blockade.
	+ The method is compatible with purely electrical manipulations of the qubit and does not require charge-spin conversion.
	+ The relaxation and decoherence processes due to coupling with the electrodes and leakage from the doublet subspace are taken into account.

• Swcnt networks with randomly distributed single walled carbon nanotubes (swcnts) are emerging as novel materials for various applications, particularly as electronic materials.
• These networks can be viewed as a two-dimensional network of conducting one-dimensional rods with large length-to-diameter ratios.
• The junction resistance between nanotubes dominates the overall resistance for sub-monolayer networks, leading to percolation behavior with nonlinear thickness dependence.
• For thicker films, conductance through metallic tubes dominates, resulting in metallic behavior of the overall resistance.
• The frequency-dependent and electric-field-dependent conductivity have been investigated for individual swcnts and some types of swcnt networks.
• Burke et al. measured the microwave conductivity of individual swcnts and investigated their operation as a transistor at 2.6 GHz.
• For swcnt networks with 30 nm thickness, the ac conductivity is frequency-independent up to an onset frequency of about 10 GHz, beyond which it increases with an approximate power law behavior.
• Peit et al. found that conductivities at dc and 10 GHz are almost the same for swcnt networks with thickness in the range of tens of micrometers.
• Fuhrer et al. observed the nonlinearity of the electric field-dependent conductivity of relatively thick nanotube networks and claimed that charge carriers can be localized by disorder in the swcnts with an approximate length scale of 1.65nm.

• The frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity investigation of different network densities is important for understanding the electrical transport properties of swcnt networks and for applications such as high-speed transistors, transparent shielding materials, and interconnects in circuits.
• The onset frequency extracted from the frequency dependence measurement increases with the film thickness, while the length scale extracted from the electric field dependence measurement decreases at the same time.
• An empirical relation between the two transport measurement methods was developed using the measured onset frequency and extracted length scale for different films.
• Swcnt networks on polyethylene terephthalate (pet) substrate were prepared by the spraying method and characterized by their sheet conductance rather than conductivity due to the inhomogeneous nature

• Grover's algorithm is a quantum algorithm that can search an unsorted database more efficiently than classical algorithms due to quantum superposition and interference.
   • Three-qubit Grover's algorithm, specifically, can be implemented using four-level squids in cavity QED.
     • This implementation scheme has several advantages over the conventional gate decomposition method, including faster implementation time and higher fidelity.
   • Decay rates of the intermediate level and cavity field can affect the performance of the algorithm.
     • The fidelity and success probability of the algorithm decrease as the decay rates increase.
     • The proposed scheme can be performed with high success probability and fidelity as long as the decay rates are small enough.

<summary>

- In the 1970s, many-body theory was a popular topic in physics, particularly in the context of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and its effects on core levels in metals.
- The text discusses the many-body effects on XPS spectra, specifically the appearance of singularities near edges in absorption and emission spectra.
- The conduction band (CB) electrons can have various effects on the XPS peak from the core level. If the excitation is considered adiabatic, the screening of the core hole by the CB electrons leads to a shift of the peak to higher kinetic energy.
- However, the excitation is not adiabatic, and the CB electrons are left in a nonequilibrium state, resulting in plasmon replicas in the spectrum.
- The main peak corresponds to the system left in quasi-equilibrium, while the replicas represent states where one, two, or more plasmons are excited.
- The plasmon curve shows dispersion, and the replicas are not identical smaller versions of the main peak due to the different energies of the plasmons.
- The text also mentions the presence of single-particle excitations, which contribute to the tail and deform both the main peak and the plasmon replicas. The finite life-time of the core hole causes Lorentzian broadening of all peaks, and experimental uncertainties result in Gaussian broadening.

</summary>

<summary>

  * Replicas: states where one, two, or more plasmons are excited.

• The text discusses a study on the dynamics of a two-genotype system in a population undergoing evolution in a non-spatial environment.
• The study investigates the effects of nonlinear frequency-dependent selection and asymmetric mutation probabilities on the coevolutionary dynamics using the Moran process.
• The authors derive the stationary probability distribution of the system dynamics via its Fokker-Planck equation and analyze its implications, revealing new stable configurations and the impact of mutation rates on the dynamics.

Sub-points:
- The study uses the Moran process, a well-established model for understanding the interplay of selection, mutation, and genetic drift in evolutionary dynamics.
- The authors derive the Fokker-Planck equation describing the dynamics of the number of individuals of genotype 1 in the limit of large population sizes and quantify the quality of the fokker-planck approach for an example where the difference of simulation data and theoretical solution becomes almost not detectable for population sizes larger than a certain value.
- The study identifies the individual effects of selection, mean mutation rate, mutation difference, and genetic drift and analyzes the distribution to find that asymmetries in the mutation probabilities may induce the shifting of existing stable points of the dynamics to new positions and lead to the emergence of new stable points.
- The authors also find that dynamic fitness leads to multiple stable points of the dynamics induced by selection and genetic drift and show an example where three stable points exist, two caused by selection and one by genetic drift.
- The study concludes that frequency-dependent fitness together with asymmetric mutation rates induces complex evolutionary dynamics, particularly when interactions imply nonlinear fitness functions, and that there is no limit for the number of stable points that the dynamics can exhibit.
- The authors suggest that multiple metastable equilibria may exist in real biological systems whenever species interact in a way complex enough to imply a fitness that nonlinearly depends on frequency, and that a change may occur even in the absence of changes in the environment or due to stochastic switching from one metastable state to another.
- The study might serve as a promising starting point to investigate how nonlinear frequency dependencies impact evolutionary dynamics in complex environments.
- The authors acknowledge the support of EPSRC and thank Steven Strogatz and Stefan Eule for their contributions.

<summary>

- The phase-field method is a popular simulation technique for studying microstructure formation during solidification due to its algorithmic simplicity and ability to describe geometry in terms of phase fields.
- The method is based on the assumption that the interface thickness is much smaller than other physical length scales, and the equations are analyzed using matched asymptotic expansions to obtain effective boundary conditions.
- The thin-interface limit procedure was pioneered by Karma and Rappel, who obtained a thin-interface correction to the expression of the kinetic coefficient for symmetric models.
- However, extending this method to models with arbitrary diffusivities is not straightforward, as several new thin-interface effects appear which cannot all be eliminated simultaneously.
- One solution to this problem is the introduction of the antitrapping current for one-sided models, which restores local equilibrium and eliminates the temperature jump at the interface.
- However, there is a second, independent thin-interface effect, the Kapitza resistance, which cannot be removed by an antitrapping current.
- Orientation-field models for pure substances and alloys have been proposed to simplify the model by working with a small number of field variables, but they do not correctly describe the microscopic evolution of the orientation field due to connectivity and geometrical conservation laws.
- Phase-field simulations often include fluctuations, which are introduced in a qualitative way to trigger instabilities or create disorder in the geometry of microstructures.

* The text discusses the study of heavy fermion materials, specifically lanthanide-based heavy fermion metals, using the local moment approach (LMA) within the framework of dynamical mean field theory (DMFT).
* The LMA is a non-perturbative approach that introduces the notion of local moments and leads to a two-self-energy description, which captures the key correlated spin-flip dynamics. It has been shown to give good agreement with numerical results for the single-impurity Anderson model and static magnetic properties of known exact results.
* The text also discusses the extension of the LMA to handle the Anderson lattice model, particularly for the particle-hole symmetric limit appropriate to kondo insulators. This extension provides a rich description of transport and optical properties of kondo insulators, with excellent agreement between theory and experiment on essentially all relevant energy and temperature scales. The LMA has recently been non-trivially extended to handle the generic asymmetric Anderson lattice model and single-particle dynamics at finite temperature, enabling access to d.c. transport and optics. The text focuses on the strongly correlated heavy fermion regime and the thermal evolution of single-particle dynamics and scattering rates, as well as the d.c. resistivity and optical conductivities. The LMA results are compared to experiments for various heavy fermion materials, including YbRh2Si2, CeCoIn5, and UPt3.

- The text discusses the effects of static and fluctuating tension on semiflexible polymer looping.
- The polymers are modeled as semiflexible chains of beads with interaction potentials for stretching and bending.
- The dynamics of the beads are described by the overdamped Langevin equation with tension applied to the chain ends.
- The looping time, defined as the mean first-passage time to cross the free energy barrier, increases steeply with applied tension in the presence of static tension.
- For the case of time-dependent tension, the looping times are reduced and show a minimum at an optimal flipping time, a phenomenon called resonant activation.
- The radial distribution function of the mean-field wormlike chain model is used to calculate the looping time in the presence of tension.
- The simulation results agree well with the mean-field wormlike chain model for short chain lengths, but deviate for larger tensions due to chain extensibility.
- The study suggests that the sensitivity of looping on tension is an emergent behavior that manifests beyond the complexity of real DNA loop formation.

- The text discusses a new approach to obtain information about the relative distance between two identical incoherent point sources in a disordered environment using the analysis of fluctuations of emitted light.
- The method is based on the measurement of intensity fluctuations and the analysis of the intensity-intensity correlation function and speckle pattern formed by the two sources.
- The approach allows for monitoring the relative distance between the sources in the range of 10-500 nm with a precision not limited by diffraction but by the microstructure of the scattering medium.
- The method could simplify green function retrieval techniques in complex media by replacing the two-point field-field correlation of the background noise with a measurement at a single point of the intensity noise due to the two fluctuating sources.

- The text proposes a method to capture the interaction between two identical sources in a scattering environment using only the measurement of intensity fluctuations.
- The method is based on the analysis of the intensity-intensity correlation function and the intensity fluctuations in the speckle pattern formed by two identical and mutually incoherent point sources.
- The approach permits monitoring the relative distance between the sources in the range of 10-500 nm with a precision not limited by diffraction but by the microstructure of the scattering medium.
- The method could simplify green function retrieval techniques in complex media by replacing the two-point field-field correlation of the background noise with a measurement at a single point of the intensity noise due to the two fluctuating sources.
- The method shows that multiple scattering, which had long been considered as an unavoidable nuisance, can actually enhance the performance of sensing, imaging, and communication techniques.

- The electric fields at any point in the medium can be written in terms of the dyadic green function of the disordered medium, and the intensity associated to this field is a time-fluctuating and spatially varying quantity that forms a time-dependent speckle pattern.

• The text discusses a theoretical framework for understanding the inelastic nonlinear mechanical behavior of sticky biopolymer networks using the glassy wormlike chain (GWLC) model.
• The model extends the original equilibrium statistical fluctuations captured by the GWLC model by allowing for a dynamically evolving thermodynamic state variable characterizing the network of thermo-reversible sticky bonds.
• The theory predicts a pronounced fluidization response, which develops upon strong deformations on top of the intrinsic viscoelastic stiffening response provided by the individual polymers. After cessation of loading, the system slowly recovers its initial state. The yield force for the onset of fluidization is sensitive to the deformation rate, and the fluidization response is accompanied by a cyclic softening or shake-down effect. Taking into account the spatial heterogeneity of biopolymer solutions by a distribution of entanglement lengths leads to a smoothing of the force-displacement curves without affecting their qualitative characteristics. The model also integrates experimentally confirmed features of the GWLC response such as slow relaxation, power-law rheology, viscoelastic hysteresis, and shear stiffening with a simple bond kinetics scheme. It is also extendable to account for irreversible plastic deformations by accommodating an additional term acting as a slip rate in the rate equation.
