<summary>
• The text describes an invention for locating and tracing concealed elongated conductive objects, specifically improving the process when there is an adjacent object.
• Two general techniques for locating buried metallic objects exist: passive and active.
• The passive technique uses a gradiometer or similar device to detect magnetic fields from ferrous objects.
• The active technique uses a transmitter to induce currents in non-ferrous objects and a receiver to sense magnetic fields associated with those currents.
• The invention improves the ease and accuracy of locating and tracing one concealed, elongated, conductive object in the presence of an adjacent object.
• The system consists of a transmitter with a pair of antennae and a receiver, with both having means for sensing magnetic fields associated with the currents in the objects.
• The method involves producing distinguishable alternating currents in the objects and moving a receiver sensitive to the magnetic fields associated with those currents.
• The output signal is dependent upon the sensing of both magnetic fields.
• The invention uses a transmitter with a pair of antennae that generate distinguishable magnetic fields, optimally positioned relative to the objects to produce two distinct output signal nulls.
</summary>

• The invention employs a transmitter with a pair of antennae that generate distinguishable magnetic fields, F1 and F2.
• The signals that drive the antennae are distinguishable, inducing corresponding currents in the cables or pipes, C and C', respectively.
• The system is capable of producing two distinct output signal nulls, N and N', over respective cables or pipes.
• The output signal characteristics depend on the depth, distance, size, and conductivity of the objects.
• The invention alleviates the problem of tracing a desired cable or pipe in the presence of an adjacent one.
• The transmitter is optimally positioned relative to the cables or pipes for improved tracing operations.
• The receiver senses both magnetic fields associated with the currents in the respective cables or pipes and produces an output signal dependent upon the presence of both currents.
• Techniques to make the currents distinguishable include using different carrier frequencies, amplitude modulation, or pulsing at different repetition rates.
• The invention is especially useful in environments where the horizontal separation between the cables is related

• Invention relates to an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network for automatic answering and hands-free communication
• Includes a source of power, selective switch means, a coupler for automatically coupling the telephone network to the speaker device, and a timer for limiting call duration
• Two embodiments: optocoupler-based and neon lamp-based
• Optocoupler-based: uses an optocoupler to detect ringing signal and connect speaker phone to telephone lines automatically
  • Includes a blocking capacitor to prevent DC components from interfering with optocoupler
  • Timer limits call duration and can be bypassed with a selector switch
• Neon lamp-based: uses a neon lamp and photocell to detect ringing signal and connect speaker phone to telephone lines
  • Photocell resistance decreases as light intensity increases, triggering photocell relay to connect speaker phone
  • Timer limits call duration and can be bypassed with a selector switch
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention is a system for reducing or eliminating undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and supplying energy to those amplifiers over the same branch cables.
• Trunk and branch ring network consists of a ring topology optical fiber cable trunk, telecommunications hubs, and branch assemblies.
• Hub assembly with remote pumping includes a hub, light emitting power source, and an optical amplifier, all optically coupled to the trunk.
• Branch assembly includes a cable station, light emitting power source, branch fiber optic cable, branching unit, and an optical amplifier, all optically coupled.
• Energy from the light emitting power source is transferred unidirectionally over the branch fiber optic cable and used to amplify signals in the optical amplifier.
• Advantages include maintaining full connectivity during trunk and branch fiber optic cable cuts, respecting sovereignty concerns, and reducing capital and operating costs.
</summary>

• Trunk and branch ring network: ring topology optical fiber cable trunk, telecommunications hubs, and branch assemblies
• Hub assembly with remote pumping: hub, light emitting power source, and optical amplifier
• Branch assembly: cable station, light emitting power source, branch fiber optic cable, branching unit, and optical amplifier
• Energy transfer: unidirectional transfer over branch fiber optic cable, used for signal amplification
• Advantages: maintaining full connectivity during cable cuts, respecting sovereignty concerns, reducing capital and operating costs.

- The invention provides a cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices with no visible fasteners, easily installed or removed, and suitable for uneven walls.

Additionally, the invention can be used for multiple wiring devices in a ganged box, with the number of components adjusting accordingly. - The adapter member has a recess filled with compressible material to compensate for monitor curvature and an axial projection to attach to the monitor.

<summary>
• The invention is about a device for optical recording of rapid processes using a TV camera with means for deviating and suppressing the beam to scan over N lines of a picture plane.
• It includes a cyclic line counter, a sawtooth generator, and a beam suppression circuit.
• The cyclic line counter carries out one counting step for each line pulse and supplies an end-of-count pulse after p line pulses, with N/p being an integer > 1.
• The end-of-count pulse is applied to the beam suppression circuit for picture beam suppression.
• The sawtooth generator is synchronized with the output pulses of the counter and controls the vertical deviation of the beam.
• The sawtooth generator and beam suppression circuit are controlled via a delay device, whose delay time is a selectable part of a line period and is triggered by the output of the counter.
• The line counter is preferably a programmable counter.
</summary>

• Increases picture sequence frequency in a TV camera
• Uses a cyclic counter and a sawtooth generator for controlling vertical deviation and beam suppression
• Counter counts output pulses from pulse former and supplies end-of-count pulse after scanning p lines
• End-of-count pulse triggers beam suppression and sawtooth generator via delay device
• Delay device controls vertical deviation and beam suppression timing
• Programmable counter allows adjusting the number of lines scanned per picture (p) for optimal time and spatial resolution.

<summary>

- The present invention relates to content synchronization frameworks for connected devices using dynamic attributes and file bundles.
- Existing methods for data synchronization lack support for arbitrary attribute-based synchronization and geographic distribution of data sets.
- The invention provides a method for accepting context from a connected device, constructing response bundles, prioritizing download order, downloading files, confirming complete download, and rejecting incompletely downloaded bundles.
- The framework includes a central reference point, servers hosting files, software sending context, and network connectivity.
- The client shares contextual information with the central reference point, which uses it to compile bundle information and construct a response.
- The response includes bundles with priority download order and file descriptions, which are used by the client to create a delta list of files to download.
- The client downloads files in the delta list from various servers in the priority order.
- Incomplete bundles are rejected, and all bundles are downloaded to ensure synchronization efficiency.
- The framework supports multiple languages, character sets, and network topologies, and enables clients to have the latest and most relevant content based on their context.

</summary>

- The present invention is about content synchronization frameworks for connected devices using dynamic attributes and file bundles.
  * Existing methods have limitations in supporting arbitrary attribute-based synchronization and geographic distribution of data sets.
- The invention offers a method for accepting context from a device, constructing response bundles, prioritizing download order, downloading files, confirming complete download, and rejecting incomplete bundles.
  * The framework includes a central reference point, servers hosting files, software sending context, and network connectivity.
- The client shares contextual information with the central reference point, which uses it to compile bundle information and construct a response.
  * The response includes bundles with priority download order and file descriptions.
    * File descriptions help the client determine if the file is new and aid in processing the file.

- Owners can register their contact information and unique IDs associated with their possessions on a centralized database.
- Finders can access a website or virtual locale associated with a tag on a lost object to initiate communication with the owner using the unique ID.
- The system allows for anonymous communication between the finder and owner, protecting their privacy.
- The system also ensures that the owner's contact information is up-to-date and easily accessible to the finder.
- The system can be used with various types of tags, including printed labels, sew-on patches, plastic key-ring tags, and electronic tags.

- The system allows for various communication methods, including email, instant messaging, and text messaging, to facilitate the return of lost or misplaced objects.

<summary>

- The text describes a foil electron multiplier invention that uses a series of thin foils in an evacuated enclosure to amplify electrons or detect particles.
- The multiplier comprises a series of thin foils held by foil holders in an evacuated enclosure, with voltage applied to each foil to accelerate electrons and generate secondary electrons that continue to the next foil.
- The gain of the foil electron multiplier is maximized by maximizing electron transmission through the foil, transmission through the support grid, and secondary electron emission yield.
- The secondary electron yield from a primary electron exiting a foil is typically greater than that from a primary electron entering a surface, and the continuation of the primary electron with the secondaries it produces is a key advantage of the foil electron multiplier.
- The invention does not experience ion feedback, unlike continuous electron multipliers, which can resolve using curved channels.
- The foil dimensions for the present invention range from 0.5 cm to 2×4 cm, with a preferred embodiment using a 1 cm diameter, 0.2 to 1 μg/cm 2 foil.
- Carbon is the preferred foil material due to its thinness and uniformity, but other materials like silver, gold, chromium, and hydrocarbons can also be used.
- The thinner the foil, the lower the voltage required for secondary electrons to transit the subsequent foil, but a trade-off exists with the need for a supporting grid.
- The invention was demonstrated using a series of foil stages followed by a conductive anode, with resistors attached between adjacent foil stages and between the last stage and anode. The multiplier gain was measured as a function of applied voltage and number of stages, demonstrating a higher gain efficiency than conventional electron multipliers.

</summary>

<summary>

- The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention utilizes signals to synchronize lens filters to lateral motion in motion pictures and control the 3-dimensional visual effect for the viewer
- The signals are developed in real-time by the 3-D Phenomenoscope and do not require any alteration to the motion picture or control information placed in it
- The invention makes use of a computer algorithm running on a computer processor within the 3-D Phenomenoscope to calculate synchronization events from a multiplicity of media frames
- The preferred embodiment has no moving parts and no wire connections, and uses material that partially occludes or entirely clears in response to electronic signals
- The 3-D Phenomenoscope allows any motion picture with sustained lateral motion to be viewed with a 3-dimensional effect
- The invention works regardless of whether the motion picture was shot on regular or digital film, or presented on various media such as film, digital film, VCR tape, DVD, TV, or PC monitor
- The Pulfrich effect is used to produce the 3-dimensional illusion, which requires the brain to perceive depth from the slight difference in time it takes for each eye to receive an image
- The invention solves problems related to synchronization and control in motion pictures, such as the need for special equipment during filming and projection, and viewer discomfort from wearing special glasses
- The invention builds upon prior art references, including Steenblik's use of diffractive optical elements, Takahaski's use of spectacles based on the Pulfrich effect, Beard's use of gradients of optical densities, Hirano's use of spectacles with rotating lenses, and Davino's use of opaque frames to take advantage of the Pulfrich effect

</summary>

The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention:

- Allows any motion picture to be viewed with a 3-dimensional effect (Level 1)
  - Utilizes signals to synchronize lens filters to lateral motion (Level 2)
  - Calculates synchronization events in real-time (Level 2)
  - No alteration to the motion picture required (Level 2)
  - Controls the 3-dimensional visual effect for the viewer (Level 2)

<summary>
• The present invention discloses a method and apparatus for dicing semiconductor wafers using pressure to mechanically separate individual die without a wafer saw.
• The process involves forming trenches along scribe lines and applying mechanical pressure to singulate the die.
   • A photo resist layer is applied and patterned to expose the wafer surface along the scribe lines.
   • Trenches are etched along the scribe lines, and the wafer is back-ground if necessary.
   • Adhesive tape is applied to the back surface, and pressure is applied to singulate the die along the trenches.
• The apparatus includes a pad for supporting the wafer and a positioning member to position it. A pressure mechanism applies the necessary pressure to singulate the die.
</summary>

<summary>

* The present invention relates to a field emission display device with a protection structure to prevent burnout damage to field emission elements.
* The protection structure includes at least one reduction plate or electrode, typically on the cathode, which deflects the discharge path of ionized gases away from the cathode.
* The reduction plate is negatively charged by a bias voltage source, attracting positive nitrogen and oxygen ions and preventing them from contacting the cathode and inducing electrical surges.
* The protection structure can include multiple reduction plates interspersed among field emission elements or arranged in a meshwork- or net-shaped configuration.
* The field emission device includes a cathode, anodes, operating voltage source, and field emission elements. High-energy electrons emitted from the field emission elements strike molecular nitrogen and oxygen, forming positive ions that are deflected to the reduction plate, preventing damage to the field emission elements.

</summary>

* Protection structure for field emission display device
  * Includes at least one reduction plate or electrode
  * Deflects discharge path of ionized gases away from cathode
* Reduction plate
  * Typically on cathode
  * Negatively charged by bias voltage source
* Prevents burnout damage to field emission elements
  * Prevents ion-induced surges in electrical current
* Multiple reduction plates
  * Interspersed among field emission elements
  * Arranged in meshwork- or net-shaped pattern
* Field emission display device
  * Cathode, anodes, operating voltage source, field emission elements
  * High-energy electrons strike nitrogen and oxygen, forming positive ions
  * Ions deflected to reduction plate, preventing damage to field emission elements

<summary>

* The present invention relates to an image sensor with multiple imaging planes
* Objective: Overcome the problem of using only one imaging plane in prior art CCD image sensors
* Image sensor comprises: a semiconductor substrate, image sensor elements, and means for guiding charge carriers
* Substrate has a P-type material with a bottom layer highly doped and an upper layer lightly doped
* Image sensor elements include a charge collection and transfer means and an image sensing region
* Charge carriers generated at edges are guided back towards the middle of the substrate by the P + layers
* Advantages: permits imaging in a plurality of planes, suitable for various image formats, and can be easily incorporated in known image sensors
</summary>

* Substrate: P-type material with a bottom layer highly doped and an upper layer lightly doped
	+ Thickness of the upper layer determines effective vertical aperture dimension
	+ Carrier lifetime in the P + layers is low, and they do not contribute significantly to the aperture
* Image sensor elements: include an image sensing region, a charge collecting and transfer means, and are arranged in rows and columns
	+ Each image sensor includes a storage gate, a transfer gate, and a clock phase terminal
* Charge carriers generated at edges are guided towards the CCDs by the P + layers, forming a waveguide-like structure
	+ Carriers are free to diffuse laterally and are collected when they encounter the drift field from the storage gate depletion
* Second embodiment: CCDs extended to the edges to increase lateral extent of the depletion region, improving collection and reducing crosstalk
* Applications: simultaneous imaging of multiple planes, color applications with color filters and suitable optics, and various other uses.

<summary>
• The text describes a method for minimizing power consumption in home networks by transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device
• Master device performs network administrative functions and nominal device functions, while slave device only performs nominal device functions
• Master device sends data enabling slave device to perform network administrative functions and enters power save mode

• Master device determines if there is traffic on the network before entering power save mode
• If no traffic is found, master device enters power save mode
• If traffic is found, master device sends a transfer request to network slave nodes
• Slave nodes that accept the transfer request send a request reply to the master node
• Master node selects a slave node based on predetermined criteria to transfer network administrative functions
• Selected slave node becomes the new master node and master node enters power save mode

• Network slave node waits for a transfer request from master node
• If slave node is in power save mode, it does not accept transfer requests
• If slave node accepts transfer request, it sends a request reply to master node
• If slave node is selected by master node to be the new master node, network administrative functions are transferred and slave node becomes the new master node
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to an antenna array for measuring the direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation using radio interferometric techniques.
• It comprises at least four antennae spaced to provide at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane.
• Each triplet is characterized by the spacing of its elements and the height of the center element above the ground plane.
• Radio receiver means obtain information signals from each antenna of each triplet, whose amplitudes and phases are functions of the elevation angles and ground reflection coefficient.
• First and second logic means combine and derive signals from outermost and center antennae of each triplet, respectively.
• Dividing means divide one derived signal by the other to provide a quotient signal for each triplet, which is a function of the elevation angle but not the ground reflection coefficient.
• Selection means provide at least one quotient signal to measure the elevation angle.
• The array can operate in receive or transmit mode, with unambiguous angle measurement in the former and coded transmissions in the latter.
• A common coherent carrier is required for transmissions from each antenna in a triplet.
• Applications include determining the range, identity, and elevation angle of an aircraft carrying a transponder.
</summary>

• Invented system measures direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation using radio interferometric techniques
• Uses antenna array with at least four antennae in at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to ground plane
• Each triplet has specific spacing and height of center element above ground plane
• Radio receivers obtain information signals with amplitudes and phases dependent on elevation angles and ground reflection coefficient
• First and second logic means combine and derive signals from outermost and center antennae of each triplet
• Dividing means divide one derived signal by another to get quotient signals for each triplet, independent of ground reflection coefficient
• Selection means provide quotient signals to measure elevation angle
• Can operate in receive or transmit mode, with unambiguous angle measurement in receive and coded transmissions in transmit
• Common coherent carrier required for transmissions from each antenna in a triplet
• Applications include determining range, identity, and elevation angle of aircraft with transponder

<summary>
• The text describes an invention related to high intensity, thermal, efficient incandescent lamps and lamp systems with a liquid tight seal.
• Traditional subminiature lamps have a glass envelope supported by a base with a low pitch thread and a ceramic adhesive between the glass envelope and the metal sleeve.
• Problems with this design include adhesive breakdown due to thermal cycling, destructive shear caused by thermal expansion differences, vulnerability to liquid cleaning procedures, and moisture intrusion leading to corrosion.
• The invention uses a high temperature polymer in compression contact with the glass envelope, which provides extended axial length sealing, heat resistance, ease of handling, and increased resistance to invasion and chemical attack.
• The polymeric material is non-thermally conducting, able to withstand high temperatures, and can be shaped to complement the base for structural cooperation.
• The polymeric seal support can be made of a fluoroelastomer like VITON®, which offers excellent heat resistance, resistance to aggressive fuels and chemicals, and controlled flexibility at low temperatures.
• The polymeric seal support forms a housing around the glass envelope and the abbreviated height one piece conductive base, making a liquid tight seal.
• The addition of a potting material underneath the glass envelope further stabilizes the electrical leads and protects the upper portions of the leads from heat.
• The design eliminates the need for adhesive or cement, allowing for closer tolerance centering of the subminiature lamp to the axis of the base and reducing the number of sealing points.
</summary>

<summary>
• The text describes a technique for realizing a Generalized Decision Feedback Equalizer (GDFE) Precoder for multi-user (MU) MIMO systems, reducing computational cost without capacity loss.
• The method relaxes the requirement for knowledge of the covariance matrix (S zz ) corresponding to "Least Favorable Noise," which is the key component in conventional GDFE Precoder design and requires extensive computational cost.
• The described implementation achieves significant improvement in computational cost over conventional GDFE Precoders.
• The text presents a method for configuring a GDFE Precoder in a base station of a MU-MIMO wireless system, including computing a filter matrix C using one of several alternative formulas, and computing the transmit filter matrix B, feedforward filter matrix F, and interference pre-cancellation matrix G based on the computation of C.
• The text also describes an alternate method for computing the matrix C without using S zz .
• The text includes numerical examples illustrating the computation of various matrices involved in the design of GDFE Precoders using both methods.
</summary>

• Method for configuring a GDFE Precoder:
  • Compute filter matrix C using one of several alternative formulas.
  • Based on the computation of C, compute transmit filter matrix B, feedforward filter matrix F, and interference pre-cancellation matrix G.

• Alternate method for computing C:
  • Rewrite and substitute equations to obtain a new expression for C.
  • Solve the limit of the expression as X approaches 0 to obtain C.

<summary>

- The present invention relates to an electroluminescent display panel capable of displaying different colors without using an intermediate electrode.
- The display panel consists of various layers laminated on a glass substrate, including first and second electrodes, insulation layers, and luminescent layers.
- The first luminescent layer emits green light, while the second luminescent layer, which overlaps the first layer, emits orange or red light.
- The threshold voltage of the single layer portion is lower than that of the double layer portion, allowing selective display of green or lemon (mixture of green and orange) by changing the voltage level.
- The display panel can be used as an automobile instrument panel, displaying green light at night and lemon light at day time, providing high luminance and comfort to the driver.

Sub-points:
- The first electrodes are made of ITO and are perpendicular to the second electrodes, forming a matrix of picture elements.
- The first luminescent layer is made of TbOF-added ZnS and has a thickness of 600 nm, while the second luminescent layer is made of Mn-added ZnS and has a thickness of 400 nm.
- The threshold voltage difference between the single and double layer portions is determined by the layer thickness and properties of the materials used.
- The display panel can be manufactured using various processes, including DC sputtering, electron beam vapor deposition, and ion plating.

</summary>

• The text describes an electronic portable communications terminal for Internet/network telephony that uses a network and/or the Internet for transferring information/data representing digitized speech, sounds, music, etc.
• The terminal is designed to increase flexibility with respect to wireless communication/connection with a network and/or the Internet, and does not require specialized equipment and functionality to provide a connection. It also enables flexibility with respect to functionality, provides a simple design, small size, and reduced power consumption.
• The terminal comprises audio means for reproducing and recording sound, converting means for converting sound data into a suitable format, and protocol means for handling and controlling communication of data in accordance with a standardized Internet/network protocol.
• The terminal also includes wireless communications means for wireless near field communication of data with a connecting unit, and the ability to communicate additional information and/or data with the connecting unit.
• The system for Internet telephony includes a portable communications terminal, a connecting unit, and a service server connected to the Internet and/or a network. The server comprises one or more databases containing information related to potential desired communication receivers and/or transmitters, and is adapted to pass on information concerning the IP address of a desired communication receiver and/or establish a direct connection between the desired communication receiver and a communication transmitter/terminal.
• The method for Internet/network telephony includes reproducing and recording sound, converting sound data into a suitable format, handling and controlling communication with received and transmission data in accordance with a standardized Internet/network protocol, and wireless near field communication of data with a connecting unit. The method also communicates additional information and/or data with the connecting unit and establishes a connection to a service server on the network and/or the Internet.

• The text discusses the use of a Ge buffer layer between high-dielectric oxides and Si or metal to reduce reactivity, enhance epitaxy, and prevent the formation of low dielectric layers.
• Ge is a semiconductor that is thermodynamically stable next to many high-dielectric oxides and is compatible with Si process technology. It also allows for the epitaxial growth of high-dielectric materials on a conductor or semiconductor.
• The use of a stable ferroelectric buffer layer, such as SrTiO 3 or BaTiO 3, between a Pb containing ferroelectric and the Ge coated Si substrate can act as a chemical barrier and nucleate the desired perovskite structure.
• A second buffer layer of a stable ferroelectric can be used to improve the properties of the first ferroelectric layer and act as a diffusion barrier.
• The use of a Ge buffer layer allows for the fabrication of non-volatile, non-destructive readout memories using various stable ferroelectrics on Si, GaAs, and other III-V compounds.
• The text also mentions the importance of avoiding problems between the non-lead-containing high-dielectric material and the substrate and the use of a second germanium layer to allow for a wider variety of conductors for the top electrode and higher temperature processing.

* The text describes a problem in receiver input circuits where amplification control is necessary to protect semiconductor components from overloading and distortions caused by strong signals.
* Two types of amplification control circuits are used: a first circuit for preventing overloading of the mixer stage and varactor diodes, and a second circuit for protecting the mixer stage and oscillator from powerful usable signals or spurious signals.
* The first control circuit has an effective band width identical to the transmission band width and a signal response threshold below the modulation limit. The second control circuit has a smaller effective band width and a lower signal response threshold, and can support the other control circuits or have its response threshold controlled by the second control circuit.
* An embodiment of the input circuit includes a PIN diode for controllable signal attenuation, a preamplifier stage, a mixer and oscillator stage, an intermediate frequency filter, rectifier circuits, and a control signal processing circuit.
* The control signal is obtained from the rectifier circuits and smoothed by a capacitor before being used to control the PIN diode. This type of amplification control has the advantage of constant operating power and protection of all distortion-forming circuit components.
* The input network can be extended with a second PIN diode and an extended reactance network for greater control range and selectivity.
* The text also discusses a tunable selective circuit with varactor diodes and separate supply and adjustment of the tuning voltage for iteration-free alignment of all tunable tuning circuits. The resonant circuits are aligned to maximum amplification and identical C (U) characteristic.

<summary>

- The invention relates to setting up a collaborative work-share environment between parties during a telephone call, without complex setup processes.
- Each party has a collaboration button and indicator on their telephone set. When the indicator is lit, richer collaboration is possible.
- When a party activates the collaboration button, network-enabled applications are launched on their desktop computers, enabling information sharing and video conferencing while maintaining the voice connection.
- The telephone is used for regular voice-only calls, but determines if both parties have collaboration capabilities and illuminates the indicator accordingly.
- The invention includes various implementation examples, such as IP-based PBX systems, call control units, and collaboration control programs.

</summary>

- IP-based PBX system with telephone and desktop PC connected to a LAN
  * Telephone has a collaborate indicator and button
  * PC runs collaboration application programs and collaboration control program
- Call setup process between two parties
  * Phone-1 sends dialed digits to Phone-Proxy in Call Control Unit
  * Phone-2 responds with IP address of voice port, enabling duplex voice paths
- Collaborate indicator setup
  * Initiated by Call Completed event
  * Illuminated if both parties have a common collaboration application and protocol
- Collaborate button operation
  * Takes no action if indicator is not lit
  * Launches or brings collaboration application to foreground if indicator is lit and only one application is available
  * Displays dialog box with list of available applications if more than one is available
- General architecture with LAN generalized to include Internet
  * Stations can be located anywhere with Internet or other network access
  * Collaboration control program may be performed by ISP or PC
- Alternative configurations and implementations
  * Separate connections from phone to LAN and PC to LAN
  * Collaborate indicator or button on PC
  * Peer-to-peer architecture
- Applicable to multiparty collaboration and various deployment scenarios
- Can be implemented on top of dedicated telephone systems with data systems to connect telephone and PC at the desktop
- Can be implemented by remote computers connected over a network with integrated telephone and input device
- Invention encompasses computer program and carrier medium, such as floppy disk, CD ROM, programmable memory device

* The present invention optimizes the visual impact of an advertising clip inserted into a video sequence by considering the regions of interest of the video sequence and the advertising clip.
* The method involves generating salience maps for the video sequence and each advertising clip, determining the degree of similarity between the maps, and selecting the clip with the highest degree of similarity.
* The degree of similarity can be calculated using different methods, such as correlation coefficient or Kullback-Leibler divergence.
* The insertion point is preferably a shot change in the video sequence, and the method can be implemented using a device with processing, memory, and input/output capabilities.
* The device includes modules for generating salience maps, determining degrees of similarity, and inserting the selected clip into the video sequence at the insertion point.
* The method can also consider preselected clips based on their semantic content, theme, or other factors.

• The text describes an invention for reducing high electric fields and preventing electrical breakdown in very small semiconductor devices with sub-250 nanometer dimensions.
• The invention involves using a recessed mask structure to protect the dielectric material and reduce lateral leakage between adjacent metal lines, while maintaining a lower effective dielectric constant than a conventional structure.
• The mask is applied below the surface to be planarized, in a range of about 0.5 to 20 nanometers, to minimize damage during processing and ensure undisturbed surfaces.
   • The mask material is usually a harder low k dielectric, such as silicon nitride, and is recessed after chemical-mechanical polishing to a selectable thickness.
   • The invention results in a lower and predictable overall capacitance, leading to faster signal propagation in interconnect wiring.

<summary>

- The text describes an invention for a downconverting analog-to-digital converter (ADC) that utilizes predictive coding principles.
- The predictive loop filter is implemented using digital signal processing techniques, eliminating the need for complex discrete-time analog circuitry.
- The invention also uses a subharmonic mode to downconvert the signal and a variable gain amplifier controlled by the digital output of the loop to increase dynamic range.
- An offset nuller element is incorporated to eliminate DC offsets introduced by the implementation circuits.
- The invention has several advantages over prior art, including the ability to adapt the characteristics of the digital predictive loop to match those of the input signal, reducing complexity and improving dynamic range and noise performance.
- The design includes a digitally-controlled variable gain amplifier, a predictive digital filter, a digital quadrature mixer, a digital summing element, a digital-to-analog converter, and a digital offset nuller loop.

</summary>

- Eliminates complexities and adds flexibility by placing the sampler inside the predictive loop
- Downconversion is achieved in a subharmonic mode, reducing digital logic complexity
- Variable gain amplifier controlled by digital output of the loop increases dynamic range
- Offset nuller element eliminates DC offsets introduced by implementation circuits
- Predictive filter characteristics can be adapted to match input signal, improving performance
- Includes digital quadrature mixer, digital summing element, digital-to-analog converter, and digital offset nuller loop.

* The text describes a method for fabricating arrays of nano-scale features on a single wafer using nanoimprint lithography for sensor devices in a multiplex detection array.
* The fabrication process includes preparing the electrical base with semiconductor nanotraces, patterning the base electrode structures, and developing the electrical architecture for addressing each drain electrode.
* The set of parallel semiconductor nanotraces is fabricated using nanoimprint lithography, which involves preparing the imprint template, depositing a photoresist layer, and transferring the pattern into the semiconductor active layer through a series of dry etch processes. The resulting nanotraces have precise width, depth, and spacing, and are ready for functionalization with sensitizing compounds.

• The present invention provides a method of singulating and plating semiconductor packages, employing plating of the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe to prevent contamination of the lead surfaces.
• The method includes providing a plurality of semiconductor dies coupled to a leadframe, singulating the dies, and plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads with a plating material.
• The leads can be copper, and the plating material can be a metallic material such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold. The leadframe can be singulated using full or partial cutting, and the plating process can be performed before or after the singulation step. The side surfaces of the semiconductor package can have a step or beveled portion.

  • Full cutting: entire leadframe and molding compound are cut, leaving side surfaces of molding compound between dies
  • Partial cutting: only leadframe is cut, leaving individual semiconductor packages attached to each other

• Plating process
  • Exposed side surfaces of leads are plated with a plating material
  • Plating material can be a metallic material, such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold
  • Plating can be performed before or after singulation step

• Semiconductor package features
  • Side surfaces have a step or beveled portion
  • Top and bottom surfaces, as well as die attach pad region, are plated
  • Leads can be copper or other materials
  • Plating material is a non-reactive material to oxygen.

<summary>

- The invention relates to a method and system for a mobile terminal to selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN).
- The WLAN gathers information of neighboring base stations from an access point and broadcasts it to mobile terminals.
- When the mobile terminal connects to the WLAN, it receives the service information, which includes signal strength, channel information, and base station identity codes of nearby WWAN base stations.
- The mobile terminal uses the service information to skip some initial scanning procedures when connecting to the WWAN, accelerating the connection process.
- If the first wireless module fails to connect to the serving base station using the service information, it starts scanning all channels.
- The invention allows the mobile terminal to switch from the WLAN to the WWAN in a timely manner to avoid dropped or delayed connections.

</summary>

- Mobile terminal connects to WLAN and receives service information
  * WLAN access point gathers information of neighboring WWAN base stations
  * Service information includes signal strength, channel information, and base station identity codes
- Mobile terminal uses service information to skip initial scanning procedures when connecting to WWAN
  * Skipping initial scanning procedures accelerates connection process
- If first wireless module fails to connect to serving base station, it starts scanning all channels
- Mobile terminal switches from WLAN to WWAN to avoid dropped or delayed connections
- Invention provides method and system for efficient mobile terminal communication between WWAN and WLAN.

<summary>

* The text describes a new process for producing multilayered components, such as capacitors, eliminating steps 4 and 6 of the conventional process
* The process involves creating first and second laminate sub-assemblies by depositing electrical components on electrodes on decals
* Components are allowed to cure and solidify, then sub-assemblies are brought into mutually stacked relation and decals are removed
* The resultant assemblies are formed with precision registration and no large laminating force required, preventing delamination problems
* The process allows for various electrode configurations, such as T-shaped electrodes and electrodes that overlap the end surface of the component
* The new electrode configuration enables the formation of end terminations at the same time as the stack is fired, allowing for smaller parts and lower voltage ratings
* The process enhances in-process inspection and eliminates cutting stress cracks and internal delamination
* The lower labor content per part and end terminations of electrodes enable provision of a variety of tab configurations
* The invention is adaptable to other electronic ceramic devices, such as multilayer ferrite inductors and multilayer substrates
* The process allows for rapid response to customers by carrying inventory in decal form and fabricating capacitor plates and configurations as required
</summary>

* Elimination of steps 4 and 6 in conventional process
	+ Simplifies manufacture
	+ Elimination of labor-intensive steps
* Creation of first and second laminate sub-assemblies
	+ Deposition of electrical components on electrodes on decals
	+ Allowed to cure and solidify
* Precision registration and stacking of sub-assemblies
	+ Decals removed to form resultant assemblies
	+ No large laminating force required
* Various electrode configurations
	+ T-shaped electrodes with stem sunk in component recess
	+ Electrodes that overlap end surface of component
* End terminations formed at the same time as stack is fired
	+ Smaller parts possible

<summary>
• The invention describes a process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons using an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) plant and a Coal-to-Liquid (CTL) plant.
• Wet gasification stage:
    • Coal slurry is gasified to produce combustion gas at elevated pressure with a high H2/CO molar ratio.
    • The combustion gas is cooled and cleaned in a gas clean-up stage.
    • A portion of the combustion gas is enriched with hydrogen in a sour shift stage and used to increase the H2/CO molar ratio of synthesis gas precursor.
• Dry gasification stage:
    • Coal is gasified to produce synthesis gas precursor at elevated pressure with a lower H2/CO molar ratio.
    • The synthesis gas precursor is cleaned and enriched with hydrogen using H2-enriched gas from the wet gasification stage.
    • Synthesis gas is produced for hydrocarbon synthesis.
• Power is generated from the second portion of the combustion gas using a gas turbine expander and a steam turbine.
• CO2 is captured and used for enhanced oil recovery or enhanced coal-bed methane recovery.
</summary>

* The present invention provides a method for preparing a superconducting device with a blocking film to prevent oxygen removal from the surface of oxide superconducting materials.
* The method involves coating a thin film on the surface of the superconducting material using a photo CVD method, followed by adding oxygen and heat treatment to create a dense insulating layer.
** Film formation: A thin film is formed on the surface of the superconducting material using a photo CVD method, which can be an insulated or half-insulated film for a Josephson element or a passivation film.
** Oxygen addition and heat treatment: Oxygen is added to the surface or portion close to the surface, and the film is heat-treated to create a more complete blocking layer and optimize the oxygen concentration.

<summary>

- The invention relates to a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer, especially an ocean bottom seismometer (OBS), and for leveling its seismic motion detectors.
- Seismometers, including OBSs, are used in geological research, particularly for oil and natural gas exploration. OBSs are designed for remote operation on the ocean floor.
- The present invention provides a simple and inexpensive method for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer on the ocean floor and for preserving its orientation for later measurement.
- The invention comprises a seismometer with a spherical ball connected to a shaft, which forms a simple pendulum. The geophone, mounted at the end of the shaft, is aligned with the vertical when the pendulum is at rest.
- A plunger with a head and a coil spring is used to lock the spherical ball, shaft, and geophone in their positions once the seismometer is deployed.
- The plunger is positioned above the ball and is restrained from contacting it by a pin that passes through the plunger and is connected to a linearly acting solenoid.
- Once the seismometer is deployed, the solenoid is activated, causing the pin to be pulled from the plunger, which extends to contact the ball, locking the seismometer in place.
- The angle of inclination of the seismometer can be determined by measuring the acute angle formed by the ball, shaft, and geophone in their locked position and a known vertical surface.
- The invention also includes a method and apparatus for automatically leveling seismic motion detectors employed in the seismometer.

</summary>

- Simple and inexpensive method for determining angle of inclination of a seismometer on the ocean floor
- Preserves orientation for later measurement
- Spherical ball and shaft form pendulum, geophone aligned with vertical
- Plunger with head and coil spring locks spherical ball, shaft, and geophone in place
- Pin and solenoid used to extend plunger and lock seismometer
- Angle of inclination measured by acute angle of ball, shaft, and geophone
- Automatic leveling of seismic motion

<summary>
• The present invention introduces a new type of humidity sensing element for gaseous fluids.
• Key features include:
  • A first electrode formed from commercially pure aluminum and anodized to create a porous dielectric coating.
  • Minute particles of electron conductive material (nickel) deposited in the interstices of the porosity of the dielectric.
  • A second electrode formed by vacuum deposition of metal (nickel) on the sealed anodized coating.
• The impedance between the electrodes varies linearly with the relative humidity of the surrounding gaseous atmosphere when excited by a suitable alternating current voltage.
</summary>

• Manufacturing process:
  • Coat a portion of the first electrode with a porous coating of dielectric.
  • Deposit minute particles of electron conductive material in the interstices of the porosity of the dielectric.
  • Commonly contact the particles by means of an ion-forming material.
  • Form a second electron conductive electrode contacting the ion-forming material and pervious to moisture vapor.

• Preferred manufacturing method:
  • Form the first electrode from commercially pure aluminum and anodize it to form the dielectric coating.
  • Vacuum deposit atomic particles of nickel into the interstices of the porosity of the anodized layer.
  • Contact the particles in the interstices by hydrolizing and sealing the anodized coating.
  • Vacuum deposit nickel onto the sealed anodized coating to form the second electrode.

<summary>

- The present invention relates to a force transmission structure and a motor assembly for a window lift system.
- The force transmission structure includes a drive plate and a shaft with a Y-shaped mounting hole and toothed portion for securely connecting the two components.
- The drive plate has a coupling with buffer holes and a body with protrusions for engaging with a driving member.
- The motor assembly comprises a motor, force transmission structure, and gear train for driving the drive plate.

* Force transmission structure:
  * Comprises a drive plate and a shaft
  * Drive plate has a Y-shaped mounting hole and a coupling with buffer holes
  * Shaft has a toothed portion that fits into the Y-shaped mounting hole
  * Connection between the drive plate and shaft is stable and reduces noise

* Motor assembly:
  * Consists of a motor, force transmission structure, and gear train
  * Gear train connects the motor to the drive plate
  * Drive plate is driven by the worm gear through a damper
  * Shaft is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip
</summary>

The text describes a force transmission structure and a motor assembly for a window lift system. The force transmission structure includes a drive plate and a shaft with a Y-shaped mounting hole and toothed portion for securely connecting the two components. The drive plate has a coupling with buffer holes and a body with protrusions for engaging with a driving member. The motor assembly comprises a motor, force transmission structure, and gear train for driving the drive plate. The gear train includes a worm, worm gear, damper, and a capstan. The drive plate and shaft are made of different materials, such as plastics for the drive plate and low alloy steel or other metal materials for the shaft. The Y-shaped mounting hole and toothed portion of the shaft fit securely into the corresponding features on the drive plate, providing a stable connection that reduces noise and vibration. The buffer holes in the coupling of the drive plate aid in molding and provide relief to reduce distortion. The motor drives the worm, which in turn drives the worm gear, which rotates the drive plate and shaft to move the window up or down. The shaft is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip.

• The present invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver in WCDMA systems.
• One embodiment includes an antenna, RF subsystem, and baseband subsystem.
  • RF subsystem includes a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator.
  • Baseband subsystem includes a free running counter coupled to the high and low frequency oscillators.
• The free running counter generates the mobile time reference using the high frequency oscillator in active mode and the low frequency oscillator in idle mode.
  • The mobile time reference is maintained during idle mode and updated when transitioning to active mode.
• The mobile time reference is used for signal detection, identification, and monitoring of multipath signals in WCDMA systems.
• The invention also includes a method of generating a mobile time reference using a high frequency clock and a low frequency clock.
  • The mobile time reference is maintained using the low frequency clock when the high frequency clock is not available.
  • The mobile time reference is generated using the high frequency clock and the maintained mobile time reference as a starting point when the high frequency clock is again available.
</summary>

* The text describes various embodiments of a method for manufacturing a semiconductor device with a lightly doped drain (LDD) structure.
* The first embodiment involves forming a polycrystalline silicon layer on the gate sidewall and using it as a mask for ion injection to form the high density region of the source/drain.
* The second embodiment uses an oxide film on the gate sidewall as a mask for ion injection to form the high density region of the source/drain.
* The third embodiment forms the high concentration region of the source/drain prior to forming the low concentration region and uses the oxide film on the gate sidewall as a mask for both steps.
* The fourth embodiment uses an insulating film on the gate electrode as an etching stopper for anisotropic RIE of the conductive or polycrystalline semiconductor layer, allowing for precise control of the width of the portion on the gate sidewall.
* The fifth embodiment uses a high melting point metal or a silicide of such a metal for the gate sidewall portion to prevent degradation of the transconductance by hot-carrier injection.
* The sixth embodiment silicides the gate electrode and the source/drain, reducing the sheet resistance of the source/drain region and preventing a short-circuit between the gate electrode and the source/drain.
* The seventh embodiment uses an n-type substrate and injects p-type impurities to form a p-channel MOSFET with an LDD structure and a silicided gate electrode.
* The eighth embodiment silicides both the gate electrode and the source/drain, reducing the sheet resistance of the source/drain region and preventing a short-circuit between the gate electrode and the source/drain.
* The ninth embodiment uses a tungsten silicide layer to form the source/drain region, eliminating the need to remove the portion of the high melting point metal which is not silicided.
* The tenth embodiment uses an inert gas ion such as He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe or Rn to make the source/drain region amorphous, allowing for easy realization of shallow injection and minimization of the device size.

<summary>

- The present invention relates to an improved IP telephone system that overcomes the disadvantages of conventional IP telephony systems.
- The system includes an enhanced radio telephone that can operate as both a conventional radio telephone and an IP telephone.
- The enhanced radio telephone has an internal speech coder for low power consumption and can be connected to a PC via a serial or parallel port or wirelessly using IR or short range radio.
- During IP-telephone mode, the enhanced radio telephone passes coded speech signals to the PC, which formats them using an appropriate UDP/IP network protocol and transmits them to the network.
- The PC receives network-formatted far-end signals, converts them into coded far-end speech signals, and passes them back to the enhanced radio telephone for decoding and presentation to the user.
- The system provides several advantages, including reduced speech delay, a convenient and comfortable handset, and elimination of the need for a high-end PC or sound equipment.

</summary>

- Improved IP telephone system
  * Overcomes disadvantages of conventional IP telephony
  * Includes enhanced radio telephone
    * Operates as both conventional radio telephone and IP telephone
    * Has internal speech coder for low power consumption
- Connection to PC
  * Serial or parallel port
  * Wireless IR or short range radio
- Operation during IP-telephone mode
  * Coded speech signals passed to PC
  * PC formats signals using UDP/IP network protocol
  * Transmits signals to network
- Operation during IP-telephone mode (continued)
  * Network-formatted far-end signals received at PC
  * Converted into coded far-end speech signals
  * Passed back to enhanced radio telephone for decoding and presentation to user
- Advantages
  * Reduced speech delay
  * Convenient and comfortable handset
  * Elimination of need for high-end PC or sound equipment

* The text discusses an invention related to wave energy converters that utilize submerged devices to capture energy from surface waves using hydrostatic pressure differences and/or enhanced surge or pitch
* The invention aims to address the challenges of high cost and low efficiency in current wave energy converter designs, particularly those deployed near shore or on the sea bed
* The invention uses gas-filled or evacuated containers that deform or deflect in response to overhead wave-induced static pressure changes, enhancing or supplementing energy capture with overhead floating bodies
* The design features include tidal and sea-state depth adjustability, low moving mass, large deformation stroke, and the ability to capture both hydrostatic and hydrokinetic wave energy
* The invention distinguishes itself from prior art by using a flexible elastomer bellows or diaphragm, atmospheric venting or partial evacuation, and the ability to capture kinetic wave energy using a mechanical connection to a surface float. Additionally, the invention does not require a rolling membrane seal or a heavy, high maintenance ectoskeleton.

<summary>

- The text describes a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a cigarette-production or packaging machine.
- The problem is that cigarettes can end up in a transverse position, blocking individual shafts or shaft groups, resulting in disruptions that require laborious and costly elimination.
- The invention uses an optical checking element, such as a camera, to scan images of cigarettes in the magazine and evaluate them using an image-processing device.
- If a deviation from a reference image or reference value is detected, an error signal is produced.
- The advantages include monitoring a large area of cigarettes for orientation and the ability to detect not only transversely located cigarettes but also defective ones.
- The error signal can be used to eliminate the disruption manually or automatically, with the latter option ejecting a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.
- Each ejecting unit has a housing, a linear cylinder, and a guiding carriage connected to the actual ejector.
- The ejector has a front wall and a rear wall, which are connected by a rod and can be displaced in the direction of the chute when the ejecting unit is actuated.
- The four front walls and housing-like devices of the ejectors are spaced apart to prevent cigarettes from dropping into the region of the ejector when it is located in the ejecting position.
</summary>

* Process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes
* Problem: Cigarettes in transverse position block shafts or shaft groups, requiring laborious and costly elimination
* Solution: Optical checking element (camera) scans images of cigarettes, evaluated by image-processing device
* Advantages: Monitors large area for orientation, detects transversely located and defective cigarettes
* Error signal: Manual or automatic elimination of disruption
* Ejecting unit: Housing, linear cylinder, guiding carriage, ejector with front and rear walls
* Ejector displacement: Front and rear walls connected by rod, ejected cigarettes drop into chute
* Prevention of cigarettes dropping into ejector region: Spaced

<summary>

- The present invention relates to a simplified connection system for high voltage cables with ratings up to 400 KV and above.
- The invention provides a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections, resulting in advantages such as factory pretesting, reduced installation time and cost, and simplified field testing.
- The interface components do not include any gas or oil, making them non-leakable and non-explosive.
- The invention includes three interface methods: inner cone concept, outer cone concept, and no cone or slight inner cone concept. The outer cone concept separates the cable connection further from the apparatus, reducing the likelihood of faults affecting each other.

* Interface methods:
** Inner cone concept: separates the cable connection closer to the apparatus, may cause problems with coned surfaces due to differences in materials.
** Outer cone concept: separates the cable connection further from the apparatus, easier to expand rubber material than compress it.
** Plane surface interconnection: simplifies complete alignment of meeting surfaces and eliminates risk of glow discharges.

</summary>

- The outer cone concept has advantages over the inner cone concept, such as separating the cable connection further from the apparatus and making it easier to expand rubber material.
- The invention includes various applications, such as SF6 terminals, transformer terminals, out-door terminals, straight through joints, transition joints, and joints between two apparatus.
* SF6 terminals:
** Use a compact or rigid epoxy body instead of a hollow insulator, resulting in a compact design, lower material and installation cost, and complete independence between gas insulated switch gear and cable installations.
* Transformer terminals:
** Use an oil-filled box with a bushing or connect the bushing directly to the cable termination.
** Eliminate the oil-filled box for enhanced safety.
* Out-door terminals:
** Eliminate the need for an oil- or SF6-filled insulator while maintaining mechanical rigidity.
** Include a surge suppressor device for protection against voltage surges.
* Straight through joints:
** Use a symmetrical double cone design for a plug-in joint joining two cable terminations.
* Transition joints:
** Extend the epoxy

* The invention introduces an improved tool-fixing mechanism with curved connecting surfaces for secure and simple tool mounting and release.

  * At least one connecting surface in the tool frame and tool holder is shaped as a curved surface, allowing easy mounting and transmission of machining force.
  * The first and second contact surfaces are adjusted to be in contact in the operational position, ensuring a secure connection and transmitting machining force.
* Advantages:

* The text describes methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits with high efficiency and low EMI.
* Two embodiments are presented: interleaving parallel source and drain paths to cancel out EMI, and adding terminal leads to act as RF antennas and absorb leaking EMI fields.
** Interleaving source and drain paths:
*** Parallel source paths are placed between drain paths.
*** EMI produced in one path is cancelled by EMI produced in the adjacent path due to opposite current flow directions.
** Adding terminal leads:
*** Terminal leads are only connected at one end and do not carry current.
*** They act as RF antennas to pick up and absorb leaking EMI fields from adjacent fully-connected paths.

* The text describes a method for charging and balancing the voltage of cells in a battery pack to support a desired drive range.
* The method involves determining the maximum capacity of each cell, calculating the common voltage needed for each cell, determining the charge time for the battery pack, and activating resistive circuitry for underperforming cells to balance their voltages.
** Determining maximum cell capacity: Using equations (1) and (3), the controller measures the voltage and current of each cell to calculate its maximum capacity.
** Calculating common voltage: The controller uses the minimum Amp-hr cell assumption and the maximum Amp-hr cell assumption to calculate the required voltage for each cell to meet the desired drive range.
** Determining charge time: The controller calculates the time required to charge the battery pack based on the cell with the greatest ΔIhrs and the charge current rate.
** Activating resistive circuitry: The controller activates resistive circuitry for underperforming cells during charge to balance their voltages and ensure they reach the target voltage.
** Balancing during charge or end of charge: If the time required to balance the cells exceeds the charge time, the controller may balance the cells at the end or beginning of the charge cycle instead.
** Implementation: The algorithms can be delivered to or implemented by a processing device, such as a controller or battery charger, using hardware, software, or a combination of both.

<summary>
• The invention provides a new approach to maintenance of illumination in a space using a closed loop system for control of electric lights and window treatments based on a single input variable derived from interior sensors.
• The system eliminates the need for exterior sensors and complex data gathering and setup procedures, reducing overall system cost.
• The system allows for sun glare in the interior space to be controlled, providing near optimal illumination control and energy savings.
• The system can maintain a desired illumination profile for multiple lighting conditions and presets.
• Two electric light control methods are described: open loop and closed loop.
• The open loop method uses a fixed number of presets and adjusts electric light levels based on photosensor readings.
• The closed loop method uses a hysteretic light level comparator and adjusts electric light levels based on the difference between the current light level and the target value.
• The system can vary the time delay to operate window treatments based on the amount of illumination and adjust the dead-band set point to reduce glare.
• The system can be programmed to control window treatments based on interior sensor readings and adjust electric light levels based on exterior sensor readings.
</summary>

• New approach to illumination maintenance in a space using closed loop system for electric lights and window treatments based on interior sensors
• Eliminates need for exterior sensors and complex data gathering and setup procedures, reducing overall system cost
• Allows for sun glare in interior space to be controlled, providing near optimal illumination and energy savings
• Maintains desired illumination profile for multiple lighting conditions and presets

• Open loop method uses fixed number of presets and adjusts electric light levels based on photosensor readings
  • Adjusts electric light levels based on difference between current light level and target value
  • Uses hysteretic light level comparator

• Closed loop method adjusts electric light levels based on difference between current light level and target value
  • Uses hysteretic light level comparator
  • Varies time delay to operate window treatments based on amount of illumination
  • Adjusts dead-band set point to reduce glare

• System can be programmed to control window treatments based on interior sensor readings and adjust electric light levels based on exterior sensor readings.

<summary>

* Before September 2001, significant vulnerabilities in aviation security were identified, including weaknesses in screening passengers and baggage, controlling access to secure areas, and protecting air traffic control computer systems and facilities.
* To address these vulnerabilities, the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was created and mandated deadlines for security requirements were established.
* Before September 2001, airport screeners, who were then hired by airlines, often failed to detect threat objects, with principal causes being high turnover and insufficient training.
* Access controls for secure areas of airports did not always work effectively, allowing unauthorized individuals to gain access to secure areas and aircraft.
* The air traffic control computer systems and facilities were also vulnerable to intrusion and malicious attacks, making the air traffic control system susceptible to disruption and potential loss of life.
* TSA has taken major steps to increase aviation security since September 2001, including implementing congressional mandates and exploring options for technology and information to control access and improve passenger screening.
* FAA has focused on enhancing the security of the nation's air traffic control systems and facilities.
* Ongoing work includes examining initiatives to strengthen control over access to secure areas and improve passenger screening, as well as developing a comprehensive plan for air cargo security.

</summary>

* Weaknesses in aviation security before September 2001: screening passengers and baggage, access controls, air traffic control systems and facilities
* Creation of TSA and mandated deadlines for security requirements
* Rapid turnover and insufficient training of airport screeners
* Inadequate access controls at airports, allowing unauthorized individuals to gain access to secure areas and aircraft
* Vulnerabilities in air traffic control computer systems and facilities, making the air traffic control system susceptible to disruption and potential loss of life
* TSA's efforts to increase aviation security since September 2001: implementing mandates, exploring technology and information options
* FAA's focus on enhancing security of air traffic control systems and facilities
* Ongoing work: examining initiatives to strengthen access control and improve passenger screening, developing a comprehensive plan for air cargo security.

<summary>

* LDA and IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) were enacted at different times and for different purposes
* LDA requires organizations to register and report lobbying efforts to the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives, focusing on public disclosure of federal lobbying
* IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) do not have the same focus on public disclosure, but they do impact LDA reporting in different ways
* IRC section 4911 limits lobbying by 501(c)(3) organizations and clarifies the extent to which they can lobby without jeopardizing their tax-exempt status
* IRC section 162(e) denies federal income tax deductibility of certain lobbying expenses for businesses
* Differences in the definitions of lobbying under LDA and IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) can affect registration and reporting under LDA
* Organizations using the IRC definitions for tax purposes may report different lobbying expenses and related information than those using the LDA definition, potentially reducing the transparency of LDA's public disclosure purposes

Under LDA:

* Registration and reporting requirements for lobbying federal officials
* Semiannual reporting of lobbying expenses and related information
* Minimum thresholds for registration and reporting

Under IRC sections 4911 and 162(e):

* Different definitions of lobbying, covering both federal and state/local government officials and grassroots lobbying
* Different coverage of executive branch officials for nonlegislative matters
* Different treatment of lobbying expenses for tax purposes
</summary>

<summary>
• GAO has been advocating for strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions since 2002
• Companies that adopted strategic sourcing saw significant savings through tactics like leveraged buying, managing demand, standardization, and evaluating total cost of ownership
• Federal government's procurement spending is decentralized, leading to missed opportunities for leveraging buying power and achieving savings
• Challenges to strategic sourcing in the federal setting include obtaining reliable data, securing expertise, and gaining leadership commitment

• Data: Agencies face difficulties in gathering comprehensive data for spend analysis, which is essential for strategic sourcing
• Expertise: Lack of trained personnel in strategic sourcing and spend analysis hinders agencies from conducting effective opportunity analyses
• Leadership commitment: Senior management support and resources are necessary to facilitate strategic sourcing efforts and ensure follow-through
</summary>

<summary>

* The current surface transportation programs are not effectively addressing the nation's transportation challenges
* Many programs lack clear links to needs or performance, and some goals and roles are conflicting
* Federal surface transportation programs have grown in number and complexity, leading to a variety of grant structures and approaches
* Goals for federal involvement in surface transportation should be clearly defined, and the federal role should be established in relation to other entities
* Performance and accountability should be incorporated into funding decisions, and the best tools and approaches should be employed to improve results and ensure fiscal sustainability
</summary>

* Lack of clear goals and roles:
  * Many programs not linked to needs or performance
  * Goals and roles sometimes conflicting
* Growth of federal surface transportation programs:
  * Variety of grant structures and approaches
  * Some goals and eligibility requirements give broad discretion to states and local governments
  * Others require grantees to compete for funding based on specific criteria and goals
* Defining goals and federal role:
  * Goals should be specific and outcome-based
  * Federal role should be defined in relation to other entities and national interests
* Performance and accountability:
  * National performance goals should be identified and discussed in relation to state, regional, and local performance goals
  * Performance measures should be outcome-based and funding linked to performance
  * Incentives or penalty provisions should be included to hold stakeholders accountable for achieving results
* Best tools and approaches:
  * Costs and revenues should be considered in relation to stakeholders and the level of federal involvement
  * Tools and approaches should align with the level of federal involvement and provide flexibility and incentives for state and local governments
* Fiscal sustainability:
  * Current concerns suggest an opportune time for reexamining the federal role in transportation and improving progress toward specific, nationally defined outcomes
  * A range of options, including altering existing or introducing new funding approaches and employing various financing mechanisms, could be used to address projected transportation funding shortfalls
  * Each financing strategy is a form of debt that ultimately must be repaid with interest, and policy makers must decide how borrowed dollars will be repaid, either by users or by the general population either now or in the future through increases in taxes or reductions in other government services.

• FAA engages in three primary activities: aviation safety oversight, ATC, and airport infrastructure development
• Costs associated with each activity depend on the nature and usage of the specific service

• Aviation safety activities:
  • Licensing of pilots and mechanics
  • Inspection of various aspects of the aviation system
  • Costs primarily driven by volume of services

• ATC activities:
  • Commercial aircraft fly under instrument flight rules (IFR) requiring ATC services throughout a flight
  • Control towers and terminal radar approach control centers (TRACONs) provide terminal services
  • Air route traffic control centers (ARTCCs) provide en-route services
  • Costs influenced by amount and nature of specific services used and peak periods

• Airport infrastructure development:
  • Funded through the Airport Improvement Program (AIP)
  • AIP expenditures not directly linked to costs imposed by users
  • AIP funding based on congressional priorities and does not represent a "cost" of providing services to users.

<summary>

* The Institute of Medicine published a report in 1993 revealing that approximately 60,000 military personnel were used as human experimental subjects during World War II, exposed to mustard agents and lewisite.
* In 1993, VA lacked information about individuals exposed during secret DOD chemical tests.
* After a series of letters between Members of Congress, the President, and the Secretary of Defense, the Deputy Secretary of Defense issued a memo releasing all individuals from nondisclosure restrictions and directing efforts to declassify and provide information to VA.
* The Chemical Weapons Exposure Study Task Force was established to identify DOD personnel exposed to chemical substances during testing, training, transport, production, and storage.
* The task force identified approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians who were potentially exposed to mustard, lewisite, and other chemical substances.
* In 2000, the issue of servicemembers being used as human subjects during DOD's chemical and biological tests received attention again, leading to actions to identify potentially exposed individuals.
* DOD identified 5,842 servicemembers and estimated that 350 civilians had been potentially exposed during Project 112 tests.
* DOD's current effort to identify individuals who may have been exposed to chemical or biological substances during activities outside of Project 112 lacks clear objectives, adequate oversight, effective coordination with other entities, and transparency.

</summary>

	+ VA lacked information about individuals exposed during secret DOD chemical tests.
	+ A series of letters between Members of Congress, the President, and the Secretary of Defense led to the release of all individuals from nondisclosure restrictions and efforts to declassify and provide information to VA.
