<summary>

* Mexican criminal groups, initially emerged as Drug Trafficking Organizations (DTOs) in the 1980s and 1990s, have grown in power and expanded their criminal activities beyond drug trafficking.
* The Mexican government, under President Felipe Calderón, mobilized military and law enforcement agencies to combat DTOs in 2006.
* Under current President Enrique Peña Nieto, the emphasis has shifted towards reducing criminal violence and securing the business sector.
* Mexican DTOs are known to operate in over a thousand cities in the United States, and their criminal activities include human trafficking, kidnapping, money laundering, extortion, bribery, racketeering, weapons trafficking, and the smuggling of billions of dollars' worth of narcotics into the United States annually.
* Firearms are a constant requirement for DTOs to assert control, eliminate rivals, enforce illicit business dealings, and resist government operations.
* Firearms acquired from the United States are primarily transported overland using the same routes and methods employed for drug and cash smuggling.
* The United States and Mexico have committed to working together to stem the activities of these criminal organizations, including illicit arms trafficking. Since 2008, about $2.5 billion in assistance has been provided through the Mérida Initiative.

</summary>

* Mexican criminal groups, known as Drug Trafficking Organizations (DTOs), have grown in power and expanded their criminal activities beyond drug trafficking.
	+ Human trafficking, kidnapping, money laundering, extortion, bribery, racketeering, weapons trafficking.
* Mexican government's efforts to combat DTOs:
	+ Mobilized military and law enforcement agencies under President Felipe Calderón in 2006.
	+ Current President Enrique Peña Nieto's emphasis on reducing criminal violence and securing the business sector.
* DTO criminal activities:
	+ Seized in Mexico and traced by ATF, 70% originated in the United States (2009-2014).
	+ Firearms of choice for drug traffickers are high caliber assault rifles and military grade equipment.

<summary>

* NCHIP is a federal grant program to improve criminal history records and facilitate their exchange between states and the FBI
* States have used NCHIP funds primarily for NICS-related purposes, such as converting manual records to automated formats and purchasing equipment for computerized systems
* Automation levels and accessibility of criminal history records have improved in recent years, but challenges remain, such as the availability of disposition information and records related to certain disqualifiers like domestic violence misdemeanors and mental health commitments
* NCHIP has encouraged states to automate criminal history records and make them accessible nationally since its inception in 1995
* NCHIP funds have been used to develop or improve sex offender registries and contribute data to national sex offender databases
* NCHIP's goal is to improve public safety by enhancing the quality, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records for criminal justice and authorized noncriminal justice purposes

</summary>

* NCHIP grants have been used to support NICS in conducting background checks of firearms purchasers
* Over $165 million in NCHIP grants were awarded during fiscal years 2000 through 2003, with the majority going to NICS-related purposes
* NCHIP funds have also been used for other records improvement efforts, such as AFIS/Livescan activities, sex offender registry enhancements, and national security/antiterrorism activities
* States' participation in NICS has made little difference in how NCHIP funds are used
* NCHIP funds have played a role in leading states to accomplishments such as the establishment of the NCIC Protection Order File, the National Sex Offender Registry, and the implementation of IAFIS
* NCHIP is best viewed as an "umbrella" program that pools or coordinates various streams of monies and requires states to provide a 10% match to federal funds.

• Superfund program was established under CERCLA in 1980 to clean up severely contaminated hazardous waste sites
• As of December 1996, there were 1,210 sites on the National Priorities List (NPL)

• Incineration used as cleanup remedy at about 6% of Superfund sites
• Three incinerators operating at Superfund sites: Bayou Bonfouca in Louisiana, Times Beach in Missouri, and Baird and McGuire in Massachusetts

• Incineration involves preparing and burning wastes, collecting and removing ash, and cooling and releasing cleaned gases
• Fixed facility hazardous waste incinerators require RCRA permit and inspections every 2 years

• Superfund incinerators not required to have operating permits, but must meet RCRA's substantive requirements
• EPA uses four methods to ensure safe operation: site-specific standards, safety features, monitoring, and 24-hour oversight

• Site-specific standards based on site characteristics and adopted from other environmental programs
• EPA requires engineering controls and safety features to prevent emissions from exceeding standards
• EPA monitors emissions continuously and performs detailed laboratory analyses
• EPA provides 24-hour on-site oversight through Corps of Engineers or state agencies

• EPA had planned to implement additional methods to promote safe operation but never fully did so
• EPA issued a directive for inspectors to evaluate Superfund incinerators but did not follow through
• EPA intended to systematically share lessons learned but did not revive plans for preparing fact sheets or monthly conference calls

• EPA employs various techniques to encourage safe operation, including mechanical features and operational procedures
• Residents desire additional assurance that incinerators are operating safely
• EPA has not followed through on opportunities to improve oversight and provide additional assurance to the public, such as having RCRA inspectors inspect Superfund incinerators and sharing lessons learned from site to site.

<summary>
• SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were fairly presented in all material respects, but internal control deficiencies existed
• Material weakness in financial reporting process: period-end financial reporting, disgorgements and penalties, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures
• Significant deficiencies in internal control: information security, property and equipment, and accounting for budgetary resources
• Information security: SEC made progress but still lacks consistent implementation of key controls to safeguard financial and sensitive information
• Property and equipment: inaccuracies in recorded acquisition costs, dates, and errors in capitalization and amortization
• Budgetary resources: recording obligations prior to having documentary evidence, incorrect posting configurations, and errors in recording new obligations and deobligations
• SEC management responsible for preparing financial statements, establishing and maintaining internal control, and complying with laws and regulations
</summary>

• Material weakness in financial reporting process:
  • Period-end financial reporting: extensive manual procedures and lack of integration with general ledger system
  • Disgorgements and penalties: errors in spreadsheet calculations for accounts receivable balances
  • Accounting for transaction fee revenue: lack of written procedures to ensure adjustments are made for actual transaction volumes
  • Preparing financial statement disclosures: numerous errors in amounts, breakouts, and carry-forwards from previous year

• Significant deficiencies in internal control:
  • Information security: weaknesses in controls for malicious code attacks, access privileges, intrusion detection, and physical security
  • Property and equipment: lack of process for comparing received items against orders, insufficient oversight of recording acquisition dates and values, and lack of integrated financial management system
  • Budgetary resources: recording obligations prior to having documentary evidence, incorrect posting configurations, and errors in recording new obligations and deobligations

<summary>

* The Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees in 1997, with a focus on analyzing the cluster-level EAS workforce.
* The EAS workforce consists primarily of employees in EAS 11 through 26 positions, with management-level positions beginning at EAS 16.
* The Service's diversity development program includes efforts to provide equal employment opportunities, take advantage of a diverse workforce, and compete effectively.
* A study by Aguirre International in 1997 found that women and minorities were experiencing problems advancing to management jobs at EAS 17 and above positions.
* The Service developed an action plan to address diversity issues raised by the Aguirre report.
* The Service's cluster-level workforce was underrepresented in terms of white and Hispanic women and Native American men compared to the 1990 CLF.

* Representation of women and minorities increased between fiscal years 1993 and 1997, but black men's representation decreased slightly.
* Representation of women and minorities among those promoted to EAS 17 and above positions was higher than their representation in those positions before the promotions, except for Asian women.
* Women and minorities were less represented in EAS 17 and above positions than in EAS 11 through 16 positions.
* The Service has implemented 23 initiatives to improve diversity, with nine completed and seven nearly completed as of December 1998.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Military Working Dog (MWD) program involves dogs bred, procured, or acquired by the Department of Defense (DOD) for various roles, including explosive and illegal narcotic detection, patrol, and tracking.
• MWDs are removed from service due to medical or behavior problems, lack of need by the military, or other circumstances. Robby's Law, enacted in 2000, requires the military to make suitable MWDs available for adoption.
</summary>

• Adoption process:
  • Handlers interested in adopting an MWD must communicate with the Kennel Master where the MWD is located.
  • The Unit Commander determines which handler is in the best interest of the MWD if multiple handlers are interested.
• Medical care:
  • Army Veterinary Corps Officers provide recommendation letters and consultation/referral forms for MWDs during the disposition process.
  • The Army maintains a veterinary care system that provides medical care to privately owned animals, including adopted MWDs, for a fee.
• Prevalent medical conditions:
  • Skin conditions or ear infections and dental disease or injury are common but unlikely to result in removal from service.
  • Degenerative lumbo-sacral stenosis, arthritis or degenerative joint disease, and degenerative lumbo-sacral stenosis are more likely to result in removal from service and are common in breeds used by the MWD program.
• Assistance with veterinary care:
  • The U.S. War Dogs Association offers prescription drugs, free specialty care, and financial assistance for adopted MWDs.
  • Other organizations, such as the American Humane organization, also provide assistance with veterinary care for adopted MWDs.
• Access to veterinary care:
  • Owners of adopted MWDs may purchase veterinary services through DOD if they have access to medical services at military installations.
  • The availability and types of veterinary services offered vary by military installation.

<summary>

* The Comanche helicopter program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter.
* The program faced challenges due to ambitious maintainability goals, budgetary constraints, and the need to develop advanced technologies.
* In response to budgetary constraints, the Secretary of Defense restructured the Comanche helicopter program in 1994, reducing funding and extending the development phase.
* The Army proposed a restructure that allowed for the acquisition of six "early operational capability" aircraft, which would provide additional aircraft for testing and evaluation.
* The Comanche program faced risks associated with high concurrency, software development problems, maintainability issues, and weight growth.
	+ The program's high concurrency increased the risks of production items having to be retrofitted and system design not being thoroughly tested.
	+ Software development problems included delays, lack of a uniform compilation system among developers, and high turnover of software personnel.
	+ Maintainability requirements, such as direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour and mean time to repair, were not being met, putting lower operating and support costs and wartime availability goals at risk.
	+ Weight growth affected vertical rate of climb performance and could require engine redesign.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Food Stamp Program provides low-income households with paper or electronic benefits for purchasing food
• FNS funds and regulates the program, with states determining eligibility and issuing benefits
• Recent changes include options for increasing access and reducing reporting burden, such as categorical eligibility and reporting waivers
• Payment errors occur due to mistakes by recipients and caseworkers, with about half due to incorrect determination of household income
• States use various options and waivers to reduce reporting requirements and payment errors, including semiannual reporting and categorical eligibility for TANF recipients
</summary>

• Food Stamp Program basics:
  • Provides benefits to eligible low-income households
  • FNS funds and regulates, states administer
  • Eligibility based on income and asset limits

• Recent changes:
  • Increase access, reduce reporting burden
    • Categorical eligibility for TANF recipients
    • Reporting waivers for households with earnings
  • Monitoring and accountability
    • Quality control system measures state performance
    • Payment errors occur for various reasons

• Payment errors:
  • Overpayments and underpayments
  • Causes: mistakes by recipients, caseworkers, or both
  • About half due to incorrect determination of household income

• State options and waivers:
  • Semiannual reporting for households with earnings
  • Categorical eligibility for TANF recipients
  • Other reporting waivers and simplified eligibility determination processes
  • States use these options to increase access, simplify administration, and reduce payment errors

<summary>

* HUD is a federal agency established in 1965 responsible for housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues
* HUD had 9,386 employees as of February 1999

Housing Assistance:
* Provides public and private-market housing assistance through Section 8 program
* Benefits limited to about one-fourth of eligible individuals due to budgetary constraints

Community Development:
* Provides grants for local economic development, housing development, and assistance to the homeless
* Funding for some programs may be distributed directly to nonprofit groups and organizations

Housing Finance:
* Insures lenders against losses on mortgages for single-family and multifamily properties
* Guarantees investors the timely payment of principal and interest on securities issued by lenders

Regulatory Issues:
* Regulates interstate land sales, home mortgage settlement services, manufactured housing, lead-based paint abatement, and home mortgage disclosures
* Supports fair housing programs and enforces federal fair housing laws

Budget:
* Proposed budget for fiscal year 2000 is $34 billion in discretionary outlays, a 9-percent increase in budget authority over fiscal year 1999
* Includes 19 new initiatives and programs, 7 of which are set-asides totaling $210 million

Section 8 Housing Assistance Program:
* HUD has previously overstated funding needs, leading to unnecessary requests for project-based funding
* HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget justification does not identify shortfall estimates or available unexpended balances
* HUD has requested information from GAO on shortfall estimates and unexpended balances

CDBG Program:
* Provides grants for activities that benefit low- and moderate-income people and address urgent community needs
* HUD plans to replace IDIS with a new grants management system, but IDIS is not secure and does not provide detailed performance information
* Unused CDBG balances have been increasing and $7.6 million in funds expired in 1998 without being used for grantees
</summary>

<summary>

• DOD's Military Health System has a dual mission: readiness and benefits
• The replacement medical center at Weilerbach Storage Area in Germany will consolidate LRMC and 86th MDG clinic into one facility
• The facility will be operated by the Army, with Air Force providing clinical services
• DOD used beneficiary population data and cost-benefit analysis to determine the need for a single medical center
• The replacement medical center will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for EUCOM, Central Command, and Africa Command

• Beneficiary population data:
    • March 2010 data identified areas served by the proposed medical center
    • Reductions in contingency operations in Afghanistan and changes in troop strength in Europe have been assessed for impact
• Cost-benefit analysis:
    • Initial plans included renovation of LRMC and construction of a new clinic for 86th MDG
    • Consolidation of the two projects into one facility was determined to be more efficient and cost-effective
</summary>

* ICE officers and attorneys exercise discretion during the alien apprehension and removal process in various phases, including initiating removals, apprehending aliens, issuing removal documents, and detaining aliens.
* Internal controls include policies, procedures, and training to guide officer decision making, such as factors to consider when making apprehension, charging, and detention decisions for aliens with humanitarian issues.
* ICE has taken steps to improve training and guidance for officers, including worksite enforcement training and Spanish language training for DRO officers, but more comprehensive and up-to-date guidance is needed to support officer decision making in complex situations.

* Officers exercise discretion for aliens with humanitarian issues and those who are not investigation targets on a case-by-case basis with guidance from supervisors.
* Discretion for aliens who are fugitives, criminals, and other investigation targets is limited by clearly prescribed policies and procedures.
* ICE has not completed efforts to provide officers with complete and up-to-date guidance to reflect expanded worksite and fugitive operations enforcement efforts.

* ICE officers require information on relevant legal developments to help inform their decision making regarding removal dispositions.
* ICE has not instituted a mechanism to ensure that legal developments are consistently disseminated to ICE officers across all field offices.
* The lack of comprehensive guidance and a mechanism to ensure consistent information dissemination puts ICE officers at risk of taking actions that are not appropriate exercises of discretion and do not support the agency's operational objectives.

* Ground ambulance services vary in organizational structure, staffing types, transports offered, and revenue sources
* Medicare payments for ambulance services consist of a service-level payment and a mileage payment
* Providers may be affiliated with institutions or freestanding, for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based, and may rely on volunteers or paid staff
* Costs for providing ground ambulance transports were highly variable in 2010, ranging from $224 to $2,204, with a median cost of $429
	+ Personnel costs accounted for the largest percentage of total costs and contributed the most to increases in total costs between 2009 and 2010
	+ Providers with lower transport volumes, higher percentages of Medicare transports that are BLS, higher percentages of Medicare transports that are super-rural, and lower levels of community tax support had higher costs per transport
* Medicare payments per transport varied by predominant service area (urban, rural, or super-rural) and for all providers, with a median of $512, $552, and $585, respectively
	+ Median Medicare margin was about positive 2% in 2010 for the 153 providers in the sample, but decreased to negative 1% when add-on payments were removed
	+ Ambulance transports for all Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries increased by 33% from 2004 to 2010, with the largest increase in super-rural areas (41%) and the smallest increase in urban areas (32%)
	+ Increase in transports was primarily due to an increase in BLS nonemergency transports, which rose by 59% from 2004 to 2010, with the largest increase in super-rural areas (82%)
	+ Some local governments began billing Medicare and other insurers for ambulance transports, contributing to increased billing and potentially more revenue for providers.

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) is responsible for managing SRC I ammunition through various offices and military services, with the Army having a prominent role due to its procurement and storage of the majority of DOD's SRC I ammunition.
• DOD policy requires continuous program and policy oversight, tracking, and physical inventories of SRC I ammunition by serial number.
• The Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command tracks the movement and coordinates responses to transportation issues of SRC I ammunition while in transit.
• DODM 5100.76 sets forth DOD policy on the physical security of sensitive conventional arms, ammunition, and explosives, requiring a higher level of protection and security for SRC I ammunition.
• The military services have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, with the department in the final stages of evaluating a system to serve as the DOD-wide authoritative source of data for conventional ammunition, including SRC I ammunition.
</summary>

• DOD components are required to track and conduct physical inventories of SRC I ammunition by serial number (DODM 5100.76)
• The Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force collectively had approximately 226,000 SRC I missiles and rockets in the continental United States as of April 30, 2015 (military service data)
• USTRANSCOM is designated as the DOD's single manager for transportation and DOD Distribution Process Owner, including transportation of SRC I ammunition
• DOD policy requires SRC I ammunition to have a higher level of protection and security than other conventional ammunition
• The military services have several automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, with the department evaluating a system to serve as the DOD-wide authoritative source of data for conventional ammunition

• The Army procures a majority of DOD's SRC I ammunition and provides wholesale storage for other military services at Army depots
• The Army depots ship SRC I ammunition owned by other military services to their respective locations at their request

<summary>

• The Social Security Administration (SSA) is the largest producer and collector of personal information in the US
• SSA is responsible for issuing Social Security Numbers (SSNs) and maintaining wage and earnings records
• SSA's disclosure policy has evolved to comply with various statutes, including the Privacy Act of 1974
• The Privacy Act requires agencies to inform individuals about the collection and use of their personal information, and prohibits disclosure without consent except in certain circumstances
• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and allows sharing of information with law enforcement under specific conditions
• Key conditions for sharing information with law enforcement include:
   • Criminal activity involves fraud or other criminal activity in Social Security programs
   • Criminal activity is a violent or serious crime
   • Information is required by other federal statutes or to protect the security and safety of SSA clients, personnel, or facilities

</summary>

<summary>

• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) was passed in 1976 and amended in 1984 to establish a national policy for managing hazardous waste
• RCRA governs the identification, listing, and management of hazardous waste from generation to disposal
• EPA has established criteria for identifying hazardous waste, including specific types listed by source or characteristics
• Waste from both current and past industrial operations is regulated, as well as waste associated with cleanups
• Three requirements under RCRA that create disincentives for industry to clean up previously contaminated sites are land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and requirements for permits
• Land disposal restrictions and minimum technological requirements primarily add costs by setting stringent standards for treating and disposing of hazardous waste, while requirements for permits add time and costs
• EPA has proposed alternatives to mitigate the impact of these requirements, but stakeholders disagree on their applicability and legality
• Comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements for managing remediation waste is necessary, but achieving it through regulatory process is challenging due to disagreements on the extent of exemptions and EPA's legal authority
• EPA plans to withdraw its proposed rule and pursue legislative reform instead

Sub-points for Land disposal restrictions:
• Prohibits parties from disposing of hazardous waste on land unless it has been treated to minimize threats to human health and the environment
• Requires EPA to establish treatment standards for hazardous waste that has been restricted from land disposal

Sub-points for Minimum technological requirements:
• Establishes design and operating specifications for facilities that treat or dispose of hazardous waste
• Compliance can be costly and may be more stringent than necessary for some remediation waste

</summary>

<summary>

* Medicare program integrity activities were previously subsumed under Medicare's general administrative budget and performed by insurance companies, leading to funding constraints and reduced ability to conduct audits and review medical claims.
* HHS advocated for dedicated and stable funding for program integrity activities outside of the annual appropriations process to allow for multiyear planning and retention of experienced staff.
* Beginning in fiscal year 1997, HIPAA established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) and provided CMS with dedicated funding for program integrity activities.
* MIP funds are used to enter into contracts to promote the integrity of the Medicare program and conduct various program integrity activities.
* CMS allocates MIP funds primarily to support contractors' program integrity efforts for the traditional Medicare program, including fiscal intermediaries, carriers, Medicare administrative contractors (MACs), PSCs, COB contractor, National Supplier Clearinghouse (NSC), and data analysis and coding (DAC) contractor.
* Program integrity activities include audits, medical review, secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education.
* From fiscal years 1997 through 2005, CMS increased funding for each of its five program integrity activities, but the amount and percentage increase varied among the activities. Provider education received the largest percentage increase in funds, while audit and medical review received the largest amount of funds overall.
* CMS plans to further increase expenditures for program integrity in fiscal year 2006, with a total of $832 million available for MIP activities.
* CMS uses MIP funds to support the five program integrity activities, including certain information technology systems, fees for consultants, storage of CMS records, and postage and printing.

</summary>

* Medicare program integrity activities were previously performed by insurance companies under contract with CMS, leading to funding constraints and reduced ability to conduct audits and review medical claims (before 1996).
* HHS advocated for dedicated and stable funding for program integrity activities outside of the annual appropriations process (early and mid-1990s).
* HIPAA established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) and provided CMS with dedicated funding for program integrity activities starting in fiscal year 1997.

• TSA had failed to detect a significant percentage of dangerous objects during passenger and checked baggage screenings at airports in the past
• In 1978, screeners missed 13% of potentially dangerous objects; in 1987, they missed 20%
• In the late 1990s, as testing objects became more realistic, screener abilities declined further
• In 2004, TSA and DHS Office of Inspector General identified weaknesses in screener performance
• The 9/11 Commission also called for improvements in screener performance and understanding reasons for performance problems
• The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) was signed into law in 2001, creating TSA and giving it responsibility for securing all transportation modes, including aviation
• TSA now oversees security operations at over 450 commercial airports, including passenger and checked baggage screening
• TSA classifies airports into five security risk categories based on factors such as passenger boardings and security measures
• TSA has implemented various enhancements to screening operations since ATSA, including assuming responsibility for screeners and screening operations, establishing a basic screener training program, and conducting annual proficiency reviews
</summary>

* IRS' toll-free network consists of 10,000 customer service representatives at 25 call sites
* In 1999, IRS began operating the network as a single call center to optimize service by routing calls to sites with shortest hold times
* Before 1999, calls were routed based on area codes or percentage of staff, making it difficult to reroute when sites were experiencing high hold times
* IRS' call center network is controlled by the Operations Center, responsible for forecasting call demand, planning call routing, developing staffing requirements, and monitoring network call traffic
* IRS uses a human capital self-assessment checklist to evaluate human capital management practices
* IRS faces challenges in determining staffing levels for toll-free telephone customer service operations
* IRS does not have a long-term, desired level-of-service goal based on taxpayer needs and costs, instead relying on annual funding decisions
* Industry best practices involve setting service-level goals based on customer needs and consulting with stakeholders
* IRS has challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives
* IRS is working to improve human capital management practices, including developing a national recruiting strategy, improving training, and monitoring attrition.

* Recruiting:
  * Difficulties include seasonal nature, undesirable hours, and stressfulness of work
  * Sites use a combination of conventional recruiting methods and interview techniques
  * IRS is developing a national recruiting strategy to target sites where it is a competitive employer and sites that have trouble recruiting

* Training:
  * Broad range of topics, inadequate resources, cyclical nature of demand, and lack of formal mechanism to identify individual refresher training needs
  * IRS began refocusing its program to provide just-in-time training and intends to further specialize training for specific taxpayer groups

* Retention:
  * IRS does not monitor attrition or determine reasons for leaving or where representatives go after leaving
  * Some organizations have high attrition but benefit from promoting from within and encouraging employee mobility

* Scheduling:
  * Inaccurate demand forecasting and complicated scheduling process lead to overstaffing or understaffing at call sites
  * IRS is adapting an automated system to facilitate

<summary>

• Ginnie Mae was created in 1968 to expand affordable housing in America by linking capital markets to the housing markets
• Operates as a unit of HUD, with administrative decisions coordinated with HUD's
• Defines mission as expanding affordable housing by securitizing government-backed loans
• All mortgages in Ginnie Mae pools must be insured or guaranteed by a government agency and have eligible interest rates and maturities
• Ginnie Mae has several different products, including original MBS program (Ginnie Mae I), Ginnie Mae II MBS program, and Multiclass Securities Program
• Ginnie Mae I requires similar types of mortgages with similar maturities and the same interest rates
• Ginnie Mae II permits pools to contain loans with varying interest rates and allows for adjustable rate mortgages
• Ginnie Mae's Multiclass Securities Program includes Real Estate Mortgage Investment Conduits (REMICs) and Ginnie Mae Platinum Securities
• Investors in Ginnie Mae MBS face prepayment risk but not credit risk, as underlying mortgages are federally insured or guaranteed
• Ginnie Mae charges issuers a guarantee fee and a commitment fee for providing its guarantee of timely payment

</summary>

<summary>
• DOD identified $615 million of illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments in fiscal year 2000
• $592 million of these adjustments have been reversed, but additional accounting problems were discovered
• DOD plans to complete reaudits to correct the accounting for the 30 contracts by September 30, 2002
• $1.9 billion of closed account adjustments were made during fiscal year 2001, $172 million of which were illegal or otherwise improper
• DOD has implemented new controls to prevent illegal closed account adjustments and reduced adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002

• DOD's lack of controls and managerial attention led to illegal and otherwise improper adjustments in the past
• DOD has taken steps to address the problem, including upgrading the contract reconciliation system and changing payment allocation defaults
• The use of numerous ACRNs and changing contract payment allocation terms contributes to payment errors and adjustments
• The Congress could consider options such as prohibiting adjustments to closed accounts or allowing a limited period for corrections after closure
• DOD's ongoing efforts to correct past adjustments and improve financial management systems are key to effectively resolving financial management and contract payment problems
</summary>

<summary>
• The Internet, which relies on the domain name system to ensure the uniqueness of email and website addresses, has grown significantly in importance and usage.
• The domain name system is managed through a set of rules and functions, including the domain name system (DNS) and the domain name servers.
• The U.S. government, which supported the development of the Internet, began a process in the late 1990s to transition the technical responsibility for managing the domain name system to the private sector.
• ICANN, a not-for-profit organization, was established to manage the domain name system and entered into an MOU with the Department of Commerce to guide the transition.
• ICANN has made progress in increasing competition in the domain name market but has faced challenges in addressing other guiding principles of the transition, such as stability, security, representation, and private, bottom-up coordination.
• The U.S. government, as the responsible steward of the transition, is assessing the progress of the transition and considering adjustments to the MOU or a new arrangement with ICANN or another organization as the September 2002 termination date approaches.

• The domain name system translates domain names into IP addresses and back again, relying on a system of servers called domain name servers and a hierarchical organization of domain names.
• The rules for connecting networks on the Internet were developed under DOD sponsorship, with Dr. Jon Postel playing a key role in the development and coordination of the domain name system.
• The growth of commercial activity on the Internet led to the National Science Foundation's contract with Network Solutions, Inc., to manage public registration of domain names and run the authoritative root server.
• The U.S. government began efforts to privatize the management of the domain name system in response to controversy over the Network Solutions fee and the need for a more stable and secure system.
• The Green Paper and White Paper proposed a transition to a private, nonprofit corporation to manage the domain name system, leading to the formation of ICANN and the signing of an MOU between ICANN and the Department of Commerce.
</summary>

<summary>

* The federal government has held trust funds for Indian tribes since 1820.
* The General Allotment Act of 1887 provided for the division of tribal lands into individual allotments, and the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the period for federal trust management indefinitely.
* The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for managing trust funds and providing trust services to beneficiaries.
* The Office of the Special Trustee (OST) was established in 1994 to oversee trust reforms and manage trust fund operations.
* OST has relied extensively on contractors to perform trust reform activities, with about 21% of its appropriated funds spent on contracts in fiscal years 2004 and 2005.
* In 2006, senior OST officials were found to have given preferential treatment to a contractor, CD&L, in violation of ethical conduct standards.
* OST has made progress in implementing trust fund management reforms, but has not provided the Congress with a timetable for completion or a plan for future trust fund operations.
* The Special Trustee believes that OST's staff will need to continue to perform their functions after trust reforms are completed, and plans to reduce funding for contracting accordingly.
* OST has not developed a workforce plan to reexamine responsibilities and needs for trust fund operations once reforms are completed.

</summary>

* * Managed tribal lands and assets

* The General Allotment Act of 1887 and Indian Reorganization Act of 1934

* * Extended federal trust management indefinitely

* Responsibility for managing trust funds and providing trust services

* Established in 1994 to oversee trust reforms and manage trust fund operations

* Relying extensively on contractors for trust reform activities

<summary>
• VA and DOD initiated the Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR) project in 1998 to develop a comprehensive, life-long medical record for active duty military personnel and veterans, leading to the creation of the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program in 2002.
• FHIE enabled one-way transfer of patient health data from DOD to VA, but lacked a well-defined architecture, clear project management structure, and comprehensive project management plan, leading to management weaknesses and delays.
</summary>

• Lack of a well-defined architecture:
    • Missing system requirements, design specifications, and software descriptions
    • No established project management lead entity and structure
    • No comprehensive and coordinated project management plan

• Missing comprehensive project management plan:
    • Lack of authority and responsibility of organizational units
    • Lack of detail in work breakdown structure and schedules
    • Security policy still being drafted

• Delayed milestone:
    • Planned to exchange outpatient pharmacy data, laboratory results, allergy information, and patient demographic information by October 2005
    • Delay due to complex work required to implement standards for pharmacy and medication allergy data
    • New target date for exchange is now February 2006

• Limited health information in data repositories:
    • DOD's Clinical Data Repository includes incomplete data from CHCS II
    • VA's Health Data Repository contains limited data in interoperable format
    • Health information in other systems not yet captured in data repositories

• Long-term goals:
    • Achieve a virtual medical record through two-way exchange of computable data between VA's Health Data Repository and DOD's Clinical Data Repository
    • Institutionalize a highly disciplined approach to project management to ensure success of CHDR initiative.

<summary>

• The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) aims to determine correct taxable income and liability through income tax audits
• Nine audit standards define audit quality, addressing issues such as scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management
• Workpapers document the audit process and provide support for the auditor's report and findings
• IRS uses the Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) to assess audit quality and identify areas for improvement
• Key element pass rate is a measure of audit quality, indicating the percentage of audits demonstrating specific characteristics
• IRS historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers, with EQMS indicating that auditors met all key elements in no more than 72% of audits between 1992 and 1997
• Supervisory review during audits is a primary tool for ensuring quality, but documentation of this review is limited
• IRS is drafting changes to the IRM requiring documentation of managerial involvement in the audit process
• Lack of documentation of supervisory review raises questions about the extent of supervisory involvement and control over audit quality
• Recommendation: IRS Commissioner should require audit supervisors to document their review of audit workpapers to improve quality control

• IRS uses EQMS to measure audit quality against nine standards, including consideration of large items, income reporting, return filing, issue completion, tax law application, penalties, audit trail documentation, report presentation, and time utilization
• Key element pass rate is a sensitive measurement for describing audit flaws, establishing a baseline for improvement, and identifying systemic changes
• Workpapers are essential for providing principal support for the auditor's report and documenting procedures, tests, information obtained, and conclusions reached
• IRS found problems with workpaper quality in the past, with EQMS indicating that auditors met all key elements in no more than 72% of audits between 1992 and 1997
• Supervisory review during audits is crucial for ensuring quality, but documentation of this review is limited
• IRS is drafting changes to the IRM requiring documentation of managerial involvement in the audit process
• Lack of documentation of supervisory review raises questions about the extent of supervisory involvement and control over audit quality

<summary>

* The Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program was authorized by Congress in 1983 through the Foreign Assistance Act.
* The purpose of ATA is to enhance antiterrorism skills of friendly countries, strengthen bilateral ties, and increase respect for human rights.
* Most assistance consists of training courses and counterterrorism equipment grants.
* ATA curricula focus on critical counterterrorism capabilities, such as crisis management and response, cyberterrorism, and dignitary protection.
* DS/T/ATA conducts initial and subsequent assessments of partner nations' counterterrorism capabilities every 2-3 years.
* S/CT provides minimal policy guidance to DS/T/ATA for assistance priorities and ensuring alignment with broader U.S. policy goals.
* DS/T/ATA and S/CT did not systematically use country-specific needs assessments and program reviews to plan assistance in accordance with State policy guidance.
* State places countries on a tiered list based on threats and diplomatic engagement, but other factors also influence which countries receive assistance.
* State lacked clear measures and processes for assessing sustainability and had not integrated the concept into program planning.

</summary>

	+ Other factors: U.S. foreign policy objectives and unforeseen events.
* Planning: DS

<summary>

* Large financial companies may file for bankruptcy under Chapters 7 or 11 of the Bankruptcy Code
* Chapter 7 involves liquidation of assets, while Chapter 11 allows for reorganization
* Bankruptcy proceedings can be voluntary or involuntary, with creditors able to defend against involuntary requests
* Secured creditors receive similar treatment for their claims, while business debtors may seek liquidation or reorganization
* Chapter 11 proceedings involve several stages, including first-day motions, disclosure, plan of reorganization, and reorganization itself
* Safe harbor provisions allow certain financial and derivative contracts to be exercised despite the automatic stay
* Chapter 15 of the Bankruptcy Code facilitates coordination between U.S. and foreign jurisdictions in cross-border insolvency cases
* Recent efforts include regulatory actions by the Federal Reserve and FDIC, as well as international initiatives like the European Union's Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive

</summary>

* Bankruptcy proceedings for large financial companies:
  + Chapters 7 (liquidation) and 11 (reorganization)
  + Voluntary or involuntary filings
    ** Involuntary proceedings: creditors can defend against requests

* Stages of Chapter 11 proceedings:
  + First-day motions: requests for continued business operation, financing
  + Disclosure: debtor must provide sufficient information for creditor judgments
  + Plan of reorganization: debtor proposes how to reorganize and treat creditors
    ** Classes of claims receive similar treatment
  + Reorganization: possible outcomes include distribution under a plan, liquidation, or reorganization

* Safe harbor provisions:
  + Allow certain financial and derivative contracts to be exercised despite automatic stay
  + Types of contracts eligible for safe harbor treatment: derivatives, repurchase agreements

* Chapter 15 of the Bankruptcy Code:
  + Facilitates coordination between U.S. and foreign jurisdictions
  + Excludes same financial institutions as those generally not eligible to file as debtors

* Recent efforts to improve cross-border coordination:
  + Regulatory actions by Federal Reserve and FDIC

<summary>

* The electricity industry consists of four functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* Electricity is generated through various means, then transmitted through high-voltage lines to local distributors, and finally distributed to consumers.
* System operators manage and control the flow of electricity using IT- and network-based control systems.
* The electricity industry has been updating its infrastructure to integrate new technologies and improve reliability and efficiency.
* The smart grid vision aims to facilitate alternative energy sources, improve reliability, and give consumers real-time energy information.
* Challenges to the electricity industry include the need for cybersecurity, evolving threats, and the need for clear regulatory responsibilities.
** Cybersecurity threats include unintentional and intentional attacks, with potential impacts on industrial control systems, SCADA systems, and the grid as a whole.
** Regulatory responsibilities are not clearly defined, and there is a need for collaboration and coordination between federal and state regulators.

</summary>

<summary>
• Skills gaps in the federal workforce pose a high risk to the nation, impeding effective public service and mission achievement
• Reasons for skills gaps include insufficient numbers of employees or lack of appropriate skills and abilities
• Factors contributing to skills gaps include budget pressures, changing nature of federal work, and upcoming retirements
• Federal workforce is highly educated compared to private sector, with a greater proportion of jobs in skilled occupations
• To address skills gaps, improvements are needed in hiring, classification, pay, performance management, and employee engagement
</summary>

• Hiring:
  • Federal agencies need a flexible and applicant-friendly hiring process
  • OPM should analyze the effectiveness of hiring authorities and refine or eliminate ineffective ones
  • Agencies should ensure effective communication between hiring specialists and hiring managers

• Classification:
  • The GS classification system needs modernization to better address highly skilled and specialized federal work
  • OPM should work with stakeholders to examine ways to modernize the system
  • Cost-effective methods are needed to ensure accurate classification

• Pay:
  • Federal pay system does not align well with modern compensation principles
  • Agencies should have effective performance management systems to link pay to individual performance
  • A cultural shift may be needed to move from a longevity-based pay system to a performance-oriented one

• Performance management:
  • Effective performance management helps establish a clear line of sight between individual performance and organizational success
  • Agencies should make meaningful distinctions in employee performance levels
  • Supervisors play a key role in performance management and should be selected for their supervisory skills

• Employee engagement:
  • Additional analysis and sharing of promising practices could improve employee engagement and performance
  • Federal jobs require more advanced skills and education than private sector jobs
  • Balancing the size and composition of the federal workforce is a key challenge to deliver high-quality services within budgetary realities

<summary>

* The financial crisis prompted extraordinary government interventions to stabilize the financial system, with actions taken between September 2007 and December 2009.
* Initial responses included a HUD-initiated foreclosure prevention program, a Federal Reserve lending facility for depository institutions, and currency swap arrangements with foreign central banks.
* As the crisis intensified, additional lending facilities were created, followed by separate actions by the Federal Reserve, Treasury, and others dealing with financial sector issues on a case-by-case basis.
* Some programs included: Capital Purchase Program (CPP) to restore confidence in the banking system, Capital Assistance Program (CAP) to help ensure large banking institutions had sufficient capital, Consumer & Business Lending Initiative (CBLI) to support securitizations in consumer and business credit markets, Public Private Investment Program (PPIP) to facilitate the purchase of "legacy assets," and Making Home Affordable Program (MHA) to prevent avoidable foreclosures.
* Treasury extended TARP's authority to purchase, commit to purchase, or commit to guarantee troubled assets until October 3, 2010, allowing for more flexibility and time to decide how best to allocate remaining funds.
* Key factors motivating Treasury's program-specific decisions included ongoing weaknesses in housing markets, financial conditions for small businesses, and the need to retain resources to respond to threats to financial stability.
* Treasury identified clear objectives for its small business lending programs and set quantitative program objectives, such as supporting lending to creditworthy small businesses and repairing balance sheets by removing troubled assets.

</summary>

* The financial crisis led to extensive government interventions, categorized as: providing capital to financial institutions, enhancing access to liquid assets, purchasing nonperforming or illiquid assets, guaranteeing liabilities, intervening in specific markets, and mitigating home foreclosures.

* FDA is responsible for ensuring the safety of all foods except meat, poultry, and certain egg products.

* Both agencies use the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system to prevent contamination.
* FDA and FSIS inspect facilities to verify HACCP plan implementation.
* FDA and FSIS spent about $1.3 billion on food safety activities in 1999.
* Following 9/11, the federal government intensified efforts to address potential food contamination, providing emergency funding for FDA and FSIS.
* FDA and USDA have taken steps to enhance food security, including hiring new inspectors, conducting risk assessments, and developing guidelines.
* Industry and state governments have also taken actions to protect food products from deliberate contamination.

* The largest interagency contracting vehicles are the MAS program, GWACs, and MACs, managed by GSA
* Federal agencies spent $60 billion on these contracts in fiscal year 2008
* GWACs, MACs, and enterprisewide contracts allow agencies to leverage buying power and reduce administrative overhead
* However, lack of reliable data and inconsistent policy make it difficult to effectively manage and oversee these contracts
* Total number of MACs and enterprisewide contracts is unknown due to insufficient data in the official procurement database
* Agencies establish their own contracts for reasons such as cost avoidance, mission specific requirements, and better control
* Duplication of effort among contracts is a concern, with vendors offering similar products and services on multiple contract vehicles
* OFPP has made recommendations to improve data, strengthen policy, and better coordinate awards of MACs and enterprisewide contracts
* GSA's MAS program is the largest interagency buying program, providing advantages to both agencies and vendors
* Challenges in effectively managing the MAS program include lack of transactional data, limited use of pricing tools, and a decentralized management structure

</summary>

* The baby boom generation, born between 1946 and 1964, is starting to retire, leading to an increase in the aged dependency ratio.
* The aged dependency ratio, which was 21% in 2000, will reach 35% by 2030, meaning fewer than three workers for every retiree.
* Social Security benefits are the primary source of income for over 50% of those age 65 and older.
* Recent changes to Social Security policy include eliminating the practice of reducing benefits for those with earnings after the normal retirement age and increasing the delayed retirement credit.
* The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) promotes the employment of older persons based on ability and prohibits age discrimination.
* The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) enforces ADEA and other federal statutes prohibiting employment discrimination.
* Pension laws encourage employers to establish and maintain pension plans, which can influence the work decisions of older individuals.
* Older workers are increasingly participating in the labor force, especially women age 55-64, and their labor force participation rates are projected to continue growing.
* Older workers are a growing proportion of all workers, and their representation in white-collar occupations is increasing.
* Employers are using various arrangements, such as rehiring retirees and flexible work schedules, to retain older workers.

<summary>
• State child welfare systems consist of complex policies and programs to protect children, with growing caseloads straining their ability to keep up
• From 1984 to 1995, foster care population grew from 276,000 to 494,000, with 261,000 children supported by federal funds
• Federal government plays a role in financing foster care and sets minimum procedural requirements for placement process
• States must make reasonable efforts to prevent child removal and provide services to reunite families
• Permanency planning process requires developing a case plan, reviewing it every 6 months, and holding a permanency hearing within 18 months
• Some states have enacted laws to shorten time between entering foster care and first permanency hearing, from 12 to 6 months
• Initiatives to expedite permanency process include low-cost programs addressing specific barriers to reunification, expediting termination of parental rights, and concurrent planning
</summary>
• Federal role: financing and minimum procedural requirements
  • Financing: federal funds support foster care for over 50% of children
  • Procedural requirements: states must make reasonable efforts to prevent child removal and provide services to families
• Permanency planning process
  • Case plan development and review
    • Every 6 months
  • Permanency hearing
    • Within 18 months of entering foster care
• State initiatives to expedite process
  • Shorten time between entering foster care and first permanency hearing
    • 12 states have enacted laws or policies to shorten time frame
      • Ohio and Minnesota require permanency decision after limited extension period
  • Low-cost programs addressing specific barriers to reunification
    • Arizona's Housing Assistance Program reunited 939 children with families, saving over $1 million in foster care costs
  • Expediting termination of parental rights
    • Arizona's Severance Project and Adoption Project increased number of new adoptive homes and reduced average length of stay in foster care
  • Concurrent planning
    • Colorado began using concurrent planning formally in 1994 for children under age 6, achieving 87% permanent placement within 1 year
• All decisions regarding foster child placement come through state courts

* The DATA Act expanded federal transparency legislation by requiring disclosure of federal agency expenditures and linking spending information to federal program activities
* OMB and Treasury are responsible for leading government-wide implementation
* Key components of ensuring accurate and consistent federal spending data include:
	+ OMB releasing policy guidance
	+ Treasury developing technical guidance for agency submissions and publication of data
	+ Agencies implementing data definition standards
	+ OMB and Treasury assessing readiness to meet reporting requirements

* OMB issued guidance in May 2015 and May 2016 to help agencies meet reporting requirements
* Treasury released the DATA Act Information Model Schema (DAIMS) and established a reporting framework
* Challenges identified in implementing the DATA Act include:
	+ Intragovernmental transactions
	+ Missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information
	+ Difficulties linking financial and award data
	+ Data quality issues in agency financial systems and reporting
	+ Lack of clear guidance on data definitions and reporting requirements
	+ Limited resources and human capital for implementation
	+ Inadequate internal controls and data management practices
	+ Lack of communication and coordination between agencies and OMB/Treasury
* IG reports identified material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in financial reporting and internal controls at many agencies, which may affect their ability to produce quality data for submission to Treasury as part of the DATA Act reporting requirements.

• Interagency contracting between OSC and ARC involved a sole-source order to MPRI for an organizational assessment, which did not follow proper procedures:
   • Competition was not sought among Schedule vendors
   • No convincing demonstration of why a sole-source order was necessary
   • OSC officials performed duties normally done by contracting officer's representatives without authorization or training
   • ARC contracting officials relied on OSC's justification and did not question its validity
   • OSC officials assumed the justification was adequate because ARC did not raise concerns

• OSC employees have limited options for addressing prohibited personnel practice allegations against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel:
   • Current policy and procedures do not provide for special handling of complaints against senior OSC officers
   • An external investigation by an independent entity or expanded MSPB appeal rights would be desirable but require specific authority
   • OSC employees ultimately report to the Special Counsel, making an internal investigation unworkable and potentially conflicted.

<summary>
• VA's mission is to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of veterans by ensuring they receive medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials
• Three major components: Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and National Cemetery Administration (NCA)
• VA operates approximately 240 information systems, manages 314,000 desktop computers and 30,000 laptops, and administers nearly 460,000 network user accounts
• IT infrastructure provides data storage, transmission, and communications necessary for reliable, available, and responsive support to VA staff and customers

• Legacy systems: Personnel and Accounting Integrated Data (PAID) and Benefits Delivery Network (BDN) are over 50 years old and need modernization or replacement
• VA plans to retire PAID and BDN in 2017 and 2018, respectively
• VA's strategic plan emphasizes increasing veterans' access to benefits and services, eliminating the disability claims backlog, and ending veteran homelessness
• IT improvements include enhancing health care systems, standardizing immunization data, expanding telehealth services, modernizing benefits delivery systems, and focusing on integrated service delivery
</summary>

• VA faces IT challenges, including obsolete systems, system interoperability with DOD, and failed modernization efforts
• Challenges include the failed modernization of the outpatient appointment scheduling system, the suspended development of a system for tracking surgical implants, and the lack of interoperability between VA and DOD electronic health records
• VA has initiated efforts to transform its Office of Information and Technology (OI&T) to focus on stabilizing and streamlining processes, mitigating weaknesses, and improving outcomes
• Transformation includes establishing a new project management process, creating new functions within OI&T, and improving IT security and detection of cyber vulnerabilities.

<summary>

* The Medicare program, administered by HCFA, serves over 33 million beneficiaries and processes over 900 million claims annually.
* HCFA is responsible for managing both fee-for-service Medicare and overseeing 400 managed care plans.
* Medicare benefits are divided into Part A (hospital insurance) and Part B (supplementary medical insurance).
* HCFA has around 4,000 employees and oversees 60 claims processing contractors employing an additional 22,000 people.
* The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and the Balanced Budget Act (BBA) have granted HCFA new tools to combat fraud and abuse.
* HIPAA adds new civil and criminal penalties and introduces new health plan options and payment reforms.
* BBA mandates prospective payment systems for various health care providers and makes changes to payment methods in traditional fee-for-service Medicare and managed care.
* HCFA is facing challenges in implementing legislative reforms, modernizing information systems, and dealing with the loss of experienced staff.
* HCFA has restructured its organization to better focus on its mission and establish three components focused on beneficiaries, health plans and providers, and Medicaid and other activities.
* HCFA is currently facing difficulties in establishing new communication and coordination links within units and across the agency due to the recent reorganization.

</summary>

<summary>

* FAA primarily funded by Trust Fund (82%) and General Fund (18%)
* Trust Fund receives revenues from excise taxes on airline tickets, aviation fuel, cargo, and international travel
* Proposed reauthorization would change funding system to user charges and General Fund contributions
* High-performance and piston aircraft groups identified in cost allocation study
* Concerns about current funding structure: revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency
* Proposed changes to address concerns: direct user charges, fuel taxes, and advisory board
* Uncertainties about cost allocation methodology and borrowing authority

* Trust Fund:
	+ Receives revenues from excise taxes
	+ Provides funding for AIP, F&E, RE&D, and Operations accounts
	+ Projected to increase substantially at current tax rates
	+ Current structure may not fully address concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency

* Proposed changes:
	+ Eliminate all excise taxes except fuel and international passenger tax
	+ Direct user charges for commercial aircraft and fuel taxes for general aviation
	+ Fee for congested airports based on time of day or day of the week
	+ Establish advisory board to recommend user fee amounts
	+ Use General Fund revenues to fund part of AIP
	+ Set fuel tax rates considering effects on use and revenue
	+ Allocate fixed costs to primary user of service and divide high-performance aircraft into subgroups
</summary>

* GSA's Federal Technology Service, in collaboration with the IMC, is responsible for providing federal agencies with telecommunications services and solutions to meet mission requirements through the FTS2001 program.
* The FTS2001 program aims to ensure the best service and price for the government and maximize competition for services. It has two contracts with Sprint and MCI WorldCom, each with minimum revenues of $750 million and expiring in December 2006 and January 2007, respectively.
* GSA is planning the FTS Networx acquisition program to replace existing contracts, with goals of meeting agency needs, obtaining best value, encouraging competition, responding to the changing marketplace, and providing opportunities for small businesses.
* The Networx Universal contracts will provide a full range of national and international network services, managed networking services, and network access, wireless, and satellite communications services, with multiple awards to a few offerors due to extensive geographic and service requirements.
* The Networx Select contracts will provide agencies with leading edge services and solutions with less extensive geographic and service coverage, with details of pricing structures and service delivery mechanisms to be provided in the summer of 2005.
* Challenges for the Networx acquisition program include ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring and scheduling contracts, and initiating implementation planning actions for a smooth transition from current contracts to Networx.
* Clear understanding of agency requirements and measures of success are essential for informed acquisition planning decisions and effective program management.
* Industry representatives have varying views on the proposed acquisition approach, with some supporting the broad scope of Universal contracts and others criticizing the approach for limiting competition and the timing of Select contract awards.
* GSA recognizes the importance of strong program management and transition planning to ensure a successful transition to the new contracts and avoid repeating the difficulties experienced with FTS2001.

<summary>

• The Federal Student Aid (FSA) office manages and administers student financial assistance programs under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, providing over $50 billion in aid to 8 million students and families.
• FSA is a President's Management Agenda Performance Based Organization (PBO), established in 1998 to improve service, reduce costs, increase accountability, provide flexibility, integrate information systems, and ensure program integrity.
• The PBO legislation requires FSA to develop performance plans, report annually to Congress, have performance agreements for the COO and senior managers, and use performance bonuses.
• FSA's performance plan includes strategic goals for increasing customer and employee satisfaction and reducing unit costs, with measures for gauging progress.
• Customer and employee satisfaction is measured using the American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) and Gallup Q12, respectively, with scores increasing from fiscal year 1999 to fiscal year 2001.
• Unit cost is measured by dividing budget obligations by the number of people who received aid, but this calculation has limitations and was changed from actual costs in the past.
• FSA faces challenges in reporting systems integration and program integrity progress to Congress, as its performance plans and reports do not always provide clear information on these topics.

</summary>

* NIH made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds between fiscal years 2009 and 2010.
* Grants were awarded through standard review processes and criteria, and were used for scientific research in various categories.
* NIH and grantees collect information about FTEs, other impacts, and report to the federal government through the www.federalreporting.gov website.
** FTEs supported by NIH Recovery Act funding increased from about 12,000 in December 2009 to about 21,000 in June 2011, with an estimated potential total of approximately 54,000 FTEs.
** Grantees reported using Recovery Act funding for purchasing supplies and equipment, specialized services, and scientific training for health care professionals.
** NIH is participating in the Star Metrics program to track the scientific and other impacts of its funded research grants, including employment, economic growth, and social outcomes.
** Principal investigators reported using Recovery Act funding to purchase laboratory equipment and supplies, contract for specialized testing services, and provide scientific training to health care professionals.
** Some principal investigators reported that their Recovery Act-funded research could lead to future scientific developments in preventive medicine, early disease detection, and medical therapies.
** NIH tracks scientific impact primarily through peer-reviewed publications and Investment Reports, and uses other metrics such as patent applications, future grant funding, presentations, product utilization, and health care policy changes.

<summary>

* Transit-oriented development (TOD) is a compact, mixed-use, and walkable neighborhood located near transit, typically within half a mile of a transit station.
* Stakeholders involved in TOD planning and implementation include local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, metropolitan-planning organizations, private developers, lenders, business improvement districts, and FTA.
* Local transit agencies are responsible for building, maintaining, and operating transit systems, while FTA provides funds for transit projects that may spur TOD.
* Factors that support TOD include market demand for real estate, available land for development, supportive local residents, and efficient access to jobs and centers of activity.
* Market demand for real estate is driven by a strong local economy and demand for housing and commercial space.
* Large parcels of land, such as surface parking lots or underutilized industrial land, can be converted into TOD.
* Resident support for transit and TOD is crucial, as is efficient access to jobs and activity centers.
* Challenges to TOD include higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance TOD projects, lengthy approval processes, unsupportive local populations, and undesirable physical features surrounding transit stations.
* FTA considers factors related to TOD when assessing proposed projects, including economic development effects and land use.
* FTA evaluates local government policies, such as zoning regulations, station area planning, targeted infrastructure investments, and tax incentives, to determine their effectiveness in supporting TOD.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Social Security Administration (SSA) introduced the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) in 1988 to enable workers to review their earnings records and obtain benefit estimates.
* Fewer than 2% of workers request these statements each year, but SSA plans to send them automatically to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000.
* The goals of the PEBES initiative are to inform the public about benefits, assist in financial planning, and ensure accurate earnings records.
* The PEBES includes benefit estimates based on assumptions about future employment and earnings.
* SSA's approach for estimating retirement benefits is reasonable but may not consider special circumstances that could affect individual benefits.
* The PEBES has been generally well-received by the public, with most respondents indicating it was helpful for financial planning.
* The current PEBES is too complex and contains too much information, making it difficult for readers to understand.
* The design expert suggested improvements such as an obvious purpose, attractive design, easy-to-understand explanations, and effective use of features like bulleting and highlighting.
* SSA has conducted surveys and focus groups to gather feedback and revise the statement, but some participants and experts still prefer a two-part document.
* SSA is considering a more extensive redesign of the PEBES for fiscal year 1999, focusing on reduced printing costs rather than addressing the statement's weaknesses.

</summary>

<summary>
• SSA administers two programs: Disability Insurance (DI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI), both providing benefits for individuals unable to work due to disability
• Both programs use the same definition of disability for initial entitlement: a medically determinable physical or mental impairment preventing substantial gainful activity for at least one year or resulting in death
• DI, established in 1956, is an insurance program replacing lost earnings due to disability, requiring work credits and financed by payroll taxes
• SSI, established in 1972, provides a minimum income for individuals with limited income and assets, eligibility not requiring work history, and benefits paid from general revenues
• Concurrent beneficiaries, about 14%, received both DI and SSI benefits in 2002, averaging 45 years old, mostly female, and had mental impairments
• Work incentive provisions exist in both programs, but differ significantly, with DI earnings not affecting cash benefits during a trial work period, while SSI earnings reduce cash benefits gradually
• SSA faces challenges in serving concurrent beneficiaries effectively due to complex program rules, lack of integrated guidance, and potential overpayments, requiring improvements in procedures, guidance, and public information materials.
</summary>

  • Concurrent beneficiaries: individuals receiving both DI and SSI benefits

<summary>

* Hurricane Katrina caused significant damage and human casualties in the Gulf Coast region in 2005, leading to $88 billion in relief and recovery funding through four emergency supplemental appropriations acts
* FEMA, a DHS component, received $42.6 billion for the Disaster Relief Fund and issued mission assignments to other federal agencies for disaster relief work
* Mission assignments include a description of work, estimated cost, completion date, and authorizing signatures, providing recipient agencies reimbursable budgetary authority
* Performing agencies bill FEMA for work performed under mission assignments, which are reimbursed using the Intra-Governmental Payment and Collection (IPAC) system
* FEMA reports obligations and expenditures for mission assignments, but these reports do not reflect the actual status from a governmentwide perspective due to timing differences and incomplete data from other agencies
* The federal government lacks a central collection point or framework to consolidate and report on hurricane-related funding information from the 23 federal agencies involved
* Lack of consolidated reporting makes it difficult for decision makers to determine how much has been spent, what for, and whether additional or rescinded funds are needed
* FEMA and OMB recommend improvements to reporting requirements and data collection processes to ensure better accountability, transparency, and timely information on hurricane relief and recovery funding
* The text was based on analysis of emergency supplemental appropriation documents, FEMA reports, and interviews with officials from various federal agencies

</summary>

<summary>
• FAA has authority to authorize UAS operations in the national airspace for military, public, and civil entities
• Current access to the airspace is granted through COAs, experimental certificates, and section 333 exemptions

• COAs are issued to public entities for specific UAS activities and are valid for up to 2 years
• Between January 2014 and March 2015, FAA approved 674 public COAs

• Experimental certificates are issued to civil entities for research, training, or demonstrations
• Section 333 exemptions allow commercial entities to operate UASs in the national airspace before rulemakings are completed
• FAA has granted 48 of 684 total applications for section 333 exemptions

• FAA's UAS Comprehensive Plan and Integration Roadmap provide a framework for UAS integration into the national airspace
• The accommodation phase focuses on safely facilitating limited UAS access to the national airspace with appropriate restrictions
• The integration phase aims to establish performance requirements for UAS to increase access to the national airspace
• The evolution phase focuses on updating policies, regulations, procedures, and technologies to support UAS operations in the evolving NAS environment

• FAA issued a Notice for Proposed Rulemaking for small UAS operations in February 2015, limiting their operations to daylight-only, confined areas, and visual-line-of-sight
• Six UAS test sites were selected in December 2013 and have become operational, receiving 48 COAs and one experimental certificate for over 195 UAS flights
</summary>

* Personnel at all levels expressed a need for more personnel to perform CERP program management and oversight functions
