  * The tick is more common in tropical and subtropical areas, including Southeast Asia and the Indian peninsula.
  * The first and second reported cases of human infestation in Korea occurred in southern coastal areas.
  * The present case is the third reported case in Korea and the first in a western coastal area.

  * Ticks lacerate the epidermal layers using their chelicerae and insert midline mouthparts into the opening at a depth that varies by species.
  * In the present case, the tick deeply penetrated the dermis, but the width of epidermal laceration was not similar to that of the mouthparts.

<summary>

- Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a heart condition characterized by left and/or right ventricular hypertrophy, predominantly involving the interventricular septum, in the absence of other causes.
- Familial HCM is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomere proteins.
- At least 15 genes are implicated in 5570% of HCM, with major genes including cardiac myosin heavy chain (MYH7), troponin T (TNNT2), cardiac myosin-binding protein C (MYBPC3), cardiac troponin I (TNNI3), cardiac myosin regulatory light chains (MYL2), and cardiac myosin essential light chains (MYL3).
- Cardiac troponin T is a thin-filament protein that regulates muscle contraction.
- Mutations in the TNNT2 gene, which encodes cardiac troponin T, are associated with approximately 15% of familial HCM cases.
- Most TNNT2 mutations are missense mutations located in exons 8-16 and are linked to a severe form of HCM with a poor overall prognosis and a high incidence of sudden death.
- Late gadolinium enhancement with cardiac magnetic resonance imaging is a predictive marker of ventricular arrhythmia and poor prognosis in HCM.
- Genetic analysis and determination of genotype-phenotype correlation are clinically informative for risk stratification in HCM.
- The TNNT2 mutation has the third-ranked incidence of familial HCM, and the genotype-phenotype correlation of this gene still remains insufficient in Japanese familial HCM.
- The present study genetically evaluated 173 patients with clinically diagnosed familial HCM and identified three reported mutations and a new mutation of TNNT2 in 11 individuals from four families.

</summary>

- Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a heart condition characterized by:
  * Left and/or right ventricular hypertrophy
  * Predominant involvement of the interventricular septum

<summary>
• Schistosomatidae is a family of digenetic endoparasites with complex life cycles that alternate between intermediate (freshwater gastropods) and definitive hosts (birds, reptiles, fishes, and mammals).
• Schistosoma species, the avian and mammalian blood flukes, are the best studied genus of schistosomatidae.
• Six species infect humans, causing schistosomiasis: S. haematobium, S. intercalatum, S. japonicum, S. malayensis, S. mansoni, and S. mekongi.
• Other species infect a broad range of mammals, including hippopotamus, rodents, carnivores, and ruminant animals.
• Schistosomiasis is a chronic and debilitating disease and one of the most serious public health issues, affecting 237 million people worldwide.
• Control of schistosomiasis is based on drug treatment (praziquantel), snail control, improved sanitation, and health education.

• Genomic and transcriptomic studies have expanded our understanding of schistosome biology and allowed for comparative analyses across different species.
  • Nuclear and mitochondrial genomes of some schistosoma species have been sequenced, revealing conserved features and unique gene order rearrangements.
  • Transcriptomic analyses have identified differentially expressed genes and candidate vaccine targets, including leishmanolysins and tetraspanins.
  • RNA interference (RNAi) techniques have been used to knockdown genes and study their functions, leading to the discovery of antioxidant enzymes as drug targets.
  • New tools, such as lentiviruses and transposons, are being developed for gene function studies and gene delivery.
</summary>

• Study conducted to determine predictive factors for postoperative morbidity and anastomotic leakage after simultaneous resection of colorectal liver metastases (sclm)
• Analyzed medical records of 86 patients who underwent simultaneous resection of primary colorectal and hepatic tumors from 1992 to 2004
• Compared morbidity rates with 167 patients who underwent hepatectomy for metachronous liver metastasis and 1,728 patients who underwent only resection for colorectal cancer
• Identified factors associated with increased risk of postoperative complications and anastomotic leakage
• Operation time greater than 8 hours was an independent predictive factor for anastomotic leakage
• Considered the benefits and drawbacks of simultaneous versus staged resections for sclm

• 86 patients underwent simultaneous resection of primary and hepatic tumors for sclm from 1992 to 2004
• 55% had bilobar tumor distribution, 45% had unilobar distribution, and mean diameter of hepatic tumor was about 43 mm
• 61% survival rate at 3 years and 45% at 5 years, with mean survival time of 47 months
• 64% developed complications, including 21% anastomotic leakage, 7% hepatic abscess, and 29% wound infection
• Operation time, intraoperative blood loss, and diverting stoma were significant predictors of postoperative complications
• Anastomotic leakage was significantly correlated with lateral lymph node dissection, primary site of rectum, and duration of operation greater than 8 hours

• Simultaneous resection simplifies and shortens treatment schedule, but perioperative risk may be higher
• Staged resections offer chance to evaluate liver or extrahepatic metastases, assess metastatic status of regional lymph nodes, and increase resectability
• Liver-first approach proposed as new strategy for sclm to avoid needless radical colorectal surgery and increase resectability

<summary>
• The study aimed to validate two scores for measuring patients' ability to use metered dose inhalers (MDIs) and dry powder inhalers (DPIs), identify common errors, and determine which patients require an educational program.
• The study was conducted in three phases: validation of reliability and content validity, assessment of criterion and discriminant validity, and implementation of the validated scores in clinical practice.
• Key findings include a high level of interobserver agreement, common errors such as insufficient breath-holding and incorrect inhalation speed, and the need for ongoing education and training for patients to improve inhaler technique and optimize treatment outcomes.
</summary>

• Validation of reliability and content validity:
  • Two guest pharmacists evaluated inhaler technique using preliminary scores for MDI and DPI.
  • The instruments provide step-by-step descriptions of inhaler technique and score correct and incorrect steps.
  • The pharmacists were trained on the correct use of the scoring systems.
  • The drugs used in the evaluation included beclomethasone dipropionate/albuterol for MDIs and budesonide/formoterol + budesonide for DPIs.

• Assessment of criterion and discriminant validity:
  • A new sample of patients using MDIs, DPIs, or both was recruited and evaluated by two blinded pharmacists using the validated scoring systems.
  • The median and interquartile range of scores were used to establish cut-off values and divide patients into two groups: able and unable to use inhalers.
  • The results showed that incorrect inhaler use affects drug efficacy and that assessment of inhaler technique is crucial for optimizing treatment outcomes.

• Implementation of validated scores in clinical practice:
  • The new scoring systems were more practical and allowed for objective and mathematical assessment of errors and determination of whether patients were able to achieve an ideal level of technical correctness.
  • The study identified common errors, such as insufficient breath-holding and incorrect inhalation speed, and highlighted the importance of ongoing education and training for patients to improve inhaler technique and optimize treatment outcomes.

• Bacteriocins are ribosomally synthesized antimicrobial peptides produced by bacteria with potential uses in food preservation and human/veterinary applications.
• Enterocin s37 is a bacteriocin produced by a strain of E. faecalis isolated from chicken feces.
• Enterocin s37 exhibits antagonism against Listeria and Campylobacter species and has broad-spectrum antibacterial activity.
• The purification and characterization of enterocin s37 were carried out using various techniques, including ammonium sulfate precipitation, reversed-phase HPLC, and SDS-PAGE.
• Enterocin s37 is a small, heat-stable, nonlanthionine-containing peptide with a molecular weight of 4-6 kDa.
• The antibacterial activity of enterocin s37 was stable at different pH levels and high temperatures.
• K channel modulators such as pinacidil, cromakalim, and glipizide affected the growth of L. monocytogenes and its bacteriocin-resistant variant differently when combined with enterocin s37.
• The mode of action of enterocin s37 may involve interaction with the cell membrane.

</summary>

* The text describes a phase 1 clinical study of Nusinersen in children with spinal muscular atrophy, which involved three lumbar punctures for drug administration and safety assessments.
* The study was conducted in compliance with ethical guidelines and regulatory requirements, with informed consent obtained from participants.
	+ Enrollment included medically stable children aged 2-14 years, with lumbar punctures performed at the L3-L4 or L4-L5 space using 22-25 gauge needles.
	+ Lumbar punctures were guided by fluoroscopy or ultrasonography, and participants were monitored for adverse events, including headache, back pain, and post-lumbar puncture syndrome.
	+ The study reported that 32% of lumbar punctures had adverse events, with the most common being headache, back pain, and post-lumbar puncture syndrome.
	+ A subgroup analysis showed that headache, back pain, and post-lumbar puncture syndrome were more frequent with 21-22 gauge needles, in older children, and in children with spinal muscular atrophy type 3.
	+ The use of a smaller 24-gauge needle or an atraumatic needle was suggested to reduce damage to the dura and decrease the risk for cerebrospinal fluid leak.
	+ The text also discusses the importance of patient positioning, spinal ultrasound, and anesthesia/sedation in facilitating lumbar puncture success in children.
	+ The study reported successful lumbar punctures in children with scoliosis and spinal rods, but scoliosis may hinder lumbar puncture success in some cases.
	+ The text concludes that intrathecal delivery of medication is feasible, safe, and well tolerated, and that further research is needed to optimize lumbar puncture procedures in children with spinal muscular atrophy.

* Ethical issues, such as plagiarism and data fabrication, were observed by the authors.

** Continuous training about CG concept and principles can make a positive attitude towards the program.

* Hydatid cyst disease is caused by the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus parasite.
* Canines and humans are the final and intermediate hosts, respectively.
* Humans are infected through contaminated water, vegetables, or direct contact with infected dogs.
* The disease is common in most parts of the world, especially in countries with animal husbandry.
* Prevalence rates vary from 1.1% to 13.7% in humans and 11.5% to 34.6% in intermediate hosts.
* This study aimed to determine the epidemiological and clinical status of human hydatidosis in Khorasan Razavi province during 2011-2014.
* The study population consisted of all diagnosed cases in governmental and private laboratories, hospitals, and health centers.
* Data was collected using a checklist including demographic information, infected organ, diagnosis method, clinical symptoms, and risk factors.
* Demographic characteristics: 54.9% were women, 45.8% were housewives, and the mean age of women was higher than men.

Sub-points:
- 51.8% of cases were from Mashhad, Ghouchan, Neishabour, and Fariman.
- 45.9% had domestic dogs and 64.4% washed vegetables with water alone.
- 70.5% had a single cyst and 24.5% had multiple cysts.
- 42.3% were diagnosed by radiology and 37.8% by CT scan.
- The most common clinical symptom was abdominal pain (42.3%).
- Liver involvement was reported in 59.4% of patients and 8.4% had multiple organ involvement.
- Previous studies reported an annual incidence of 0.54-1.33 per 100,000 population and a range of 1.1-13.8% infection rate.
- The highest proportion of infection was in the age group of 21-40 years old and in women.
- Housewives had the highest proportion of infection due to contact with contaminated vegetables.

* Ciliated hepatic foregut cyst (CHFC) was first described by Friedrich in 1857 as a congenital malformation
* CHFC is a rare lesion, with approximately 103 cases reported since its first description
* The lesion is thought to be the result of evagination of the foregut during embryonogenesis
* CHFC is characterized by the presence of four layers: a pseudostratified columnar epithelium layer with interspersed mucus cells, a sub-epithelial connective tissue layer, a smooth muscle layer, and an outer fibrous capsule
* A 32-year-old woman presented with a 6-month history of right upper quadrant pain and underwent successful laparoscopic excision of a CHFC
* Laparoscopic excision of CHFC is recommended for larger, symptomatic, or enlarging lesions, and for those with wall abnormalities or unexplained liver function tests
* Sub-points:
	+ The small size and anterior subcapsular location make CHFC amenable to laparoscopic excision with minimal dissection and morbidity
	+ The thick cyst wall and benign nature of the process facilitate easy handling and enucleation from the liver bed

• Text discusses the development of orally dissolving strips as an alternative to fast dissolving tablets for the administration of drugs, particularly in cases where swallowing is difficult
• Orally dissolving strips dissolve in the oral cavity within 60 seconds without water and are useful for patients with swallowing difficulties, pediatrics, geriatrics, and those experiencing sudden episodes of allergic attacks or coughing
• The backbone of an orally dissolving strip is typically formed of a plasticizer and film forming polymer or a mixture of polymers
• Polymers used in the formulation of orally dissolving strips include hydrocolloids, hydroxypropyl ethylcellulose, pectin, sodium alginate, or blends of polymers
• Clobazam, a broad-spectrum antiepileptic drug, was selected as a candidate for an orally dissolving strip formulation due to its indication in children and low-dose requirement

• The optimized formulation of clobazam using ssg and pva showed improved bioavailability and palatability, as well as faster dissolution rate, higher flexibility, and better patient compliance
• The study also investigated the effect of formulation composition on the thickness, folding endurance, tensile strength, and in vitro drug release of the orally dissolving strips

* The text discusses the importance of evaluating outcome measures used in stroke self-management interventions (SMIs) to ensure their validity and reliability for stroke populations, using the Consensus-based Standards for the Selection of Health Status Measurement Instruments (COSMIN) checklist.
* The review identified 43 abstracts as potentially relevant, of which 19 were retrieved and reviewed. Of the 43 different outcome measures used in the studies, 21 measures demonstrated some properties in stroke populations according to the COSMIN checklist.
* The text highlights several limitations and recommendations for future research, including the need for more studies to involve user involvement in measure development, the importance of specifying overlooked aspects of development in reporting, and the need for further work to conceptualise stroke self-management and develop appropriate measures.

* Lack of consensus on appropriate measures for stroke SMIs: The text suggests that the current absence of consensus regarding the appropriate measures to assist evaluation of stroke SMIs may be due to a lack of consensus about the concept and operation of self-management in stroke, as well as a lack of specific measures developed for stroke self-management.
* Importance of user involvement in measure development: The text emphasizes the importance of involving potential users in measurement development to enhance content validity and clinical utility, and argues that measures developed without user involvement have questionable meaning and other types of validity.
* Need for further work on stroke self-management conceptualisation: The text calls for further work to conceptualise stroke self-management and examine the theoretical premises supporting such interventions and expected outcomes, so that appropriate outcome measures which accurately reflect the concept can be selected and/or developed.
* Use of unreported measures: The text notes that several studies included unreported measures, which confounds the ability to draw reliable inferences from those studies and may be indicative of a lack of relevance and meaningfulness of those measures to stroke populations.
* Lack of consensus on expected outcomes of stroke SMIs: The text suggests that the heterogeneity of the outcome measures utilised by SMIs in the review may indicate a difficulty in determining the expected outcomes of stroke SMIs.

<summary>

* The text discusses a study investigating the correlation between the Koos questionnaire and the 6-minute walk test (6-mwt) in primary osteoarthritis (OA) knee patients.
* The study was a cross-sectional survey with 251 patients meeting clinical criteria for idiopathic knee OA.
* The Koos questionnaire consists of 42 questions addressing five patient-related domains: pain, other disease-specific symptoms, activity of daily living (ADL), sport and recreation function, and knee-related quality of life.
* The 6-mwt measures walking ability and endurance by asking patients to walk back and forth along a 30-m track as far as possible in 6 minutes.
* The results showed a weak correlation between the Koos questionnaire and the 6-mwt for the ADL domain (rho 0.461) and strong correlations for the pain, symptom, sports, and quality of life domains (rho 0.578, 0.619, 0.536, and 0.733, respectively).
* Body mass index (BMI) had strong correlations with all Koos subscales, while height and weight had weak correlations. Age had no correlation with any Koos subscales except for a weak correlation with the quality of life subscale (rho 0.159, p < 0.05).
</summary>

* The text also mentions previous studies comparing self-reported questionnaires (such as the WOMAC and SF-36) with performance-based tests (such as the timed up and go test and 6-mwt) in OA knee patients.
* The studies reported varying correlations between self-reported and objective measures, with some preferring self-reported questionnaires for ease of administration and others considering performance-based tests essential for ADL evaluation. Ideally, both methods should be used in knee rehabilitation settings.

• Obesity is a chronic inflammatory disease caused by a combination of genetic predisposition, sedentary lifestyle, and unhealthy diet
• Adipose tissue secretes pro- and anti-inflammatory factors, with high-fat diets promoting the production of proinflammatory interleukins
• Menopause, defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation, leads to adverse changes in lipoproteins, glucose metabolism, and vascular endothelium, increasing the risk of cardiovascular diseases
• Estrogens, which have anti-inflammatory properties, play a role in preventing vascular inflammation and atherosclerosis, but their effects are controversial
• In this study, researchers investigated the effects of a high-fat diet with or without ovariectomy on inflammatory processes in rats by measuring the production of pro- and anti-inflammatory factors and their receptors and tlr-4 protein content.
</summary>
• Experiment involved 30-day-old female Wistar rats kept under controlled conditions and divided into four groups: sham c (sham group treated with control diet), sham h (sham group treated with hyperlipidic diet), ovx c (ovariectomized group treated with control diet), and ovx h (ovariectomized group treated with hyperlipidic diet)

<summary>
• Study of 344 patients who underwent bronchial arteriography and bronchial artery embolization (BAE) for hemoptysis at Tianjin Haihe Hospital between 2006 and 2013
• Majority of patients had acute and massive hemoptysis (78%) and mean age was 57 years
• BAE was performed in 97.7% of patients, with 1530 embolization coils used and 920 arteries embolized
• Success rate of immediate hemoptysis control was 96%, but recurrent bleeding occurred in 17.7% of patients within 1 month
• Common complications included fever, chest pain, and transient neurologic symptoms, but no major complications were reported
</summary>
• Demographics and Clinical Features
  • 344 patients underwent bronchial arteriography and BAE for hemoptysis
  • Majority had acute and massive hemoptysis (234/344, 68%)
  • Mean age was 57 years (ranging from 17 to 83 years)
  • 186 men and 158 women

• Imaging and Results
  • Chest CT scan identified causes of hemoptysis in 92.2% of cases
  • Bleeding source could be localized in unilateral lung in 36.2% of cases
  • Angiography showed indirect signs of bleeding, including tortuosity, hypertrophy, hypervascularity, aneurysms, extravasation, and shunting
  • BAE was successful in controlling hemoptysis in 96% of cases

• Complications and Follow-up
  • Recurrent hemoptysis occurred in 17.7% of patients within 1 month
  • Three patients died of massive hemoptysis within 1 month after BAE
  • Two patients with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease died of hypercapnia within 3 days after BAE
  • Common complications included fever (31.1%), chest pain (18.9%), and transient neurologic symptoms (0.9%)

• The text discusses the relationship between Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection and celiac disease (CD), focusing on the presence of lymphocytic gastritis (lg) in both conditions.
• The study aimed to define the immunophenotype of the gastric mucosa in pediatric patients with CD and HP infection, and to clarify the interrelationship between the two conditions.

• Increased numbers of intraepithelial lymphocytes (iELs) and lymphoid aggregates were observed in both CD and HP infected patients.
• CD patients without HP infection had the highest proportion of lg (50%), followed by CD patients with HP infection (20%), HP positive patients without CD (8.3%), and none in the control group.
• HP infection did not contribute to the number of CD8+ iELs in HP infected patients without CD.
• CD patients with HP infection showed a lower rate of lg compared to HP positive children without CD.
• CD8+ iELs were significantly higher in CD patients compared to controls or HP infected patients without CD.
• NK cells may play a negligible role in these two pathologies as indicated by the low expression of CD57 in lymphoid cells.
• The highest number of lymphoid follicles was observed in a similar proportion of children with or without CD, who were HP positive independent of the presence of lg.
• The inflammatory infiltrate in the lp and in the mucosal glands does not contribute to the differentiation between these diseases.
• The number of cd8+ iELs in the antrum might hint toward the diagnosis of CD rather than HP infection, and the number of lymphoid follicles directs toward the diagnosis of HP infection in undefined cases.

• Angiogenesis, the process of new blood vessel formation, is crucial for solid tumor growth, and vegf is a primary stimulant of angiogenesis, making it an attractive therapeutic target in cancer treatment.
  • Effective inhibition of vegf can reduce tumor size, microvessel density, and macrophage infiltration in breast cancer.
    • 2c3, r84, and bevacizumab effectively decrease tumor size, microvessel density, and macrophage infiltration in an orthotopic model of breast cancer.
    • Reducing macrophage infiltration is an important aspect of anti-vegf therapy.
 • Inhibition of vegf also modulates immune cell infiltration, including myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs), dendritic cells (DCs), and neutrophils.
 • Combining vegf inhibition with chemotherapy can enhance the antitumoral effect.
 • Several vegf inhibitors have been approved for cancer and age-related macular degeneration treatment.
 • Combination therapy with low-dose chemotherapy followed by angioinhibitor therapy is a common approach in clinical trials.
 • Preventive angioinhibitory therapy may be possible in the future due to its less toxicity and resistance.

• The Revive survey revealed that many postmenopausal women have low awareness and poor understanding of vulvar and vaginal atrophy (VVA) and its associated symptoms.
   • Only approximately one-quarter of women specifically identified menopause as the cause of their symptoms, and most women were unaware that their vaginal symptoms could be caused by hormonal changes.

• The survey demonstrated that communication between women and healthcare providers (HCPs) regarding VVA is inadequate.
   • Almost half of the study population had never discussed their VVA symptoms with an HCP, and among those who had, the HCP was the initiator only 13% of the time.
   • Among participants who had an HCP for gynecologic needs, only 19% reported being asked about sexual health during routine examination.

• The survey showed that VVA symptoms significantly impact women's lives.
   • The most commonly reported symptoms were vaginal dryness, dyspareunia, and local irritation, and more than half of participants reported that VVA had the greatest impact on enjoyment of sex.
   • Approximately one in four women reported that other areas of their life were negatively affected by VVA, including sleep, general enjoyment of life, and temperament.

• The survey highlighted the limitations of current OTC and prescription treatments for VVA.
   • Reported limitations included inadequate symptom relief, inconvenience, and dislike of the accommodations needed for vaginal administration.
   • Previous population-based surveys have identified that many women who use vaginal therapies to treat their VVA symptoms are dissatisfied and discontinue treatment due to concerns about side effects, messiness, or lack of effect.

• The survey provided insights into women's perspectives on their satisfaction/dissatisfaction with their current treatments for VVA.
   • Of the 3046 postmenopausal women in the survey who reported VVA symptoms, 41% were currently using some form of treatment.
   • However, of those women who had been given a clinical diagnosis of VVA, 27% were not using any treatment, and only 35% of postmenopausal women currently on any treatment were satisfied with their current VVA treatment.

- The text discusses a study estimating the prevalence of folic acid (FA) and multivitamin (MV) supplement use among Danish pregnancy planners and identifying predictors of such use.
- The study was a cross-sectional analysis of baseline data from an internet-based prospective cohort study of Danish pregnancy planners called "snart-gravid."
- Data on preconceptional use of FA and MV supplements and sociodemographic, lifestyle, reproductive, and medical variables were assessed at baseline.
- The study found that 62.1% of the pregnancy planners used FA or MV supplements, with 7.7% being exclusive FA users, 20.4% exclusive MV users, and 34.0% using both.
- Sociodemographic predictors of FA or MV use included higher age, finishing high school, having a short vocational training, and a monthly household income of less than 12,500 DKK.
- Lifestyle factors such as intercourse frequency and months attempting pregnancy at study entrance were also associated with FA or MV use.
- Women who had pap smears once or more during the last 3 years were more likely to use FA or MV supplements compared with those who did not.
- Women who engaged in physical activity were more likely to use FA or MVs than sedentary women.
- Among women who had a previous spontaneous abortion, the ppd of FA or MV use was 7.7% higher than women who did not report having a previous abortion.
- The study also discussed the differences between the study and previous studies on FA and MV use among pregnant women, including the definition of compliance with the FA recommendation and the prevalence of FA and MV use.

</summary>

• Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is linked to increased coronary and cerebral vascular risk [1, 2].
• Intermittent claudication is a common symptom of mild to moderate PAD [5, 6].
• Oxidative stress contributes to the development and progression of PAD [7, 8].

• Risk factors for PAD include high total and LDL cholesterol levels [5, 6].
• Statins, which lower lipids and have pleiotropic effects, are suggested for PAD treatment [12, 13].
• This study evaluated lipid peroxidation parameters and antioxidant capacity in PAD patients before and after surgery.
• Group I patients underwent surgical treatment, while Group II received simvastatin therapy.
• Before surgery, Group I patients had higher total and LDL cholesterol levels and enhanced oxidative stress [9].
• After surgery, no significant decrease in lipid peroxidation or increase in antioxidant capacity was observed in Group I [10].
• Group II patients had similar antioxidant capacity and lower lipid peroxidation levels than Group I before surgery [11].
• A decrease in antioxidant capacity and thiol group concentrations was observed in Group I 35 days postoperatively [12].
• Ceruloplasmin activity was influenced by both simvastatin therapy and surgical treatment, but only 710 days postoperatively [13].
</summary>

- The demand for herbal remedies in Nigeria has increased, but there is a lack of scientific data to support their medicinal claims.
- The Fijk herbal remedy, which contains 13 medicinal plants, is popular in Nigeria for treating various ailments, including obesity, diabetes, and malaria.
- The present study aimed to determine the effect of oral and repeated exposure to Fijk on rat plasma biochemical indices and liver morphology.
- The oral administration of Fijk to rats caused a significant reduction in rat plasma protein level, elevation in plasma triglyceride level, depletion of plasma hdl-c, and increase in plasma ldl-c and atherogenic index.
- The study also revealed that oral and repeated exposure to Fijk caused hepatic alterations, including hypochromic, haemorrhage, ruptured vascular channels, hyperemia, and inflammation, as well as lipid peroxidation.

</summary>

- Popularity of Fijk herbal remedy in Nigeria for various health issues

- Significant reduction in rat plasma protein level, elevation in plasma triglyceride level, depletion of plasma hdl-c, and increase in plasma ldl-c and atherogenic index
- Hepatic alterations and lipid peroxidation observed in rats exposed to Fijk herbal mixture.

- Preconceptional carrier screening allows couples to identify genetic risks before pregnancy and consider reproductive options, including termination, preimplantation diagnosis, adoption, or refraining from having children.
- Carrier screening and testing are two approaches to identifying carriers. Carrier screening is for individuals without an increased risk, while carrier testing is for those with a higher a priori risk based on personal or family history.
- Commercial companies offer direct-to-consumer (DTC) preconceptional carrier tests for autosomal recessive disorders, but ethical concerns include the informed consent procedure, medical supervision and follow-up, and appropriate use of resources.
- DTC carrier tests are available through various companies, such as DNA Direct, dnaTraits, Pathway Genomics, and Counsyl. These tests may include individual tests or panels for multiple disorders.
- Concerns about DTC carrier tests include the validity and utility of tests offered, absence of individualized medical supervision, lack of adequate consent procedures, absence or quality of pre- and post-test genetic counselling, inappropriate testing of minors, privacy issues, and potential burden on public health resources.
</summary>

- DTC carrier tests are offered through online providers:
  * DNA Direct offers individual tests for cystic fibrosis and a carrier testing panel for Ashkenazi Jews.
  * dnaTraits offers a range of individual tests and panels.
  * Pathway Genomics and 23andMe include carrier status for various single-gene conditions in their full genome testing reports.
  * Counsyl offers a prepregnancy universal carrier test for over 100 genetic diseases.

- Ethical issues with DTC carrier tests:
  * Informed consent procedure: Companies may not provide sufficient information or offer adequate pre- and post-test counselling.
  * Medical supervision and follow-up: The absence of medical supervision may compromise patient health and foster informed decision-making.
  * Appropriate use of resources: The potential burden on public health resources due to follow-up visits and tests should be considered.
  * Other ethical concerns: Privacy, confidentiality, and potential discrimination based on genetic information.

* Conducted prospectively on patients admitted for implant removal in orthopedics department of a teaching hospital

• The study aimed to determine if aaa treatment inhibits mller cell gliosis and protects against retinal abnormalities in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH) mimicking glaucoma.
• Findings showed that AOH induced cell apoptosis and decreased number of rgcs, while aaa treatment attenuated gfap immunoreactivity in mller cell processes across ipl and reduced retinal tnf- levels.
</summary>
• Experimental design: Adult male Sprague Dawley rats were used in the study, and AOH was induced by increasing IOP for 60 minutes. Animals were divided into sham operation (ctrl), AOH, AOH + PBS, and AOH + aaa groups. Aaa was injected into vitreous humor after 3 hours of acute IOP elevation.
• Results: AOH induced significant reduction in retinal thickness in the inner plexiform layer (ipl) and inner nuclear layer, and increased apoptotic cells in the ganglion cell layer. AOH + PBS group had more tunel-positive cells and decreased number of thy-1-positive rgcs compared to the ctrl group. Aaa treatment attenuated tunel-positive rgcs and rescued rgcs from apoptosis, as indicated by increased number of thy-1-positive rgcs. Immunohistochemistry for gfap and gs showed mller cell activation and gliosis in the AOH model, which was attenuated by aaa treatment. Western blot analysis confirmed upregulated tnf- protein levels in the AOH group, which were significantly attenuated by aaa treatment.
• Conclusion: Aaa treatment protected retina against loss of rgcs and apoptosis in the AOH model through attenuating mller cell gliosis and downregulating tnf- production, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic target in the treatment of neurodegeneration in glaucoma.

* Laeftr-L is an alternative full-thickness resection (FTR) method for treating nonampullary gastrointestinal neoplasms using laparoscopy and a ligation device.
* The procedure involves identifying the lesion using endoscopy, ligation of the tumor with a ligation device, temporary laparoscopic suturing, and endoscopic resection under the ligation band.
* Advantages of Laeftr-L include avoiding peritoneal exposure of tumor cells and shorter endoscopic resection time compared to conventional FTR methods.
* Five consecutive patients underwent Laeftr-L for nonampullary duodenal neoplasms, achieving complete resection in all cases with a mean operative time of 173 minutes and a mean tumor size of 9 mm.
* The procedure can be applied to lesions smaller than 15 mm in diameter and not close to the ampulla of Vater.
* Prospective studies are needed to further evaluate the efficacy and safety of Laeftr-L procedures.

</summary>

* Procedure: Laeftr-L is a laparoscopy-assisted endoscopic FTR method using a ligation device.
  + Identification of lesion using endoscopy.
  + Ligation of tumor with a ligation device.
  + Temporary laparoscopic suturing.
  + Endoscopic resection under ligation band.

* Advantages: Laeftr-L offers several advantages over conventional FTR methods.
  + Avoids peritoneal exposure of tumor cells.
  + Shorter endoscopic resection time.

* Patient Outcomes: Five patients underwent Laeftr-L for nonampullary duodenal neoplasms.
  + Complete resection achieved in all cases.

  + Mean tumor size: 9 mm (7-11 mm).

• Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis, with 90-95% being caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD).
• CAH patients may experience signs and symptoms of androgen excess, including ambiguous genitalia in females and rapid somatic growth with accelerated skeletal maturation in both sexes.
• Medical treatment typically involves oral glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration to compensate for adrenal steroid deficiencies and suppress adrenal androgens.
• Adrenal masses have been found in CAH patients, with recent reports revealing a high prevalence of small tumors in untreated patients.
• Two cases in this report were managed with adrenalectomy due to increasing adrenal mass size and virilization.
• CAH is an autosomal recessive condition caused by deletions or mutations of the cytochrome p450 21-hydroxylase gene.
• CAH is classified into classic, non-classic, salt-losing, and non-salt-losing forms based on clinical features and severity.
• CAH patients may develop adrenal adenoma or carcinoma, and follow-up imaging is recommended for long-term management to detect early signs of tumor development.
</summary>

* The text discusses the relationship between self-rated health (SRH) and dietary and physical activity behaviors.
* SRH was found to be poorer among females, older adults, obese individuals, non-hispanic blacks, those with comorbidities, and those who consumed fewer fruits and vegetables or mostly high-fat foods.
* The text also highlights the importance of physical activity in improving SRH and reducing the risk of chronic diseases, with females being less physically active than males.

Level 1:
- Self-rated health (SRH) and dietary and physical activity behaviors
- Relationship between SRH and lifestyle factors

Level 2:
- SRH was poorer among females, older adults, obese individuals, non-hispanic blacks, and those with comorbidities
- Factors associated with poorer SRH: consuming fewer fruits and vegetables or mostly high-fat foods, less physical activity
- Importance of physical activity in improving SRH and reducing chronic disease risk
- Females were less physically active than males

Level 2:
- Females had a higher percentage of obesity, reported poorer SRH, and were less physically active than males
- Participants with poorer SRH were more likely to be older, obese, non-hispanic black, have comorbidities, consume fewer fruits and vegetables, and have a higher intake of high-fat foods
- Unadjusted and adjusted logistic regression models showed that females who consumed fewer fruits and vegetables or mostly high-fat foods were more likely to report poorer SRH
- Males who consumed mostly high-fat foods were more likely to report poorer SRH than those who consumed primarily low-fat foods
- Females who reported less physical activity were more likely to report poorer SRH than those who reported more physical activity
- Physical activity was associated with improved SRH and reduced risk of chronic diseases, regardless of gender
- Gender differences in physical activity levels and SRH may be explained by biological and sociocultural factors
- Participants who were highly active had better SRH than those who were less active
- Limitations of the study include the inability to establish causality and the lack of consideration of other factors that may influence SRH, such as socioeconomic status, neighborhood, housing situation, and psychosocial factors.

* Endoscopic injection of Dextranomer / hyaluronic acid copolymer (Dx/HA) using the Deflux product has expanded as a treatment option for pediatric Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR) with success rates ranging from 55-89%.
* The technique is popular due to its ease, short procedure time, and repeatability. However, it has a lower success rate (25%) compared to traditional open surgery and requires follow-up voiding cystograms to detect remaining VUR.

* Detection of occult VUR in patients with recurrent UTIs:
  * Pic cystography (PC) is a sensitive and specific method for detecting VUR, especially in patients with negative standard voiding cystograms.
  * Intraoperative PC can predict successful surgical outcomes by correlating results with postoperative cystograms.

* Comparison of two PC techniques and scenarios:
  * Preoperative unilateral VUR: PC or high-pressure cystograms can detect de novo contralateral VUR.
  * Post-injection PC: can predict successful surgical outcomes by correlating results with standard 2-month postprocedure cystograms.

* Retrospective study on intraoperative cystograms at the institution:
  * Dx/HA injections were performed for all grades of VUR, including complex cases.
  * Preoperative unilateral reflux patients underwent PC on the contralateral side before injection.
  * High-pressure intraoperative cystograms (Group 1) and standard PC (Group 2) were compared for detection of de novo VUR and remaining VUR after injection.

* Results:
  * 116 patients and 177 renal units (RUs) were treated and evaluated.
  * 27 RUs (8.6%) had new contralateral VUR (de novo) intraoperatively in preoperative unilateral reflux patients.
  * No statistically significant difference between groups 1 and 2 for the detection of de novo VUR.
  * Only 5 RUs had remaining VUR intraoperatively after Dx/HA injection.

* Fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an adjunct to ultrasound for diagnosing and characterizing fetal anomalies, particularly central nervous system pathology, including ventriculomegaly.
* Ventriculomegaly is a condition characterized by an enlargement of the lateral ventricles, with varying degrees of severity and causes.
* MRI has advantages over ultrasound, such as excellent contrast resolution and the ability to directly visualize the cortical region without sonographic limiting factors.
* MRI is useful for detecting additional cerebral anomalies, such as intraventricular hemorrhages, corpus callosum dysgenesis, cortical anomalies, and congenital infections.
* MRI is particularly valuable for evaluating cortical malformations, such as polymicrogyria, and detecting pathological white matter changes and cortical malformations in cases of congenital infections.
* MRI is more sensitive than ultrasound for detecting small foci of brain hemorrhage or callosal anomalies in fetuses diagnosed with cerebral ventriculomegaly.
* MRI is useful for assessing the size of the cerebral ventricles in cases where fetal position and calvarial ossification cause problems.
* The interobserver agreement for both ultrasound and MRI can vary greatly, and the level of subspecialty training of the individuals interpreting the MRI examination significantly improves interobserver agreement.
* The availability, cost, and expertise of fetal radiologists are practical issues that limit the use of MRI for prenatal cases of ventriculomegaly.
* Most studies advocate the added value of MRI in cases of moderate and severe ventriculomegaly for confirming severity and detecting additional anomalies. In cases of mild unilateral ventriculomegaly, MRI may demonstrate additional findings that are difficult to detect with sonography.

</summary>

- Lung cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed and the leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the US, with 226,160 diagnoses and 160,340 deaths in 2012.
- The SEER program reported that 56% of lung cancer cases were at a distant stage at diagnosis, and 38% of these patients had possible bone metastasis within a year of diagnosis.
- Bone metastasis is a common complication in lung cancer patients, with 21% of all lung cancer patients and 39% of those with distant stage disease having possible bone metastasis within a year of diagnosis.
- Among patients with bone metastasis, 51% had one or more skeletal-related events (SREs), such as fractures, radiotherapy to bone, surgery to bone, or spinal cord compression.
- The most common SRE was radiotherapy to bone, which occurred in 81% of patients with SREs.
- The median time from cancer diagnosis to bone metastasis was 5.4 months, and patients with bone metastasis were more likely to have distant stage disease and to have died by the end of the study period.
- The hazard ratio for death was 2.4 for patients with bone metastasis, both with and without SREs, compared to those without bone metastasis.
- Limitations of the study include the lack of validation of the procedures used to identify bone metastasis, potential confounding factors not included in the analysis, and the lack of information on functional status of patients.

</summary>

• Study compared the effect of photodynamic diode laser and other smear layer removal methods on bond strength of self-adhesive cement using fiber posts
• Null hypothesis: no significant differences would be found among push-out bond strength values after different root canal surface treatments
• 55 maxillary central incisors were used, cleaned, and prepared with a rotary system and irrigated with sodium hypochlorite or ethylene diamine tetra acetic acid (EDTA) or etched with orthophosphoric acid or treated with a photodynamic diode laser
• Bond strength was highest for the laser and orthophosphoric acid groups, while mixed failure occurred for the other groups
• Results revealed that different smear layer removal methods affect the bond strength of a fiber post cemented with adhesive resin to dentin (p<.05)

• NaCl, sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl), EDTA, and orthophosphoric acid (H3PO4) groups showed post-cement and cement-dentin failure (mixed failure)
• Helbo theralite laser showed post-cement failure at the cross sectional image of the dentin discs
• Smear layer removal is important for increasing antibacterial effects and adhesive effectiveness, but some authors suggest retaining it for material adaptation
• Photodynamic diode laser group had higher bond strength than other groups except h3po4 group without smear layer removal
• Collagen fibrils structure does not change after lasing, improving the infiltration of the luting agent
• Sodium hypochlorite removes organic components and breaks down to sodium chloride and oxygen, inhibiting interfacial polymerization
• 17% EDTA alone was not effective in removing smear remnants, but dual irrigation methods are effective but result in sporadic erosion and dentin dissolution
• Using the photodynamic diode laser in post space increased the bond strength of resin cement to dentin interface

</summary>

• The human microbiome project and metagenomics of the human intestinal tract consortium aim to characterize microbial communities in various human body sites and find correlations with diseases.
• The human gut flora mainly consists of two phyla: Firmicutes and Bacteroidetes, with smaller representations of Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria. Archaea, mostly represented by methanogenic methanobrevibacter smithii, have a smaller diversity than bacterial species.
• The composition of the bacterial flora depends on the environment and maternal input during delivery and breastfeeding. Human gut flora is more similar between family members than unrelated individuals, regardless of host genotype.
• Recent studies have revealed more details about human bacterial communities, including the identification of genes and their relevance to gut function. The minimal gut microbiome genes are involved in housekeeping functions and gut-specific functions.
• The concept of enterotypes, which are systematically organized clusters of microbes in each individual, has emerged as a new way to classify the gut microbiome. Enterotypes are identified based on different clusters of bacterial species and have unique properties, but their association with geography, sex, age, or BMI is unclear.
</summary>

- Onychomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the nail characterized by discoloration, thickening, and defect.1,2
  - Dermatophytes, yeasts (Candida), and nondermatophytes are the causative agents.2,3
  - Prevalence is higher in toenails than in fingernails, and aging, reduced peripheral circulation, and diabetes are major risk factors.4,7

- Tazarotene, a topical drug used for nail psoriasis, was investigated for its effect on onychomycosis in an open preliminary study.15,16
  - Tazarotene's immunomodulating and anti-inflammatory properties inhibit the infective process.17,18
  - Epidermal penetration is improved by reducing hyperkeratinization and favoring keratinocyte differentiation.18

- The study reported the therapeutic efficacy of tazarotene 0.1% gel for distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis in 15 patients.21
  - Complete mycological cure and clinical healing were observed in all patients after 12 weeks.21,23
  - No side effects were reported except for mild erythema on the perionychia in two patients.23

- Tazarotene exhibits fungistatic activity against T. mentagrophytes, T. verrucosum, C. albicans, and C. glabrata.24
  - In vitro studies showed inhibition of fungal growth, suggesting a direct action on fungus replication.24

• Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) is used to treat heart failure and left ventricular dyssynchrony, but clinical non-response is reported in 25% of patients.
• Causes of non-response include inadequate delivery of CRT therapy and patient selection.
• This study aimed to improve existing CRT in clinical non-responders by testing acute haemodynamic responses to alternative left ventricular endocardial pacing sites.
• Twenty-four patients, aged 72.8 ± 9.1 years, with NYHA class III or IV heart failure despite adequate medical therapy and no therapeutic options were included.
• The study used a 6F multipurpose angioplasty guiding catheter to perform endocardial pacing and measure left ventricular diastolic pressure/time max (LVdp/dtmax) at various sites.
• The atrioventricular and interventricular intervals were optimized to obtain the maximal LVdp/dtmax at each site.

<summary>

* Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects 1 in every 500 to 1000 individuals, with no predictable progression to renal failure in half of the patients.
* Complications for pregnant women with chronic renal failure undergoing dialysis include maternal hypertension, preeclampsia, anemia, infected renal and hepatic cysts, pyelonephritis, and rupture of cerebral artery aneurysms.
* A 35-year-old primigravida with ADPKD underwent emergency LSCS due to oligohydramnios and renal insufficiency.
* Preoperative investigations showed normal hematology and coagulation profiles, with a serum creatinine of 3.7 mg%.
* Spinal anesthesia was successfully performed using 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine and fentanyl, maintaining normal hemodynamic and biochemical parameters postoperatively.
* During pregnancy, women with moderate or severe antenatal renal insufficiency may experience deterioration of their renal functions due to increased glomerular perfusion or a cascade of platelet aggregation, microvascular fibrin thrombus formation, and endothelial dysfunction.

* Increased glomerular perfusion during pregnancy may paradoxically cause further injury to the kidneys in patients with preexisting impairment of function, but this hypothesis is not supported by published data.
* Preexisting renal disease may induce a cascade of platelet aggregation, microvascular fibrin thrombus formation, and endothelial dysfunction, leading to microvascular injury in the already tenuous kidneys.
* Serum creatinine concentration greater than 0.8 mg/dl and a BUN concentration greater than 13 mg/dl suggest renal insufficiency during pregnancy.
* Tubular sodium reabsorption and osmoregulation are reset, allowing a physiologic hypervolemia during gestation, and modest proteinuria occurs during pregnancy.
</summary>

<summary>

- Genetic variation contributes to disease susceptibility and treatment response.
- GWAS have enabled the discovery of genetic variants contributing to complex genetic diseases and pharmacogenetic markers.
- Personalized medicine applications include situations of withholding treatment, preventive interventions, or targeted treatment options for individual patients.
- Biomarkers are substances or biological structures that can be measured in the human body and influence, explain, or predict the incidence or outcome of disease.
- Differences between DNA biomarkers, DNA tumor biomarkers, and general biomarkers include stability, reproducibility, complexity, and time required for measurement.
- Current applications of biomarkers for diagnosis, prognosis, and prediction in personalized medicine include predictive biomarkers for breast cancer, lung cancer, and hepatitis C virus infection, and diagnostic biomarkers for rheumatoid arthritis and myocardial infarction.

* Diagnostic biomarkers:
  * Used to determine the diagnosis or severity of a disease.
  * Screening biomarkers are used to discriminate between healthy individuals and those in an early stage of a disease.
  * Examples include point-of-care tests for rheumatoid arthritis and myocardial infarction.

* Predictive biomarkers:
  * Predict the likely response of a patient to a special treatment in terms of efficacy and/or safety.
  * Examples include il28b gene as a predictive biomarker for response to treatment with pegylated interferon and ribavirin in patients with hepatitis C virus infection.
</summary>

• Myosin VA (myova) is a processive molecular motor involved in intracellular cargo transport along the actin cytoskeleton.
   • Its directed movement is accomplished by a conformational change in the motor domain following ATP hydrolysis, amplified by lever arms.

 • Myova's structural flexibility is crucial for maneuvering through actin intersections and traveling along actin bundles.
   • Critical domains for myova's maneuverability may reside within the lever arms or at the lever arm / coiled-coil junction.

 • Tethered particle microscopy (TPM) was used to measure the flexural stiffness of individual myova motors and their subdomains.
   • TPM involves anchoring a myova-actin complex to a microscope slide and attaching a visible particle to a desired location along the motor.

 • Thermal energy causes the particle to be randomly displaced, and the resulting motion is measured by comparing the difference in apparent image size.
   • The effective tether length and flexibility determine the particle's apparent image size, allowing individual structural domains to be isolated and their contributions to the overall flexibility assessed.

 • Calmodulin disassociation from the myova lever arm decreases the lever arm's flexural stiffness, contributing to the motor's compromised processivity in the presence of calcium.
   • TPM was used to define the flexural stiffness of myova subdomains by attaching qdots to expressed myova constructs of different lengths.

 • Full-length murine myova, double-headed myova constructs, and single-headed myova constructs were expressed and purified for the study.
   • Double-headed myova constructs were coexpressed with calcium-insensitive calmodulin to maintain their calcium sensitivity.

 • Biotinylated actin filaments were attached to the glass surface through nem-modified myosin, and streptavidin-conjugated qdots were attached to the c-termini of myova constructs.
   • The myova constructs were strongly bound to actin in the absence of MgATP, and the calcium-dependent flexibility of the myova-s1 construct was measured using TPM.

- The study aimed to determine if clinical outcome after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) could be predicted by functional polymorphisms in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.
- Six SNPs in the aurka, erbb2, mdm2, cdh1, cdkn2a, and tp73 genes were genotyped in a cohort of 346 esophageal cancer patients.
- Univariate analysis showed no significant associations between DFS and the tested polymorphisms in patients with EAC or ESCC.
- In multivariate analysis, patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous mdm2 (rs2279744) t/g genotype had significantly improved DFS compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype (HR 0.63, 95% CI [0.45-0.88]).
- Patients with EAC harboring the homozygous cdh1 (rs5030625) ga/ga genotype had a significantly reduced survival as compared with patients carrying the wild-type g/g genotype (HR 4.0, 95% CI [1.4-11]).
- The mdm2 and cdh1 polymorphisms were significantly associated with DFS in patients with EAC after adjusting for potential confounders.
- The findings could contribute to the identification of patients at high or low risk for disease recurrences and may serve as hypothesis-generating for prospective studies evaluating the prognostic significance of germ-line variants.

</summary>

• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with approximately 1.67 million new patients diagnosed annually.
• Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is the standard method for determining axillary staging in early-stage breast cancer patients with a clinically and radiologically negative axilla.
• The combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye is currently used for SLNB, but it has drawbacks such as the use of radioisotopes and limited access in many hospitals.
• A magnetic tracer and a handheld magnetometer were evaluated as a radiation-free alternative in two clinical trials.
• The magnetic technique was found to be noninferior to the combined technique with identification rates of 94.4%-98.0%.
• However, there was a discordance in SLNs identified between the magnetic and combined techniques, potentially leading to false-negative staging with the magnetic technique.
• A smaller study using a similar spio tracer and different magnetometer demonstrated the viability of the technique for performing SLNB in the absence of radioisotopes.
• The particle size of the magnetic tracer used for the magnetic technique is much larger than that of the radioisotope, which could influence lymphatic uptake and lymph node retention.
• Three spio-based licensed formulations were evaluated in an in vivo porcine model to optimize the clinical application of the magnetic technique for SLNB.
• The 59 nm tracer demonstrated the best performance in the study, with rapid distribution, retention in the first nodes reached, and accumulation in high concentrations, making it the most suitable magnetic tracer for SLNB.
</summary>

• Two clinical trials were conducted to test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing.
• In the first study, patients received intralesional injections of rhegf at 75g or 25g three times a week. In the second study, patients were randomized to rhegf 75g, 48g, or a placebo group.
• A total of 190 ulcers were included in the analyses, and results from a postmarketing surveillance study of 1,440 ulcers were also considered.
• Patients were diabetic, had wagner grade 3 or 4 ulcers larger than 1cm, and received standard care including debridement, moist dressing, pressure offloading, and antibiotics.
• Granulation tissue development and percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas at the 2nd week and end of treatment (eot) were used as surrogate variables.
• The median treatment duration was 5 weeks, and missing data were imputed using the last observation carried forward or the average of contiguous evaluations.
• The area under the receiver operating characteristic (roc) curve was calculated for each surrogate variable to evaluate its capacity and quality of discrimination.
• The granulation variable had the highest correct classification index (percent of individuals correctly classified) and high negative predictive value (conditional probability to have a negative result if the test was negative).
• The proportion mediated (using pc estimators) for 2 weeks > 50% granulation and eot > 75% granulation were 1.008 (95% ci 0.933-1.083) and 1.043 (0.946-1.142), respectively, suggesting almost 100% of the effect of treatment on complete healing may have been mediated by granulation tissue formation.
</summary>

* Study compared perioperative surgical trauma and postoperative impact on the abdominal wall between Needle Scopic Transabdominal Preperitoneal (ntapp) and Single Incision Laparoscopic Surgery (stapp) for inguinal hernia repair
* 85 patients with a single-sided primary inguinal hernia were recruited between November 2009 and July 2012
* Demographic and surgical data were collected from surgical records and postoperative questionnaires
* ntapp procedure involved smaller umbilical skin incision and less operating time than stapp procedure
* stapp procedure had a longer umbilical skin incision and longer operative time, with some cases requiring an additional working trocar
* ntapp patients had less immediate postoperative pain and shorter sick leave than stapp patients
* Both procedures had similar results in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction
* One ntapp patient had chronic discomfort, and one stapp patient developed postherniorrhaphy pain syndrome
* The smaller jaws and lesser contact area in stapp procedure may exert more force and tear tissue, leading to potential complications
* Further studies are needed to validate the benefits of needlescopic surgery in laparoscopic tapp hernia repair.

* Smaller umbilical skin incision in ntapp procedure
* Shorter operative time in ntapp procedure
* Fewer cases of additional working trocars in ntapp procedure
* Less immediate postoperative pain in ntapp patients
* Shorter sick leave in ntapp patients
* Larger umbilical skin incision in stapp procedure
* Longer operative time in stapp procedure
* Some cases of additional working trocars in stapp procedure
* Greater force exerted on tissue in stapp procedure
* Potential complications from smaller jaws and lesser contact area in stapp procedure.

• The text discusses a case of a woman with breast cancer who developed a second primary tumor in the same breast after initial treatment
• Key points in the diagnosis and treatment of the second tumor:
  - The second tumor was diagnosed as inflammatory breast cancer (IBC)
  - Immunohistochemical analysis showed negative ER and PR expression and positive Her-2 expression
  - The patient received chemotherapy with paclitaxel, carboplatin, and trastuzumab
• The text also discusses the importance of distinguishing true local recurrence (TR) from new primary tumors (NPT) in breast cancer patients, and the challenges in differentiating between the two
• Key points on TR and NPT:
  - TR refers to the regrowth of malignant cells not removed by initial treatment, while NPT is a new malignancy arising from residual breast tissue
  - Differentiating between TR and NPT can be difficult, and methods such as genetic sequencing and molecular techniques are being used to establish true clonality
  - Patients with NPT are generally younger at initial diagnosis and have a favorable prognosis, while those with TR have a poor prognosis and may benefit from more aggressive adjuvant treatment.

<summary>

- Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of severe vision loss in older adults, with neovascular AMD accounting for most cases of severe central vision loss.
- Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including VEGF, is implicated in the development and progression of AMD.
- Intravitreal anti-VEGF therapy, such as ranibizumab and aflibercept, is effective in preventing vision loss and improving visual acuity in patients with neovascular AMD.
- Contrast sensitivity (CS) testing is an important measure of visual function in addition to visual acuity (VA), as it can detect subtle vision changes that may be concealed by acuity testing.

* Neovascular AMD:
  * Leading cause of severe vision loss in older adults
  * Neovascular form involves choroidal neovascularization (CNV) and fluid exudation or bleeding
  * Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including VEGF, implicated in development and progression

* Intravitreal Anti-VEGF Therapy:
  * Ranibizumab and aflibercept approved for treatment of neovascular AMD
  * Monthly ranibizumab prevents vision loss in most patients, with significant visual gain in some
  * Aflibercept every 8 weeks noninferior to monthly ranibizumab, with longer duration of action and greater binding affinity to VEGF

* CS Testing:
  * Measures an individual's ability to detect low contrast images and perceive differences between light and dark
  * Can detect subtle vision changes that may be concealed by acuity testing
  * Sensitive and essential outcome end point for a complete assessment of visual function and visual performance
  * Potential applications for patients with high visual requirements, such as athletes and public service personnel
</summary>

• The aim of the study was to evaluate the association between the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene and MS in an Iranian population.

• The occurrence of MS was confirmed using McDonald's criteria and brain MRI results by an expert neurologist.
• Inclusion criteria were having at least one central nervous system demyelinating event and being at least 18 years old to give informed consent.
• Exclusion criteria were genetic diseases, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, and smoking.

• DNA was purified from peripheral blood immune cells using a commercial kit and the PCR amplification of exon 2 of the IL-25 gene and RFLP was performed.
• The results revealed no statistically significant difference in the frequency distribution of genotypes or alleles between MS patients and healthy controls.
• The authors hypothesized that polymorphisms within cytokine genes are associated with their expression and that the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene may be associated with MS.

<summary>

* Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with 1.7 million new cases in 2012.
* The highest incidence rates are in Europe and North America, with Belgium, Denmark, and France having the highest rates.
* Digital mammography (DM) has replaced screen-film mammography (SFM) in most practices in the US, offering digital image processing and improved sensitivity.
* DM uses less radiation than SFM and has a lower false-positive rate, but it still has limitations, such as tissue overlap and the need for breast compression.
* Tomosynthesis, a 3-D mammography technique, can help solve the problem of tissue overlap and improve cancer detection.
* The use of intravascular contrast material with DM can enhance tumor detection by taking advantage of malignant neovascularity.
* Clinical trials, such as the Oslo trial and the Storm study, have shown that adding tomosynthesis to DM can increase cancer detection and decrease false-positive recalls.
* Ongoing research includes the use of contrast-enhanced tomosynthesis and automated breast ultrasound with tomosynthesis, as well as continued improvements in radiation exposure and imaging parameters.

</summary>

<summary>
• Study investigates the effect of diphenhydramine-containing, multicomponent syrup on cough reflex sensitivity in healthy subjects with acute URI, compared to dextromethorphan-containing syrup and placebo.
• Diphenhydramine inhibits cough reflex sensitivity in subjects with acute URI (p < 0.01), making it a more effective antitussive than dextromethorphan (p = 0.0024).
• Cough reflex sensitivity was measured 2 hours after study drug administration to coincide with near-peak blood concentrations of the agents under investigation.
• Five subjects reported slight drowsiness after ingesting diphenhydramine, and five reported side effects after ingesting dextromethorphan syrup.
• The study is the first to demonstrate the ability of diphenhydramine to inhibit cough reflex sensitivity in acute pathological cough, contributing to the initial evidence for this agent as an effective antitussive.

• Cough reflex sensitivity was significantly inhibited (log c5 increased) after diphenhydramine (p < 0.01).
• Diphenhydramine-containing syrup contains natural cocoa flavoring, which may contribute to its overall efficacy by creating a demulcent effect.
• Theobromine, a component of cocoa, has been shown to have antitussive effect, but the amount in the medication evaluated herein is much smaller than that required for cough reflex inhibition.
• Placebo preparation was also sweetened to present subjects with sweet liquids on each of the 3 days of testing to account for the effect of sweet substances on cough reflex sensitivity to capsaicin.
</summary>

<summary>
• Aging population: Global population is getting older, with older adults being at increased risk for cardiovascular diseases due to endothelial dysfunction.
• Endothelial dysfunction: Characterized by reduced vasodilator substance output (NO) and increased endothelium-derived contracting factors, leading to a vasoconstrictive, hypercoagulative, proliferative, and proinflammatory state.
• Endothelium: A monolayer of cells lining blood vessels, responsible for adjusting vascular function, modulating coagulation, and contributing to tissue perfusion.
• NO production: Decreased in older adults due to oxidative stress, which inactivates NO and reduces its bioavailability.
• Oxidative stress: An imbalance between production of oxidizing agents (ROS and RNS) and antioxidant systems, leading to endothelial dysfunction and increased production of proinflammatory cytokines.
• Inflammation: A critical component of atherosclerosis, with markers such as hs-CRP being used to provide insights on the biological status of atherosclerotic lesions.
• Exercise: A modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease, with regular physical activity shown to improve endothelial function, reduce inflammation, and increase antioxidant defense mechanisms.
</summary>

• Endothelial dysfunction:
  • Reduced vasodilator substance output (NO)
  • Increased endothelium-derived contracting factors

• Endothelium:

  • Adjusts vascular function
  • Modulates coagulation
  • Contributes to tissue perfusion

  • Promotes chronic inflammation

<summary>
• Axillary lymph node status is crucial for breast carcinoma prognosis, with increasing metastatic lymph nodes worsening the prognosis.
• The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC)/International Union Against Cancer (UICC) classifies nodal disease into three groups based on the number of axillary metastatic lymph nodes: n1, n2, and n3.
• The number of metastatic lymph nodes depends on the number of removed lymph nodes and varies with the surgeon and pathologist.
• Studies suggest that the lymph node ratio (LNR), which is the ratio of the number of metastatic lymph nodes to the number of removed lymph nodes, provides more useful prognostic information than nodal disease classification based on the number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• The LNR threshold value separating patients into two prognostic groups with significantly different survival varies depending on the study and ranges from 0.10 to 0.80.
• In a study of breast carcinoma patients with 13 axillary metastatic lymph nodes, dfs and lrfs were significantly worse in patients with 15 lymph nodes removed compared to those with 6 or more nodes removed, and this grouping had independent prognostic significance for both types of survival outcomes.
• LNR is a more powerful prognostic factor than the number of metastatic lymph nodes and can be used to separate n1 disease patients having at least 10 lymph nodes removed into low- and high-risk prognostic groups for distant metastasis development.
</summary>

<summary>

- Non-native biological invaders have caused significant damage to ecosystems for centuries, with examples including the phylloxera and chestnut blight.
- Charles Elton's work in the 1950s on invasions did not lead to a widespread response, but an international project in the 1980s triggered a surge of research on invasions.
- Research on invasions has focused on how introduced species impact native species at the population, community, and ecosystem levels.
- Two new lines of research have emerged: impacts on nutrient cycles and other ecosystem processes, and the use of molecular genetic techniques to trace sources and routes of invasions.
- Hybridization and introgression between native and introduced species have been discovered through molecular genetic research.
- Introgression can cause substantial evolution of native species and even produce new, more invasive species.
- Environmental DNA (eDNA) is increasingly used to detect invaders and played a key role in showing the advance of Asian carp toward the Great Lakes.
- Invasion biology has faced criticism on various grounds, including the argument that problems are overblown, the belief that introduced species increase native biodiversity, xenophobia, the belief that it's a hopeless battle, and concerns about the ethics of eradication.
- Critics also call for the end of traditional restoration ecology and the promotion of novel ecosystems, which is incorrect and can influence policy in a way that delays prevention and redress of environmental impacts.

</summary>

* Research on invasions:
  * Focused on population, community, and ecosystem impacts
  * Two new lines of research: ecosystem processes and molecular genetics

* Impacts of invasions:
  * Documented for only about 10% of introduced species in Europe, but likely underestimated
  * About 30% of introduced terrestrial vertebrates, freshwater plants, and animals have harmful impacts
  * Lag effects and subtle impacts mean that early action is necessary
  * Some native species cause impacts, but less frequently than non-native species

* Criticism of invasion biology:
  * Problems are overblown and most introduced species are not problematic
  * Introduced species increase native biodiversity
  * Antipathy toward introduced

• The text describes a case of a biopsy-proven schwannoma of the vidian canal in a patient with multiple sclerosis.
• The patient presented with a new finding on MRI, which revealed a 19 mm ovoid mass along the inferior margin of the right cavernous sinus originating within an expanded vidian canal.

• The patient was asymptomatic, but underwent surgery to remove the mass.
• The patient's recovery was unremarkable, and she had no problems with dry eye or nasal irritation postoperatively.
• The patient decided to pursue stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT) as her treatment due to the benign histology, her young age, and the potential risks of late normal tissue injury with radiation.
• Schwannomas of the vidian canal are rare and can present with symptoms of headaches, facial pain, facial muscle paralysis, decreased lacrimation, and nasal dryness.
• There have been four documented cases of biopsy-proven vidian nerve schwannomas in the literature, with presenting symptoms including headache, facial palsy, oculomotor palsy, unilateral hearing loss, and facial paresthesias.
• Traditional and curative management of peripheral nerve tumors is surgical, but recent advancements in transnasal endoscopic skull base approaches enable complete resection.
• Radiation therapy is also an alternative option for treatment, with options including single-fraction stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) or conventional fractionated radiotherapy.
• The choice of treatment modality depends on patient choice, functional status, presenting symptoms, tumor location, tumor volume, and malignant potential.
• The patient in this case decided to pursue treatment with radiation therapy due to the significant increase in tumor volume during the eight-year interval of MRI surveillance and the presence of bone erosion.
• SRS and fractionated radiation have similar results, but SRS is more convenient for the patient and has a high success rate of durable tumor control, while fractionated radiation is chosen when there are concerns for late effects or critical radiation-sensitive structures in adjacent areas.

• The study compared the stiffness of a short-segment pedicle fixation using monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws placed at the level of a burst fracture in a calf experimental model.
• The study found that short-segment constructs containing intermediate screws had decreased flexion, extension, and torsion in both the mpsi and ppsi groups compared to the respective constructs without this reinforcement.
• The addition of intermediate screws at the level of a burst fracture significantly increased the stiffness of the short-segment pedicle fixation, irrespective of whether monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws were used. However, the mpsi construct had a more significant increase in stiffness than the ppsi construct due to better coupling between the polyaxial screw heads and the connecting rod.

• Electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films of inorganic semiconductor cuscn and organic dyes has been used to create photoanodes for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), bypassing the need for high-temperature sintering and allowing the use of conductive plastic substrates.
 
 • ESA has been successfully used to create zno photoanodes with vertically aligned interconnected and crystalline nanowires of zno filled with aggregates of dye. The solid dye can be removed by soaking the hybrid film in a mild alkaline solution, resulting in porous crystal zno with high surface area and high crystallinity.

 • Researchers have also attempted to create cuscn-based hybrid thin films using ESA, with the goal of creating a counterpart to the well-established zno-based systems for use in DSSCs. They have explored the use of dyes with soft basic ncs groups and cationic dyes as structure-directing agents (SDAs) for the formation of nanostructures and changes in crystallographic orientation of cuscn.
</summary>

  • Vertically aligned interconnected and crystalline nanowires of zno formed, with aggregates of dye filling the space between the nanowires
