• Exploring creation of cuscn-based hybrid thin films using ESA as a counterpart to zno-based systems

  • Successfully used dyes with soft basic ncs groups and cationic dyes as SDAs for formation of nanostructures and changes in crystallographic orientation of cuscn
 
  • Goal is to create a counterpart to zno-based systems for use in DSSCs.

- A 34-year-old Arabian female presented with medically intractable seizures and a history of hydrocephalus and right ventriculoperitoneal shunting.
- She also had decreased visual acuity in both eyes, contractures, and mental impairment.
- Neurological examination revealed chorioretinitis, compatible with congenital toxoplasmosis, and positive toxoplasma-specific IgG test.
- Seizures were characterized by psychic aura and secondary generalized seizures with right eyeball deviation and head version.
- Brain imaging showed multifocal encephalomalacia, left hippocampal sclerosis (HS), left amygdala hypertrophy, and multifocal parenchymal calcification.
- Video-EEG monitoring revealed complex partial seizures (CPS) with secondary generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS), starting with psychic aura and accompanied by tonic posture and head version.
- Ictal and interictal SPECT showed ictal hyperperfusion in bilateral frontotemporal areas and hypoperfusion in the left frontotemporal area.
- Brain FDG-PET demonstrated focal hypermetabolism in the left medial temporal cortex and hypometabolism in the left fronto-parieto-temporal cortex.
- Wada test revealed right hemisphere language and memory dominance, predictive of good outcome after left anteromesial temporal resection.
- Given the medically intractable seizures and epileptogenic focus in the left temporal lobe, epilepsy surgery with left anteromesial temporal resection was performed to achieve seizure control.

• Approximately 20 million people have gallstones, and 1 million new patients are diagnosed with cholelithiasis each year.
• Cholelithiasis treatment costs exceed $5 billion annually, making it the most costly digestive disease.
• In 1992, a consensus development conference concluded that laparoscopic cholecystectomy offered advantages over open cholecystectomy with no increase in morbidity or mortality.
• Laparoscopic cholecystectomy reduces disability and shortens recovery time, leading to potential cost savings.
• Excessive length of stay (LOS) and charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy at Maricopa Medical Center (MMC) were identified and compared to open cholecystectomy.
• Matched pair comparisons between open and converted laparoscopic cholecystectomy patients eliminated many confounding variables, revealing that increased charges were due to laparoscopy.
• A retrospective review of 70 cholecystectomy patients found that open cholecystectomy was more cost-effective, but reducing laparoscopy charges could make it cost-effective.
• Steiner's review of surgical rates and operative mortality for open and laparoscopic cholecystectomy in Maryland showed a 33% reduction in overall mortality but no decrease in total deaths due to increased cholecystectomy rates.
• Healthcare providers must improve results by reducing mortality, morbidity, and costs through database analysis and modification of preoperative evaluation, surgery, and postoperative treatment.
• Reducing laparoscopic cholecystectomy charges and conversion rates is necessary to make it cost-effective, with sensitivity analysis suggesting a charge reduction of $12,679.90 for a 5% conversion rate.
</summary>

- The text discusses the importance of oral health in elderly individuals and the high prevalence of oral lesions in this population.
  * Prevalence varies depending on socioeconomic factors, medical history, and geographic location.
  * No previous studies have been conducted in the Indian subcontinent to estimate the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in the elderly.

- The present study aimed to find the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in 5,100 geriatric patients in India.
  * 3,264 patients (64%) presented with various oral lesions.
  * The most common lesions were nicotinic stomatitis (43%) due to tobacco use and denture stomatitis (34%) due to long use of prostheses.

- Oral mucosal lesions are common in older patients and are often associated with oral cancer and precancerous conditions.
  * Prevalence varies widely depending on the study and population.

- Factors contributing to oral mucosal lesions in the elderly include tobacco use, poor denture fit, systemic diseases, and medications.
  * The use of poorly adapted prostheses is a significant risk factor for denture stomatitis and denture hyperplasia.
  * Certain lesions are more commonly seen on specific sites in the oral cavity.

- The increased number of aged individuals necessitates the need for community programs to educate and screen the elderly population for oral mucosal lesions.
  * Knowledge of site predilection for different diseases will aid in identifying the factors responsible for oral mucosal lesions.

</summary>

• Chondroblastoma is a rare bone tumor that affects the epiphyseal regions of tubular bones, especially the ends of tibia, femur, and humerus.
• Chondroblastoma in the head and neck region, including the temporal bone and temporomandibular joint (TMJ), is uncommon but can result in various symptoms such as occlusal abnormalities, trismus, clicking of the TMJ, hearing impairments, dizziness, and otorrhea.
• Malignant changes in chondroblastoma are rare but have been observed after irradiation.
• Diagnosis of chondroblastoma is difficult due to its unusual histological features and the high risk of recurrence with incomplete resection.
• A misdiagnosed case of a 41-year-old male with TMJ disorder and chronic hearing loss was initially diagnosed with otitis media and underwent several unsuccessful treatments.
• The patient's symptoms progressed to include trismus, hearing loss, and dizziness, and a CT scan and pathologic examination revealed the presence of a giant cell tumor in the temporal bone.
• Re-examination of the CT scan and MRI showed the tumor had enlarged and invaded the middle cranial fossa, temporal lobe, and infratemporal fossa.
• Histopathologic findings confirmed the presence of chondroblastoma with multinucleated giant cells, acidophilic substrate, large cystic areas, hemorrhage, and aneurismal bone cysts.
• Surgical treatment for chondroblastoma in the temporal bone includes a generous postauricular incision, neck dissection, radical mastoidectomy, subtotal resection of the temporal bone, and reconstruction using the sternocleidomastoid and platysma muscles.
</summary>

• The study aimed to evaluate the relationship between sedentary behavior and habitual physical activity with visceral adiposity (vat) and liver fat in adults with overweight/obesity.
• No relationship was observed between objectively measured physical inactivity and raised liver fat. Instead, a weak positive association was found between vat volume and time spent in moderate activity.
• Traditional risk factors such as waist circumference, sex, and age were associated with vat and ihl.
• The inclusion of objectively measured levels of moderate activity and sedentary behavior did not improve the prediction of liver fat concentration or level of visceral adiposity when compared to traditional risk factors.
• Current habitual activity levels are not related to vat or liver fat at an individual level, but population-level epidemiological data suggests physical inactivity is associated with the development of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and visceral adiposity.
• Reducing sedentary behavior, including sitting time, is generally advocated in public health messages, but the relationship between unstructured physical activity and sedentariness and metabolically risky fat depots is unclear.
• Structured exercise programs are effective in reducing vat and ihl, and increasing cardiorespiratory fitness is a characteristic of metabolically healthy obesity.
• Further research is needed to examine the interaction between sedentary behavior, physical activity levels, and metabolically detrimental fat depots across a more diverse population using gold-standard methods.
• The study had limitations, including the recruitment of adults with overweight/obesity who had no known comorbid cardiovascular or metabolic disease, which may have contributed to the limited spread in the data.
• Vigorous activity may be necessary for improvements in the progressive forms of NAFLD, but longitudinal data from clinical trials are lacking.

* Study conducted at a tertiary eye care hospital in North India during Diwali festival from 2011 to 2015
* 53 eyes of 45 patients included, with 30 right and 23 left eyes affected
** Severity of injury greater for those who ignited fireworks themselves
* Five open-globe injuries, 48 closed-globe injuries, six referred for further management
** 18 surgically managed eyes: corneal tear repair, scleral tear repair, cataract extraction, lensectomy, pars plana vitrectomy
* 33.96% (18 eyes) underwent surgical management, 64.15% (34 eyes) managed conservatively, 1.88% (1 eye) advised primary enucleation
** Age distribution: mean age 20.55 years, 39 male patients
* Previous studies show similar findings of male predominance
* Study by John et al. in Tamil Nadu included children, 84 presented, 44% hospitalized, 8% unilateral blindness
* Our hospital is a tertiary eye care center, fewer cases due to specialized focus, urban location, and better awareness
* Serious injuries often unpredictable, most common types are bombs, high-velocity fireworks cause poorer visual outcomes
* Corneal abrasions, corneal foreign body, and hyphema common anterior segment findings, vitreous hemorrhage common posterior segment finding
* Fireworks violate noise and pollution norms, laws inadequate, increased firework sales can lead to increased morbidity
* Public awareness and professional displays encouraged, strong legislation needed to reduce preventable ocular morbidity.

* Subclinical hypothyroidism (sch) is a common disorder characterized by elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with normal free thyroxine (FT4) levels, representing early thyroid failure.
* Controversies surround the definition, clinical significance, and treatment of sch, particularly regarding its association with cardiovascular (CV) disease and mortality.
** Prevalence and causes:
*** Prevalence ranges from 4% to 20% in adults, with women, elderly people, and iodine-sufficient populations being affected more often.
**** Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the most common cause, is associated with anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies and increased risk in girls and women.
**** Poor thyroid hormone supplementation, poor adherence, drug interactions, or inadequate monitoring can also cause sch in patients with overt thyroid failure.
** Clinical implications and controversies:
**** Elevated TSH levels are associated with increased body weight, blood pressure, and altered lipid levels.
**** Sch is linked to metabolic syndrome and increased risks of all-cause mortality and CV disease.
**** The relationship between sch and CV disease and mortality remains controversial, with inconsistent findings from studies.
**** The optimal TSH cutoff values and clinical significance of sch are uncertain, and treatment is typically only considered for pregnant women, infertile individuals, those with symptoms, or those at high risk of progression to overt hypothyroidism.
**** The European Commission has funded a large, multicenter, double-blinded, placebo-controlled randomized trial (TRUST) to assess the clinical outcomes of thyroid hormone replacement in older adults with persistent sch.

  * 39 patients had toxin-positive stool specimens.
  * 14 patients had toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates.
  * 15 patients had both toxin-negative stool specimens and isolates.

  * Despite not receiving CDAD treatment, toxin-negative patients had shorter diarrhea duration.
  * Patients with toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates also had shorter diarrhea duration compared to those with toxin-positive stool specimens.

- The study also found that patients with toxin-negative isolates may have been infected with nontoxigenic C. difficile or had low toxin concentrations in their stool.
  * Primary bile salts and human immunity may contribute to lack of toxin detection in stool specimens.

- The study highlighted the limitations of EIA for toxin detection, including its lower sensitivity compared to PCR and the potential for false negatives.
  * EIA directly measures toxin proteins in stool and has a high positive predictive value.

- The study also discussed the importance of preventing hospital infection from patients with gdh-positive and toxin-negative stool specimens, as they may still carry toxigenic C. difficile.
  * Nucleic acid amplification tests are recommended for diagnosing CDAD but do not evaluate toxin production.

- The Dream Trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled study designed to determine if ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay type 2 diabetes in people with IFG or IGT.
  * 5,269 participants with these disorders were recruited and randomized to either ramipril and/or rosiglitazone using a two-by-two factorial design.
  * Followed for a median of 3 years after randomization.

- The study assessed change in -cell function using two measures: the insulinogenic index (IGI) and proinsulin (PI) concentration.
  * IGI was assessed by dividing it by the homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance index (HOMA-IR).
  * PI was assessed by dividing it by c-peptide concentration or adjusting for insulin secretion using c-peptide as a covariate.

- Rosiglitazone significantly improved -cell function as measured by IGI and reduced PI concentrations over time.
  * Changes were more substantial between baseline and 2-year visits compared with changes between 2-year and final visits.
  * Effects were similar within subgroups of IGT and IFG+IGT, but more modest in those with IIFG.

- The impact of rosiglitazone on diabetes incidence was independent of baseline levels and changes in indexes of -cell function.
  * Adjusting for the change in -cell function using IGI attenuated the preventive effect of rosiglitazone on incident diabetes, but not when using PI.

- Rosiglitazone's effect on diabetes prevention persisted after adjusting for baseline -cell function.
  * The study suggests that measures of change in -cell function in response to therapy are indexes of that therapy's ability to reduce the incidence of diabetes.
  * Some but not all of the effect of rosiglitazone on diabetes prevention/delay is mediated through its effects on -cell function.
</summary>

- The text discusses a study on metabolic interactions between microbial strains and the importance of understanding metabolic cooperation in complex microbial communities.
  * Synthetic mutualism in trans is a type of metabolic interaction between auxotrophic strains that complement each other's growth by cross-feeding essential metabolites.
  * The study used a quantitative and predictive theoretical model to reveal the extent of complex metabolic interactions from the relatively simple topology of the biochemical reaction network.

- The study selected 46 conditionally lethal auxotrophic E. coli strains and co-cultured them in minimal media to observe their growth patterns.
  * The results showed that certain pairs of auxotrophs exhibited synergistic growth, with one strain benefiting from the metabolites produced by the other.
  * The study also found that the efficiency of cooperation, as measured by the ratio of benefit to cost, was more predictive of growth than the benefit or cost alone.

- The study used a combination of experimental and computational methods to analyze the metabolic interactions between the strains.
  * Flux balance analysis was used to model the metabolic networks of the individual strains and the joint system, allowing for the prediction of growth rates and metabolite exchange.
  * The results showed that the joint flux model was effective in reproducing the observed growth patterns and the joint stoichiometric matrix allowed for the exchange of metabolites between strains.
</summary>

• Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome (BSS) is a rare genodermatosis caused by mutations in the tumor suppressor gene cyld (cylindromatosis gene) on chromosome 16q12q13.
• Characterized by the progressive development of adnexal skin tumors in the scalp and face, mainly trichoepitheliomas, cylindromas, and spiradenomas.
• Autosomal dominant inheritance with a low risk of malignancy and long-term follow-up required.
• A 71-year-old woman presented with multiple papules and nodules on her scalp and forehead, diagnosed with spiradenomas and cylindromas.
• Family history of lesions in her mother, mother's brother, and two daughters.
• Exon 8 sequencing revealed a heterozygous mutation c.1628_1629delct in the cyld gene for the patient and her two affected daughters.
• The mutation results in a frameshift and a stop codon, leading to the loss of deubiquitining activity of cyld and tumorigenesis.
• Genetic counseling provided to first-degree relatives, informing them of the 50% probability of developing BSS.
</summary>

<summary>

- Biological scaffolds derived from dermis, pericardium, and small intestine submucosa have been used for soft tissue repair applications due to their rapid revascularization and clearance of bacteria in clean or contaminated settings.
- Dexon and Vicryl, absorbable polymer scaffolds, have been utilized in damage control situations but have limitations such as rapid resorption and loss of mechanical strength.
- Gore Bio-A, Tigr Matrix, and Phasix Mesh are newer absorbable scaffolds that degrade more slowly and have shown promising results in clinical applications.
- Gore Bio-A is a copolymer of poly(glycolide : trimethylene carbonate) that degrades in vivo through both hydrolytic and enzymatic mechanisms and is fully resorbed within approximately 180 days.
- Tigr Matrix is a knitted mesh with two fibers having different resorption rates, and it exhibits collagen deposition and neovascularization at the repair site that increases over time.
- Phasix Mesh is a fully resorbable polymer monofilament knitted into a flat sheet configuration, and it has been evaluated for hernia repair applications using ball burst testing and histological analysis.
- The study found that Phasix Mesh and p4hb plug demonstrated similar burst strengths and relative stiffness at all time points, and both designs had significantly greater burst strength and relative stiffness compared to the native abdominal wall.
- The molecular weight of both Phasix Mesh and p4hb plug decreased significantly over time, but significant material resorption did not correspond with a significant drop in mechanical strength at the repair site.
- Histological analyses revealed no statistically significant changes over time for either Phasix Mesh or p4hb plug with respect to histological parameters, indicating a mild to moderate inflammatory response and presence of granulation tissue and vascularization for both devices at all time points.

</summary>

* The text describes a study evaluating the diagnostic accuracy of the Xpert Vana / Vanb assay for detecting Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococci (VRE) in clinical samples and its impact on infection control decision making.
* The study was conducted in a laboratory serving a population of 800,000 inhabitants in Denmark, using both culture-based and PCR methods for VRE screening.
* Key findings:
	+ The sensitivity of the vana PCR assay was 87.1% (95% CI 82.1-92.2%), specificity was 99.7% (95% CI 99.3-100%), and positive and negative predictive values were 98.0% (95% CI 95.8-100%) and 97.7% (95% CI 96.7-98.6%), respectively.
	+ The specificity and positive predictive value of the vanb part of the assay were low at 77.6% (95% CI 75.1-80.1%) and 0.4% (95% CI 0.00-1.2%), respectively.
	+ The implementation of the Xpert Vana / Vanb assay led to a significant reduction in isolation days (141) and transmission risk days (292) due to faster availability of results.
	+ The study also identified some discordant results between culture and PCR methods, which were further investigated and led to changes in the culture protocol to increase sensitivity.
* Limitations:
	+ The study did not include a systematic analysis of genetically diverse strains to determine the generalizability of the results.
	+ The cost-effectiveness of the Xpert Vana / Vanb assay was not evaluated in detail.

• Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in economically developed nations, with about 30% of all deaths.
• N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (N-3 PUFAs) have beneficial effects on cardiovascular health, including lipid lowering, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, and antiarrhythmic properties.
• Atherosclerosis is a systemic disease characterized by low-grade arterial inflammatory lesions, and chronic inflammation plays a role in its development.
• Endothelial cells synthesize and release nitric oxide and prostaglandins to maintain a balance between pro- and anti-inflammatory molecules, but this balance is disrupted in the presence of atherosclerosis.
• Pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukins 1, 2, and 6 and tumor necrosis factor, induce oxidative stress and further progression of the disease.
• N-3 PUFAs and their eicosanoid derivatives can modulate the inflammatory response and play a significant role in reducing the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
• Linoleic acid, an omega-6 fatty acid, can decrease the conversion of alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) into eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) by competing for the n-6-desaturase enzyme.
• Fish is the primary source of long-chain N-3 PUFAs, while ALA is found in plant sources such as seeds and nuts.
• The GISSI-Prevenzione trial demonstrated that supplementation with 850 mg/day of long-chain N-3 PUFAs decreased the risk of mortality, nonfatal myocardial infarction, and stroke in Italian patients with recent myocardial infarction.
• The JELIS trial showed that supplementation with 1.8 g/day of EPA decreased major coronary events in Japanese men and women with hypercholesterolemia treated with statins.

<summary>
• Rudolf Virchow, a 19th century pathologist, proposed that cancer arises from chronically inflamed cells
• Gastric cancer is linked to chronic inflammation, particularly atrophic gastritis and hypochlorhydria
• Pelayo Correa, a Colombian pathologist, devoted his career to understanding gastric cancer's etiology
• Correa hypothesized a stepwise process from chronic atrophic gastritis to intestinal metaplasia and cancer
• Initial changes occur in the first decade of life, when h pylori colonization occurs
• Correa initially thought environmental factors, such as diet, were responsible for promoting this progression
• In the 1970s, Warren and Marshall discovered h pylori, linking it to gastritis and peptic ulcer disease
• H pylori is now known to increase the risk of gastric cancer, particularly intestinal-type cancers
• Recent research focuses on genetic susceptibility, h pylori heterogeneity, and environmental influences to understand gastric cancer development after h pylori colonization
</summary>

• Study compared functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab and ranibizumab treatment for neovascular age-related macular degeneration in Turkish patients
• Both groups had significant improvements in mean bcva and crt compared to baseline at every time point
• No statistically significant difference in change in bcva or crt between the two groups at any time point
• Similar injection numbers and complications in both groups
• Previous studies have shown similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes for bevacizumab and ranibizumab

• Landa et al. study: similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes one month after injection, no difference in safety
• Feng et al. study: similar visual acuity changes and stability in visual acuity after 12 months, similar injection numbers
• Bellerive et al. study: greater mean visual acuity improvement in ranibizumab group, similar visual and anatomical outcomes

• CATT study: no significant difference in visual acuity and anatomical outcomes and injection numbers at first year, equivalent visual acuity gains at month 12, significant decrease in crt for both groups, greater mean gain in visual acuity for monthly groups at 2 years, similar safety profiles but ongoing debate
</summary>

- Preeclampsia (PE) is a leading cause of maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality, affecting 25% of pregnancies.
- Proteinuria is a common symptom of PE, but several studies suggest it's not a significant predictor of adverse outcomes.
- Hypoalbuminemia, caused by systemic small vessel spasm and damaged vascular endothelial cells, may indicate the severity of PE.
- Intravascular dehydration due to hypoalbuminemia can accelerate the appearance of intravascular lesions, leading to complications like HELLP syndrome and acute fatty liver of pregnancy.
- In a retrospective cohort study, 299 women with PE were evaluated based on albumin levels (25 g/l and < 25 g/l).
- Women with severe hypoproteinemia (shp) had higher rates of cesarean sections, severe hypertension, abnormal liver or renal function, ascites, and abruptio placenta than those with mild hypoproteinemia (mhp).
- Neonates of women with shp had worse short-term outcomes, including lower birth weight, higher rates of fetal growth restriction, neonatal intensive care unit admission, and preterm deliveries.
- A univariate logistic regression analysis showed that shp was a significant risk factor for cesarean sections, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes in PE women.

</summary>

  * Exclusion criteria included kidney diseases, preexisting proteinuria, essential hypertension, other chronic conditions, and twin pregnancies.

• Avastin (bevacizumab), a humanized monoclonal antibody targeting vegf-a, has been successful in treating colorectal, lung, and renal cell carcinomas.
• Resistance to avastin and the role of other growth factors in sustaining tumor angiogenesis have highlighted the need for alternative targets.
• Vegf-c and vegf-d, ligands for vegfr-2, are potential alternatives to vegf-a for vegfr-2 binding and could promote tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis.
• Other mechanisms, such as pigf, vascular mimicry, and altered tumor metabolism, may contribute to resistance to anti-angiogenic treatments.
• Further studies are required to fully understand the complex network of signaling cascades and identify effective targets for inhibiting angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis in cancer.
</summary>

• Vegf-c and Vegf-d:
  • Highly related polypeptides that require post-translational cleavage to generate mature forms with enhanced binding affinities for vegfr-2 and vegfr-3.
  • Vegf-c is expressed in a range of human cancers and promotes tumor angiogenesis, lymphangiogenesis, and metastatic spread.
  • Vegf-d is expressed in human cancers and has been associated with poor patient outcome in some tumor types.
  • Animal models have demonstrated that vegf-d can promote tumor angiogenesis, lymphangiogenesis, solid tumor growth, and metastasis.
  • Opportunities for targeting vegf-d signaling in cancer include mAbs specific to the vhd of vegf-d, ptk inhibitors, and soluble vegfr-3.

• Other signaling pathways:

<summary>
• Malaria is still a significant public health concern in Iran, particularly in the south and southeast regions.
• The implementation of control measures has led to a reduction in malaria incidence from 11,460 cases in 2008 to 3,239 in 2011.
• In Iran, Plasmodium vivax is the most common species, accounting for 90% of cases, while Plasmodium falciparum accounts for 10%.
• Iran entered the malaria pre-elimination program in 2009 and has implemented prevention strategies, active case detection, and timely treatment.
• Active surveillance using precise laboratory methods is crucial for early recognition of all infections, particularly asymptomatic ones.
• Light microscopy of Giemsa-stained thick and thin blood smears is the standard method for malaria diagnosis, but it has limitations.
• A study was conducted in a low transmission region of Bagh-e Malek in Minab District, Hormozgan Province, to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections using microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR.
</summary>
• Study was a cross-sectional survey in Bagh-e Malek, a lowland area in Hormozgan Province with a population of 1,451 people and a higher rate of malaria transmission.
• Thin and thick blood smears were prepared from all participants and examined by microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR for parasite detection.
• No parasites were detected by microscopy or RDT for any of the 200 healthy volunteers.
• Three P. vivax infections were detected by nested-PCR in asymptomatic individuals, highlighting the importance of molecular methods for detecting hidden parasites.
• Nested-PCR is more sensitive than microscopy and RDT for detecting low-level parasitemia and is particularly useful in elimination programs.
• Toward eliminating malaria from Iran, all three types of malaria detection tools should be used to improve sensitivity, specificity, and reliability for active case surveillance in endemic settings.

* The text discusses the use of machine learning algorithms, specifically Bayesian belief networks (BBNs), to identify promising biomarkers for immune response to vaccine therapies in complex data sets.
* The study involved sera samples collected from patients in three separate clinical trials, including those treated with androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), a viral vaccine (Psav), and a plasmid DNA vaccine (Papv).
* Igg responses to individual antigens were detected and associated with specific treatments, suggesting that the generation of immune responses to off-target antigens might be associated with other measures of immune response or clinical outcome.
* The findings indicate that immune-active therapies, including ADT, elicit igg responses to individual prostate-associated antigens, and that these responses are most obvious many months after treatment. The recognition of different antigens suggests different mechanisms of antigen spread or recognition of other tissue-derived antigens. The use of ml-BBN modeling was found to be feasible for identifying biomarker cohorts in complex data sets.

• The study explores the use of piezoelectric materials and the converse piezoelectric effect to mechanically stimulate bone growth using polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) films.
• The study found that piezoelectric stimulation led to increased bone formation and higher mineral apposition rates compared to static controls.
• The results suggest that piezoelectric materials are effective in stimulating bone growth, but further research is needed to improve biocompatibility and test with longer implantation times.

• Experimental procedures:
    • In vivo study using PVDF films as a substrate for mc3t3 cells.
    • Coating with acrylic (PMMA) and bone-like particles.
    • Actuator device with microcontroller, lithium battery, and six PVDF actuators.
    • Stimulation with alternating sinusoidal current (AC) of 5V, 1Hz and 3Hz for 15 minutes at each frequency.

• Results:
    • Higher bone displacement in central area of coated devices.
    • Increased total bone area and immature bone area around actuators compared to static controls.
    • Significantly higher mineral apposition rate around actuated devices (4.44 m/day) compared to static devices (2.70 m/day).
    • No significant differences in fibrous capsule thickness between actuators and static controls.
    • Marked elevation in osteopontin (OPN) expression around actuators.
</summary>

• Study conducted in oral medicine and radiology department and cancer center with a total sample of 90 individuals
  • Divided into a study group of 60 oral cancer patients and a control group of 30 healthy individuals

• Serum l-fucose levels were estimated using a clinical chemistry autoanalyzer
  • Independent samples t-test used to compare mean values between genders
  • One-way anova used to compare mean values between three or more groups (stages of cancer)

• Mean serum l-fucose level in oral cancer patients was 10.85 mg/dl, significantly higher than 3.47 mg/dl in healthy controls (p<0.001)
  • Serum l-fucose levels increased progressively with cancer stages: 8.13 mg/dl (stage I), 9.18 mg/dl (stage II), 10.53 mg/dl (stage III), and 11.59 mg/dl (stage IV)
  • No significant correlation between serum l-fucose levels and histopathological grading or age and gender

• Fucose is a monosaccharide and essential sugar involved in cell-to-cell communication and signaling pathways
  • Increased fucosylation is associated with cancer and poor prognosis
  • Fucosylation of glycoproteins plays a role in tumor progression, especially in terminal epitopes of glycoproteins
  • Elevated fucosylation contributes to decreased adhesion and uncontrolled tumor growth

• Serum l-fucose levels can be used as a noninvasive, cost-effective biochemical indicator for cancer detection, staging, therapeutic success, and prognosis
  • Further investigation is needed to confirm serum l-fucose as an effective tumor marker in oral cancer diagnosis and management
</summary>

- LCN2 mice were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells and exhibited larger adipose cells compared to wild-type mice.
- LCN2 mice on an hfd had higher body weight, white and brown fat pad weight, and organ weight compared to wild-type mice.
- LCN2 mice were more insulin resistant and glucose intolerant than wild-type mice, as shown by increased insulin-stimulated glucose disposal and glucose clearance.
- LCN2 mice had reduced expression of genes involved in lipid metabolism and adipokines in primary adipose cells.
- LCN2 mice had increased hepatic glucose production due to higher expression of key gluconeogenic enzymes pepck and g6pase.
- LCN2 mice had increased liver triglyceride content and blood lipid profiles, suggesting the development of fatty liver and dyslipidemia.
- LCN2 mice were cold intolerant and had decreased thermogenic activity in brown adipose tissue due to reduced expression of mitochondrial genes involved in mitochondrial biogenesis and oxidative function.
- LCN2 mice had increased expression of proinflammatory cytokines and decreased expression of anti-inflammatory markers in adipose tissue and liver, suggesting an increased inflammatory state.
- LCN2 mice had decreased insulin sensitivity, as shown by reduced insulin-stimulated Akt phosphorylation in liver, muscle, and adipose cells.
- The mechanisms by which LCN2 regulates mitochondrial function and lipid metabolism are not fully understood and require further investigation.

</summary>

- The study aimed to investigate the effect of weight bearing on the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head in rats.
  * Animals were given LPS and methylprednisolone to induce osteonecrosis.
  * Hindlimb unloading was performed to prevent weight bearing.

- Osteonecrosis was observed in both weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing rats, with similar incidence rates.
  * Empty lacunae and bone marrow cell necrosis were present in both groups.
  * The number of hematopoietic cells was decreased, and necrotic cell debris was accumulated in the medullary space in non-weight-bearing rats.

- Weight bearing did not contribute to the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis in rats.
  * Quadruped animals, which fail to progress to end-stage mechanical collapse like humans, were used to clarify the pathogenesis of osteonecrosis.
  * The results suggest that the rat model may help elucidate the pathogenesis of osteonecrosis and devise prevention strategies, but may not be useful for observing the mechanism of femoral head collapse.
</summary>

<summary>
• Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of inherited disorders caused by inactivating mutations in the 21-hydroxylase gene, leading to a deficiency in cortisol and aldosterone secretion.
• The most frequent variant is 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD), which causes hyperplasia of the adrenal gland and diversion of cortisol and aldosterone precursors to androgens.
• CAH patients may present with different clinical forms: classical CAH (salt-wasting and simple virilizing forms), and non-classical CAH (asymptomatic or with postnatal or adult onset hyperandrogenism).
• Neurological abnormalities, including white matter changes and temporal lobe structures dysgenesis, have been reported in CAH patients due to hormonal imbalances during early development and exposure to excess exogenous glucocorticoids.

• White matter changes:
  • Increased signal intensity on intermediate and T2-weighted sequences.
  • Periventricular regions or cerebellar white matter involvement.
  • Subclinical or unremarkable neurological signs.
  • Controversial clinical significance.
  • Possible mechanisms: hormonal imbalance, exogenous glucocorticoids, chronic hyperandrogenism, aldosterone deficiency, and ischemia.

• Temporal lobe structures dysgenesis:
  • Hippocampal dysplasia (distorted anatomy, small volume, disturbed internal architecture, and increased signal on T2 and FLAR images).
  • Amygdalar dysplasia (smaller than contralateral side or increased signal on T2 and FLAR sequences).
</summary>

<summary>
• The human genome draft sequence holds great promise for biomedical advances this century.
• Biologists need to navigate the vast genomic data using universal vocabularies for gene annotation.
• Two main ways of annotating genes: empirical observations (experimentally characterized genes) and predicted evolutionary relationships (homology).
• Homology-based annotation:
  • Homologs: genes derived from a common ancestor, with paralogs being additional copies within a genome and orthologs being corresponding genes in different species.
  • Homologous gene products have similar tertiary structures and functions.
  • Homology is an approximate direction for future empirical determination of function.
• Empirical observations-based annotation:
  • Limited to a minority of human genes.
  • Websites like LocusLink, Genecards, Ensembl, and UniProt integrate diverse sources of information for individual genes.
• Comparative proteomics:
  • Deconvolution of human proteins into constituent domains has led to understanding the evolution of chordates.
  • Comparisons of human domain families with those of other organisms reveal significant differences.
• Challenges in gene annotation:
  • Identifying sequence-similar, homologous portions of genes embedded in otherwise non-homologous contexts.
  • Automatic annotation of proteomes using domains is a short-term measure until high-throughput studies on closely related organisms provide more detailed predictions.
</summary>

- In the 1960s, McCulloch and Till proposed three functional characteristics for defining stem cells: self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency.
  * Self-renewal: ability to make identical copies of themselves.
  * Proliferation: ability to divide and produce new cells.
  * Multipotency: ability to differentiate into various cell types.
- Stem cells have been identified in the lung, primarily through their role in airway repair.
  * Tracheal basal cells expressing keratin-5 (k5) and keratin-14 (k14) have been identified as stem cell niches in proximal airways.
  * Clara cells in middle airways are considered facultative progenitor cells due to their ability to proliferate and differentiate into various cell types.
- Lung cancer may arise from deregulation of stem cell-based repair mechanisms.
- Stem cells in the bronchoalveolar duct junction (BADJ) are pluripotent and can yield diverse populations of cells in response to injury.
  * Cells expressing surfactant protein C (SP-C), stem cell antigen-1 (Sca-1), and CD34 but not CD45 or PECAM are considered pluripotent.
  * ID2 is also proposed as a suitable marker for distal lung epithelial stem cells.
- Lung adenocarcinoma and bronchioloalveolar carcinoma are common carcinomas associated with stem cells from the BADJ region.
- The hierarchical or cancer stem cell hypothesis suggests that relatively rare, multipotent cells gain unlimited proliferative potential and drive tumor growth.
  * Stem-like cells, with the ability to rapidly proliferate into phenotypically diverse progeny, could act as cancer stem cells.
  * Stem cells express high levels of anti-apoptotic and drug-resistant proteins, which may explain chemotherapy resistance.
- Recent studies have identified tumor cell subpopulations with stem-like properties, such as multidrug resistance, increased telomerase expression, and self-renewal.

• Study evaluates the role of urethral plate characters (shape and width) in the success of tip urethroplasty for primary anterior penile hypospadias in 100 children.
• Divided study population into two groups based on urethral plate width (>8 mm and <8 mm) and three groups based on plate character (flat, cleft, and deeply grooved).
• Group B patients with urethral plate < 8 mm had significantly higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration compared to group A patients with wider plates (p = 0.004 and p = 0.01, respectively).
• Narrow plates (<8 mm) are inadequate for creating neourethra, leading to higher fistula rates due to increased tension on the suture line during tubularization.
</summary>

• Technique: Tip urethroplasty using Snodgrass technique with modifications
• Patients: 100 children with primary anterior penile hypospadias
• Location: Mayo Hospital, Hodeidah, Yemen
• Surgical procedure: Urethral plate tubularization around 6 or 8 French (fr) Nelaton catheter using polyglycolic acid 6/0 subcuticular running suture
• Postoperative management: Ampicillin/gentamycin weight-adjusted dose, oxybutynin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

<summary>
• Findings:
• Group B patients with narrow plates (<8 mm) had higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration.
• Narrow plates make anastomoses under tension, increasing the incidence of fistula formation during tubularization.
• Modification to midline incision of the plate by extending it beyond the tip of the glans prevents meatal stenosis but only decreases fistula rate and meatal stenosis to <1%.
• Urethral plate augmentation with buccal mucosal graft (BMG) is recommended for narrow and inelastic plates.
</summary>

• Complications:
• Fistula: 8% of patients developed fistula.

* The study aimed to develop a prototype to measure the bracket debonding force in vivo using a strain gauge connected directly to the pliers' claw.
* The prototype consisted of a modified plier, a measurement and control circuit, and a specific software to record the debonding force.
* The prototype was calibrated using weights and showed accurate and precise results, with no significant differences between two examiners.
* The mean bond strength obtained with the prototype and the universal testing machine were statistically similar, suggesting the prototype's reliability as a tool for measuring bond strength in vivo.

* Modified plier: the original plier was cut to receive an intermediate part and a strain gauge was connected to the claw.
* Measurement and control circuit: the electronic circuit reads the strain gauge and converts the obtained value into an 8-bit binary number.
* Specific software: the software records the debonding force and has a calibration system.
* Calibration: the prototype was calibrated with weights ranging from 0.5 kg to 6 kg, and a simple linear regression analysis was applied to adjust the data.
* Accuracy and precision: the prototype was tested with weights, and the measurements were taken by two examiners who did not standardize their hand position on the pliers.
* No significant differences were found between the examiners, indicating that the prototype was not influenced by the way it was held.
* In vitro testing: the bond strength obtained with the prototype and the universal testing machine were compared to evaluate the prototype's reliability.
* The tensile test on the universal testing machine reproduced the same conditions as debonding with the prototype, and the bond strength did not differ statistically between the two methods.

<summary>

- Trichomonas vaginalis (TV) infection is a common curable sexually transmitted infection with approximately 173 million new cases annually.
- It is associated with adverse reproductive health outcomes, including pelvic inflammatory disease, low infant birth weight, and premature delivery.
- TV infection increases the transmission and acquisition of other sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV.
- The frequency of TV infection is not monitored in most countries, and there are no control programs.
- In Peru, diagnostic testing for TV is not included in STI guidelines, and syndromic management is the standard.
- Socially marginalized women, who defy Peruvian social norms by having sex with poor unemployed men, are at higher risk for TV infection.
- Older women, those with less education, singles, and women reporting unprotected sex with nonsteady partners or multiple sex partners are more likely to have TV infection.

* Prevalence:
  * Highest prevalence in oldest age group (36-40 years).
  * Three times more likely in women who did not complete high school.
  * No association with vaginal symptoms.

* Risk factors:
  * Older women: long-term prevalent infection.
  * Syndromic management may result in over and under treatment.
  * Asymptomatic nature contributes to long duration and continued spread.
</summary>

* Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS) is a childhood epilepsy characterized by tonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures, slow spike wave discharges on EEG, and cognitive impairment.
	+ Seizure types: tonic, atonic, atypical absence, myoclonic, generalized tonic-clonic, and partial seizures.
	+ Interictal EEG pattern: slow spike wave discharges (<3 Hz) with generalized distribution and paroxysms of low voltage fast activity at about 10 Hz during sleep.
	+ Cognitive impairment: moderate to severe mental retardation and behavioral disorders including aggression and autistic features.
* Treatment:
	+ Valproic acid is the most commonly used first-line medication for drop attacks, atypical absences, and myoclonic seizures in LGS.
	+ Rufinamide, a triazole derivative, is an orphan drug granted for the adjunctive treatment of LGS and has a wide spectrum of anticonvulsant effectiveness.
		- Mechanism of action: decreased firing of high frequency sodium-dependent action potentials and prolongation of sodium channel inactivation.
		- Effective in maximal electroshock and subcutaneous pentylenetetrazol models.
		- Has a good safety profile in animals and humans, with minimal cognitive side effects and behavioral toxicity.
		- Well absorbed (85% after an oral dose), with a slow absorption rate and low protein binding.
		- Eliminated primarily via metabolism, with a carboxylic acid derivative as the principal metabolite.
	+ Careful elucidation of drug-drug interactions is necessary in conditions like LGS, where polypharmacy is common.
	+ Valproic acid therapy should be introduced cautiously in children already on rufinamide due to decreased rufinamide clearance.
	+ A larger number of patients must be treated with rufinamide to establish its role in the treatment armamentarium for LGS.
	+ The role of rufinamide in relationship to prior drugs with reported effectiveness in LGS needs to be further defined

• The study explores the role of chemical sexual signals in interpopulational recognition between five distinct populations of iberian wall lizards in central Spain.
• The findings suggest that males and females can recognize and discriminate between scents of individuals from northern and southern populations, and have a greater interest for scents of lizards from their own area.
• Males from some populations discriminate and prefer scents of females from their own population, which may indicate a cryptic speciation process.
• Females also discriminate male chemicals between areas (north versus south), but not between populations.
• The results support that reproductive isolation between all populations is not entirely clear, but that at least between some populations, there could be reproductive isolation and cryptic speciation.

• The scientific activity of researchers is validated through published papers in peer-reviewed journals
• Medline/PubMed, Web of Science, Embase, and Current Contents are major international databases for health sciences research
• Medline/PubMed is the most often searched database, offering free access and over 5,100 titles
• Controlled vocabulary like Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) helps researchers retrieve information more precisely
• Small details, such as non-standardized author and institution names, make it difficult to find articles and evaluate institutions
• Journals' impact factors (IFs) reflect their influence on the scientific field and are used to evaluate institutions
• Few Brazilian journals have high IFs, but their number has increased from 23 in 2006 to 30 in 2007
• A study analyzed the scientific production of full professors at Universidade de São Paulo's Faculdade de Medicina (fmusp) from 2001 to 2006
• The study found 1,960 published articles by 66 full professors, representing 0.04% of worldwide publications, 2.4% of national publications, and 12.33% of fmusp's total publications during the period

</summary>

• The study focused on full professors as they are representative of other professors and have a high level of scientific maturity
• Of the 1,960 articles, 68.7% were published in international journals, and 31.3% in Brazilian journals
• The use of English language in Brazilian journals has led to better visibility and accessibility of research results
• Only 4 of the 24 Brazilian journals with IFs were represented in the study, accounting for 17.39% of total Brazilian journals with IFs
• The average publication rate for full professors was five articles per year, with 89% of articles published in international journals with IFs
• The analysis should consider specific research areas and types of publications when evaluating IFs

<summary>
• According to WHO experts, if rubella infection occurs during early pregnancy, the risk of passing the virus to the fetus is about 90%.
• Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is the most significant complication of rubella, which affects approximately 110,000 infants each year in developing countries.
• Rubella vaccination aims to prevent congenital infection with rubella virus and CRS.
• The most commonly used vaccine globally is the ra27/3 virus strain, which induces immunity in 95% of vaccinated persons.
• Mass rubella vaccination in Iran in 2003 resulted in a significant increase in immunity against rubella, from 79.6% to 99.3%.

• Before vaccination, the immunity rate in Iran was 73.4%, which rose to 98.8% after vaccination in a study of 1217 serum samples.
• In Mashhad, the immunity rate before and after vaccination was 70.38% and 98.5%, respectively.
• In Hamadan, the level of anti-rubella antibody in girls at marriage increased from 83.5% to 98.4%.
• The effectiveness of the ra27/3 vaccine is demonstrated by the elimination of rubella and CRS from the western hemisphere and high vaccination coverage in European countries.
• Studies on rubella seroepidemiology led to the announcement of the rubella vaccine as a compulsory state vaccine, and similar studies are proposed for other vaccines like tetanus and diphtheria.
• Due to the susceptibility of less than 1% of the population, screening for rubella antibodies in vaccinated individuals is no longer necessary, but studies should be performed every few years.
</summary>

<summary>
• Whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) using quantum dots (QDs) in xenopus embryos allows for nonamplified, high-resolution detection of endogenous mRNAs.
• QDs have ideal optical properties for use in biology, including strong fluorescent signal emission, resistance to photobleaching, and narrow and tunable emission spectra.
• Penetration of QDs into xenopus embryos is a limitation, but proteinase K treatment increases permeability and enables specific deep tissue staining.
• QD detection of multiple mRNAs was successful, including xbra, edd, myod, amylase, xa-1, cardiac actin, and ltbp1, with high signal intensity and resolution.
• Simultaneous detection of multiple transcripts using spectrally distinguishable anti-FITC-conjugated and streptavidin-conjugated QDs was demonstrated, enabling intracellular mRNA localization with high resolution.
</summary>

• Ideal optical properties of QDs:
  • Strong fluorescent signal emission
  • Resistance to photobleaching
  • Narrow and tunable emission spectra
  • Reduced spectral overlap

• Penetration of QDs into xenopus embryos:
  • Proteinase K treatment increases permeability
  • Enables specific deep tissue staining
  • Best results obtained with newly opened qd-streptavidin conjugates
  • Performance diminishes if stored for more than two-three months

• Successful detection of multiple mRNAs:
  • Similar staining patterns obtained using qds and chromogenic reaction
  • High signal to noise ratio and excellent contrast in highly autofluorescent organ
  • Degree of resolution varies with transcript of interest and expression pattern

• Simultaneous detection of multiple transcripts:
  • Successful visualization of xa-1 and xenopus cardiac actin using spectrally distinguishable anti-FITC-conjugated and streptavidin-conjugated QDs
  • Enables intracellular mRNA localization with high resolution

* Pancreatic cancer is a deadly disease with low survival rates and is classified into subtypes, with the majority being pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC)
* Demographic and clinical factors, such as age, gender, marital status, tumor size, nodal status, and distant metastases, significantly impact the survival of PDAC patients
* Surgical resection is the most effective treatment for PDAC, but only 20% of patients are suitable candidates. The combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy can improve survival.
	+ Cox proportional hazards regression models were used to estimate the impact of risk factors on PDAC survival
	+ Nomograms were developed to estimate survival and perioperative mortality for patients undergoing pancreatectomy
	+ A web-based, real-time prognostic tool was developed to estimate survival and conditional survival probabilities for PDAC patients using demographic, clinical, and treatment data.
	+ The reliability and generalizability of the models were assessed by calibration and discrimination abilities, as well as cross-validation and validation on external datasets.
	+ The models were found to be well-calibrated and had good discrimination, with c-indexes of 0.702 and 0.712 for localized and extended PDAC, respectively.
	+ The models were reproducible and generalizable to different geographical areas, with averaged cross-validated c-indexes of 0.700 and 0.711 for localized and extended PDAC, respectively.

• Study recruited Japanese patients with chronic ischemic limb disease (CLI) who underwent percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) in Kansai Rosai Hospital, Hyogo, Japan, between 2003 and 2009.
• Diabetic patients had a higher prevalence of Fontaine stage IV and hemodialysis than those without diabetes.
• PTA was the first-choice procedure for revascularization, and the indication for PTA was determined by consensus among vascular specialists.
• Major amputation was indicated when revascularization failed to relieve patients from rest pain or control their foot lesions.
• The leading cause of death was cardiac and vascular disease, and diabetic patients had a higher rate of major amputation compared with nondiabetic patients.
• Mortality was associated with age, impaired activities of daily living (ADLs), hemodialysis, and serum albumin level.
• A1c level was independently associated with major amputation in diabetic patients, and the risk increased with each quartile of A1c level.
• The presence of diabetes with poor glycemic control, infection, and hemodialysis was significantly associated with major amputation.
• The limb prognosis depends on peripheral blood flow after, rather than before, revascularization.
• Serum albumin level was used as a nutritional marker in the study, and malnutrition was confirmed to be associated with mortality using other nutrition-related markers.
</summary>

<summary>
• Human cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a parasitic zoonosis caused by Echinococcus granulosus and is common in areas with close contact between intermediate and definitive hosts, usually sheep and dogs.
• CE in humans presents with symptoms related to fluid-filled cysts in the liver, lungs, or other viscera and is diagnosed through radiology and serology.
• Postsurgical relapses or treatment failure can occur due to nonradical surgical procedures or perisurgical spillage of parasite material, especially protoscoleces.
• Immunodiagnostic tools are needed to meet the requirements of clinicians for the post-operative control of hydatidosis.
• Western blotting is a promising approach for the diagnosis and post-operative follow-up of CE patients due to its high specificity.
• The study examined the pattern of antigenic bands essential for the serologic diagnosis of CE and reported on the post-operative evolution of patients treated for this disease. The diagnostic performance of western blot was also determined.
</summary>
• Study involved 50 CE patients, 40 non-CE patients, and 20 healthy controls
• Pre-treatment samples were obtained and patients received standard antihelminthic treatment and surgical procedures
• Hydatid cyst fluid antigen was prepared and subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotting
• IgG reactivity with antigenic fractions was compared between pre-operative and post-operative samples
• The antigenic fractions of 52, 24, 39, 46, 63, and 6061 kDa were specific for hydatid disease and had higher diagnostic value
• The 39 kDa band reactivity decreased significantly in post-operative samples, but 24 and 39 kDa persisted in two patients who had relapses at two-year follow-up.
• Western blotting is a useful method for diagnosing hydatidosis and for post-surgical monitoring, as it can detect the appearance or disappearance of specific bands that other techniques cannot.
• Antibodies against proteins of 24 and 39 kDa are a good marker

• Study aimed to examine relationship between obesity parameters and serum lipid levels in obese non-diabetic patients
• Patients were divided into three groups based on BMI: class I (30.0-34.9 kg/m²), class II (35.0-39.9 kg/m²), and class III (≥40 kg/m²)
• Whole study population consisted of 66 patients with mean age of 55.8 years, 40 women, and 26 men
• Dyslipidemia was the most common lipid disorder, present in 90.9% of the study population
• Key findings:

   • Negative correlations between BMI, waist circumference (WC), and HDL-C; positive correlations between WC, waist-to-height ratio (WHTR), and TG/HDL-C ratio

• The text discusses a study on the prevalence of internet addiction and its association with psychopathology among college students in Mumbai, India.
• Key findings include:
  • Prevalence of internet addiction was studied using Young's Internet Addiction Test (IAT).
  • Females were more likely to use the internet than males, and most users accessed it for social networking, academic purposes, and entertainment.
  • Addicts were more likely to use the internet in the evenings and nights, and a significant number of them worked part-time.
  • Addicts had poor mental, physical, and mental health scores, as well as high anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores.
• The text also discusses the debate on whether internet addiction should be considered a distinct disorder or a behavioral problem secondary to another disorder.
• Future research could focus on formulating interventions to set boundaries and detect early warning signs of underlying psychopathology.
</summary>

• Study on internet addiction and psychopathology among college students in Mumbai, India
• Key findings:
  • Prevalence: Used Young's Internet Addiction Test (IAT)
  • Demographics: Females used internet more, accessed it for social networking, academic purposes, and entertainment
  • Usage patterns: Addicts used it more in evenings and nights, many worked part-time
  • Health outcomes: Poor mental, physical, and mental health scores; high anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores
• Debate on internet addiction as a distinct disorder or behavioral problem secondary to another disorder
• Future research: Formulating interventions to set boundaries and detect early warning signs of underlying psychopathology

• Device electrostatically actuated, driving voltage applied to side gate
• Parasitic signals reduced by setting drive signal to half actuation frequency

• Allan deviation measured in open-loop configuration, frequency stability extracted from resonator at resonance frequency
• Phase transformed into frequency fluctuations using resonator's phase response

• Two frequency sample arrays obtained with integration time 0
• Correlation of frequency traces versus integration time plotted in figure 4b
• Band-pass filter used for consistent correspondence between allan deviation and correlation integration times
• Correlation coefficient defined as equation (4) using sample means and standard deviations

<summary>
• The text discusses a study evaluating patient use of aspirin and reported physician recommendations for aspirin therapy for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention in a nationally representative sample using the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for the years 2011-2012.
• Key findings include:
  - Among primary prevention patients, less than a third reported being recommended by their doctor to take aspirin, and over three-quarters were classified as low risk.
  - Of those told to take aspirin by their physicians, the vast majority complied with the recommendation.
  - Among low-risk diabetes patients, 54.6% were told to take aspirin, compared to 72.8% of intermediate-risk and 56.2% of high-risk diabetes patients.
  - Education level, insurance status, and having a regular source of care were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin for primary prevention.
• Limitations of the study include:
  - The study did not account for use of warfarin or other anticoagulant/antiplatelet therapy among respondents.
  - The study did not control for the role of gastrointestinal bleeding risk in the decision of physicians to recommend aspirin.
</summary>
• The study found that among primary prevention patients, less than a third reported being recommended by their doctor to take aspirin, and over three-quarters were classified as low risk.
• Sub-points:
    - Of those told to take aspirin by their physicians, the vast majority complied with the recommendation.
    - Education level, insurance status, and having a regular source of care were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin for primary prevention.
• The study also found that among low-risk diabetes patients, 54.6% were told to take aspirin, compared to 72.8% of intermediate-risk and 56.2% of high-risk diabetes patients.
• Sub-points:
    - Among primary prevention patients, a greater percentage of nonhispanic whites had health insurance compared with other racial/ethnic groups.
    - The ability to access preventive medical care is influenced by insurance status, which may contribute to racial/ethnic disparities in primary prevention.

<summary>

- Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) during oxidative metabolism, which can regulate signaling through oxidation of protein cysteine residues.
  * ROS is converted to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) by cellular superoxide dismutases.
  * Oxidation of cysteine thiol groups by H2O2 forms sulphenic acid, disulfide bonds, or sulfenyl amide bonds, changing protein function.
- Mitochondrial ROS (mROS) generation is required for epidermal homeostasis and stem cell differentiation.
  * mROS promotes signaling through pathways such as Notch and Wnt-β-catenin, which regulate epidermal differentiation and hair growth.
  * mROS acts as pro-differentiation signals and are key upstream regulators of stem cell fate decisions.
- Mitochondrial metabolism promotes cellular differentiation through various mechanisms.
  * mROS production is required for activation of Notch and Wnt-β-catenin transcriptional programs.
  * Mitochondrial metabolism provides substrates for histone acetyltransferases and histone demethylases, regulating chromatin structure and gene expression.
- Aberrant keratinocyte metabolism may be associated with epidermal diseases and presents targets for treatment.
  * Ucp2, a mitochondrial uncoupling protein, may act as a metabolic switch controlling stem cell differentiation.
  * The mechanisms by which mitochondrial metabolism regulates differentiation and the role of calcium signaling in epidermal differentiation are ongoing areas of research.

</summary>

<summary>

- The text describes a study establishing an in situ hybridization (ISH) technique using a locked nucleic acid (LNA) probe and biotin-free tyramide amplification system (CSAI) for detecting hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) liver tissue sections.
  * Positive controls were taken from humanized liver of HCV-infected chimeric mice.
  * Thirteen humanized liver specimens from HCV-infected chimeric mice and eleven needle biopsy liver specimens of chronic hepatitis C were used.
- The ISH technique involved several steps, including quenching endogenous peroxidase activity, proteinase K digestion, heat treatment, hybridization with LNA probe, and signal amplification using tyramide.
  * Sections were quenched with hydrogen peroxide, rinsed with diethyl pyrocarbonate-treated water, and digested with proteinase K.
  * Sections were then heat-treated, hybridized with LNA probe overnight, and rinsed with saline sodium citrate and Tris-buffered saline.
  * Signals were amplified using fluorescein-isothiocyanate-conjugated tyramide and horseradish peroxidase-labeled anti-FITC antibody.
- The specificity of the ISH technique was verified by treating consecutive sections with DNase and RNase before hybridization with the LNA probe.
- In humanized liver sections of HCV-infected chimeric mice, ISH demonstrated diffuse cytoplasmic signals in human hepatocytes, while mouse hepatocytes showed no reactivity.
  * HCV RNA was detected in human ck8/18-positive chimeric hepatocytes from chimeric mice infected with HCV genotypes 1a, 1b, and 2a.
  * Positive signals remained after DNase treatment but were abolished after RNase treatment.
- The study also investigated the correlation between HCV RNA levels in serum and ISH results in chronic hepatitis C patients.

* The text discusses the use of amphibian metamorphosis as a model for testing thyroid disruption caused by chemicals
* Key points:
  * Amphibians are particularly susceptible to thyroid disruption due to their permeable skin and exposure to contaminated water
  * Thyroid hormones play a crucial role in metamorphosis, making it an effective model for detecting thyroid disruption

  ** Thyroid hormones (THs) are synthesized and secreted in a similar manner in amphibians and mammals
  ** THs are transported through the blood bound to transport proteins, primarily transthyretin (TTR)

  * Several processes influence TH balance, including sulfation, deiodination, and glucuronidation
  * Environmental contaminants can disrupt TH metabolism by interfering with these processes

  ** Inhibition of thyroidal iodide uptake and suppression of thyroidal peroxidase activity can disrupt TH synthesis and secretion
  ** Induction of hepatic microsomal enzymes and competitive binding to TTR can also affect TH levels

  * Thyroid histopathology is a valuable indicator of thyroid toxicants
  * Histological examination of the amphibian thyroid gland is a sensitive approach for detecting thyroid disruption

  ** Histopathological changes include increased follicular cell hyperplasia and hypertrophy, as well as depletion of colloid stores
  ** Difficulty in distinguishing histological changes due to alterations of the HPT axis or advanced stages in tadpoles

  * Guidelines for testing thyroid disruption in amphibians have been established by the OECD and EPA
  * Thyroid gland histology is a primary endpoint in these guidelines, along with mortality, developmental stage, hind limb length, snout-vent length, and wet body weight.

• Cesarean sections (CS) are necessary for life-saving interventions, but the rate of CS without medical indication is increasing, leading to higher rates worldwide.
• The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a CS rate of 10-15%, based on countries with the lowest maternal and neonatal mortality rates.
• A study in Iran showed a six-fold increase in CS over three decades, but the debate on the best practices to minimize postnatal morbidity is still ongoing.
• Postpartum mothers experience physical and mental health conditions that affect their quality of life (QOL).
• Socio-economic deficiencies and medical problems are risk factors for decreased QOL and depressive symptoms during the postnatal period.
• Several studies have investigated the association between type of delivery and HRQOL, with conflicting results.
• A study aimed to explore the impact of delivery mode on women's postpartum physical and mental health related QOL.
• The study was a prospective study of pregnant women in Kashan City, Iran, with 175 mothers after vaginal delivery (VD) and 167 after CS.
• The study used the Iranian version of the Short Form-36 Health Survey (SF-36) to measure QOL, which consists of 36 items organized into eight scales: physical functioning, role limitation due to physical problems, bodily pain, general health, vitality, social functioning, role limitation due to emotional problems, and emotional well-being.

• The study found no significant differences between VD and CS groups regarding socio-demographic characteristics and physical and mental health scores at 2 and 4 months after delivery.
• Physical health scores were higher in VD women at both time points, and mental health scores were generally higher in CS women but not significantly.
• Significant differences were found for physical function and emotional well-being in the VD group at 4 months postpartum.
• The VD group showed more improvements in total mental HRQOL from time 1 to time 2 assessment.
• Nearly 80% of VD was performed with episiotomy or laceration, and the median time to restart intercourse was longer in the VD group.

<summary>
• Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs: a theory proposing human needs can be categorized into five levels, with safety needs being more fundamental than physiological needs
• Safety Needs: personal security, financial security, and health and well-being
• Safety Needs and Fear: fear can inhibit the satisfaction of physiological needs, and fear responses are faster and more fundamental than hedonic responses
• Experimental Evidence: studies show that organisms are more sensitive to threatening information and process it faster than rewarding information, known as negativity bias
• Appraisal Theory: emotions result from people's interpretations and explanations of their circumstances, with primary appraisal being a faster, automatic process related to fear
• Amygdala and Ne/LC System: the amygdala is the neural basis for fear and stress-elicited fear and anxiety, and the ne/LC system is important for directing behaviors to cope with dangerous environments
• Safety Needs and Mental Disorders: safety needs are a major reason for mental disorders such as anxiety, phobia, depression, and PTSD
• Treatment for Phobias: anger might be the best treatment for phobia patients, as they are unable to express anger and their emotions are checked at the fear stage, making ne the neural substrate for them
</summary>

• Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs:
– Five levels of human needs
– Safety needs more fundamental than physiological needs

• Safety Needs and Fear:
– Fear can inhibit satisfaction of physiological needs
– Fear responses faster and more fundamental than hedonic responses

• Experimental Evidence:
– Organisms more sensitive to threatening information
– Negativity bias: adaptive response to amplify threats and initiate appropriate behaviors

• Appraisal Theory:

<summary>
• The Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model is an extension of the Chronic Care Model (CCM) and aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care to patients.
• Challenges in implementing the PCMH model include promoting physician buy-in, changing office culture, care coordination, staffing and space allocations, and leveraging electronic medical records (EMRs).
• To become a recognized PCMH by the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA), a practice must create its own policies that adhere to PCMH principles and fit the specific practice structure.
• Physician buy-in to PCMH can be difficult due to misaligned financial incentives, underreimbursement, and time-consuming procedures.
• Team-based care is a key component of PCMH, which requires staff to address patient treatment decisions collectively and use previsit meetings to allocate resources and ensure adequate health maintenance.
• Care coordinators or care managers are often employed to perform tasks previously delivered inconsistently or not at all, such as patient follow-ups and patient education.
</summary>

• Challenges in implementing the PCMH model:
• Promoting physician buy-in:
  • Misaligned financial incentives
  • Underreimbursement
  • Time-consuming procedures
• Changing office culture:
  • New experiences for staff
  • Patient response to the new healthcare structure
• Care coordination and team-based care:
  • Use of previsit huddles
  • Patient education and self-management
• Staffing and space allocations:
  • Added space for care coordinators and private consultation areas
  • Employment of shared coordinators in small practices
• Leveraging electronic medical records (EMRs):
  • Implementation and servicing
  • Optimization of clinical space
  • Improving patient care and health through population management tools in the EMR.

• Meta-analysis conducted to evaluate effectiveness and safety of mild hypothermia for patients with cardiac arrest
• Included studies were randomized controlled trials in adult patients who suffered from cardiac arrest and were successfully resuscitated
• Intervention was therapeutic mild hypothermia, with temperature between 32°C and 34°C
• Secondary outcomes were adverse events such as rearrest, renal failure, and pulmonary edema
• Six studies met inclusion criteria, including 531 adult patients
• Three studies reported survival rate at hospital discharge, three reported survival rate after 6 months
• No heterogeneity in survival rate at hospital discharge or after 6 months
• Pooled results showed no significant difference in survival rate at hospital discharge, but significant difference in survival rate after 6 months
• Pooled results showed hypothermia improves survival rate (1.25, 95% CI: 1.05-1.49, p = 0.01)
• Three studies reported neurological function at hospital discharge, three reported neurological function after 6 months
• No heterogeneity in neurological function at hospital discharge or after 6 months
• Pooled results showed no significant difference in neurological function at hospital discharge, but significant difference in neurological function after 6 months
• Pooled results showed hypothermia improves neurological function (1.37, 95% CI: 1.13-1.66, p = 0.001)
• Mild hypothermia does not influence incidence of rearrest (1.19, 95% CI: 0.87-1.61, p = 0.27)
• No significant difference in other adverse events such as pulmonary edema, pneumonia, and bleeding
• Most studies at top of funnel plot indicated high precision
• Possible reasons why mild hypothermia does not improve survival rate and neurological function at hospital discharge: whole-body hypothermia, combination with other drugs, and slow neuron recovery process
• Pooled results showed mild hypothermia improves prognosis of patients
