* Osteoporosis is a condition of impaired bone strength leading to increased risk of fracture.
* Bone quality depends on macro- and microarchitecture and intrinsic properties of the materials that comprise it.
* Bone remodeling maintains bone structure and mechanical competence by removing damaged bone and replacing it with new bone.
* Multiple sclerosis (MS) affects nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord, leading to functional impairments and increased risk of fractures.
* Impaired mobility and lack of weight-bearing physical activity in MS patients disrupt bone remodeling and osteocytes network.
* Long-term disease-modifying therapy, such as glucocorticoids, can further negatively impact bone remodeling and bone strength.
* Secondary osteoporosis and low-trauma fractures occur more frequently in MS patients than in healthy controls.
* Factors contributing to bone loss in MS patients include immobilization, vitamin D deficiency, skeletal muscle atrophy, and chronic use of other drugs.
* MS patients have a higher risk of falls due to functional impairments, which increases the frequency of bone fractures.
* Clinical evaluation for bone health in MS patients should include assessment of clinical risk factors, motor function using the EDSS score, and regular BMD testing using DXA.

</summary>

* Osteoporosis: impaired bone strength, increased risk of fracture
* Causes: bone mass and quality, bone remodeling
* Bone quality: macro- and microarchitecture, intrinsic properties
* MS: affects nerve fibers, functional impairments, increased fracture risk
* Risk factors: immobilization, vitamin D deficiency, skeletal muscle atrophy, long-term drug use
* Bone remodeling: maintains bone structure, disrupted in MS
* Secondary osteoporosis: more frequent in MS patients
* Clinical evaluation: assess risk factors, EDSS score, BMD testing

* Impaired mobility, lack of weight-bearing activity
* Long-term disease-modifying therapy: glucocorticoids, further negatively impact bone
* Factors contributing to bone loss: immobilization, vitamin D deficiency

• Malaria is caused by parasites belonging to the phylum Apicomplexa, family Plasmodiidae, and genus Plasmodium, with the most prevalent species being Plasmodium falciparum, P. vivax, and P. malariae.
• The natural transmission occurs through the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes, with Anopheles darlingi being the most prevalent species.

• Symptoms of malaria include fever, chills, sweating, headache, myalgia, arthralgia, back pain, retroocular pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
• Chloroquine and primaquine are used for malaria treatment, with chloroquine being a blood schizonticide and primaquine active against latent tissue forms of P. vivax.

• Chloroquine can cause side effects such as abdominal discomfort, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which can also occur during primaquine use.
• Primaquine use can cause hemolytic anemia, resulting in jaundice and choluria, and is more prone to cause hemolytic events due to its longer course of treatment.
• Gastrointestinal symptoms and hemolysis are common side effects of antimalarial drugs, which can decrease adherence to treatment and contribute to reducing transmission of Plasmodium.
• It is important to assess the main side effects of antimalarial drugs in patients from endemic areas to improve clinical status and reduce transmission.

• Most patients had low parasitemia (less than 200 parasites/mm), and the main symptoms observed in untreated malaria were fever, chills, sweating, headache, arthralgia, and lower back pain.

- Mir-200 family members, including mir-200c, have been shown to repress zeb1 and zeb2, which are transcription factors involved in epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and loss of e-cadherin expression.
- Mir-200c directly binds to and degrades zeb1 mRNA, leading to an upregulation of e-cadherin.
- However, zeb1 can also transcriptionally repress mir-200 family members, creating a double-negative feedback loop between mir-200c and zeb1.
- Loss of mir-200c is a marker for chemoresistance and aggressiveness in breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers.
- Mir-200c also represses other mesenchymal genes, such as tubb3, which is a common mechanism of resistance to microtubule-targeting agents in many types of cancer.
- Repression of tubb3 by mir-200c is the mechanism by which mir-200c restores sensitivity to paclitaxel.

</summary>

- Mir-200 family members, including mir-200c, are involved in the regulation of zeb1 and zeb2, which are transcription factors that play a role in epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and loss of e-cadherin expression.
  * Mir-200c directly binds to and degrades zeb1 mRNA, leading to an upregulation of e-cadherin.
  * Zeb1 can also transcriptionally repress mir-200 family members, creating a double-negative feedback loop between mir-200c and zeb1.
- Loss of mir-200c is a marker for chemoresistance and aggressiveness in breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers.
  * Mir-200c also represses other mesenchymal genes, such as tubb3, which is a common mechanism of resistance to microtubule-targeting agents in many types of cancer.
  * Repression of tubb3 by mir-200

<summary>

* Transobturator approach to treat female stress urinary incontinence using midurethral slings was first described by Delorme, with the aim of reducing complications associated with the retropubic approach
* Delval later described a similar transobturator passage using an inside-out approach to further reduce potential injury to the urethra and bladder
* A recent meta-analysis found similar cure rates between the retropubic, outside-in transobturator, and inside-out transobturator mus procedures
* Anatomical studies have confirmed the safety of both obturator approaches from a neurovascular perspective
* A cadaveric study was conducted to compare the specific relationship between the tape and the urethra in both the inside-out and outside-in approach
* The study used CT scan image analysis after tantalum wire marked mesh slings were implanted in cadavers
* Findings revealed that the mus tapes lie as a band posterior/dorsal to the urethra, with out-in tapes more closely wrapped around the inferior ischio-pubic ramus
* The mean full inner angle in a strict antero-posterior view formed by the in-out mus measured 122 (95%ci: 107-136) versus 144 (95%ci: 131-151) for the out-in mus (p = 0.02)

</summary>

* Comparison between the tape and urethra in both inside-out and outside-in approach
* Use of CT scan image analysis and tantalum wire marked mesh slings in cadavers
* Findings: mus tapes lie as a band posterior/dorsal to the urethra, with out-in tapes more closely wrapped around the inferior ischio-pubic ramus
* Statistically significant difference in mean full inner angle formed by the in-out and out-in mus (p = 0.02)
* Importance of paying attention to the second half of the helical pass during surgery for both in-out and out-in approaches
* Potential future developments: three-dimensional ultrasonography and in vivo visualization of mesh by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) following

• Minister Kirsty Williams and Huw Morris discussed the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 during a post-legislative scrutiny session
• They addressed concerns about the balance between regulation and institutional autonomy, the role of HEFCW, and the future of the Act in relation to the upcoming PCET Bill
• Key points include:
   • Intention to supercede the 2015 Act with the new PCET Bill
   • Plans to strengthen regulation and accountability while preserving institutional autonomy
   • Discussion of the role of HEFCW in regulating private providers and the potential for a single quality assurance body
   • Acknowledgment of the importance of maintaining high-quality transnational education and addressing past issues with overseas providers
   • Commitment to ensuring that the new legislation is futureproof and fit for the changing needs of the sector.

<summary>

* Kirsty Williams AM intends to carry forward much of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 into the new post-compulsory education and training Bill.
* The Act's objectives include regulating institutions, safeguarding public good, maintaining fair access, and preserving institutional autonomy.
* The current legislation has limitations, and the new Bill will address these by introducing a new commission for tertiary education and outcome agreements.
* The Act's regulation of private providers is limited to designated courses, and the new legislation will consider how to regulate the sector more effectively.

</summary>

* Intention to carry forward much of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015
  + Regulation of institutions
  + Safeguarding public good
  + Maintaining fair access
  + Preserving institutional autonomy
* Limitations of the current legislation
  + New commission for tertiary education
  + Outcome agreements
* Regulation of private providers
  + Currently regulated on a course-by-course basis
  + Need to futureproof for potential changes in the sector

• The Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 will be superseded by the new post-compulsory education and training (PCET) Bill
• The Act's objectives include regulating institutions, safeguarding public good, maintaining fair access, and preserving institutional autonomy
• The Act has been criticized for limiting Welsh Government's policy leverage over the sector, but the Minister believes it has achieved its objectives
• The Minister intends to create a new commission for tertiary education and empower it to influence national priorities through outcome agreements
• The Act requires regulated institutions to be charities, making it difficult to regulate alternative private providers
• The Minister plans to maintain the charitable status for private providers in the new legislation
• The Act has been criticized for not encouraging collaboration, and the new PCET Bill aims to address this by creating a framework that demands and encourages collaboration
• The Minister acknowledged that HEFCW's powers are inflexible and difficult to use for swift interventions, and plans to create a commission with more flexible regulatory powers
</summary>

<summary>
• Discussion about the ease of allowing people to bleep things out in a database
• Morgan wants to make it hard, while others are unsure
• Discovered that wireless microphones can pick up breath noises
• Proposed solution: check if microphone is picking up breath noise by observing the AF indicator
• Proposed starting point for database format is the channelized output of Dave Gelbart's program
• Grad C has developed an XML format for this type of data
• Question is whether to use Grad C's format or not
• Discussed encoding of time-stamped data, including words, phone boundaries, and forced alignments
• Discussed the possibility of using a relational database to store the information from the XML
• Agreed to look at ATLAS and its API as a potential solution, but also considered alternatives such as P-files
</summary>

<summary>

* The Welsh Government's approach to early childhood education and care aims to support both children and parents.
* The government's objectives include simplifying the complex early years system and extending the childcare offer to parents in education and training.
* The government is working on pathfinder projects in eight local authorities to improve accessibility and take-up of early years services.
* The childcare offer currently covers approximately 34,000 children out of 73,000 three and four-year-olds in Wales.
* The Welsh Government has suspended plans to use HMRC to administer the childcare funding due to difficulties with Welsh language standards and the desire for a more flexible system.
* The cost of transitioning from a temporary arrangement with local authorities to a permanent system is estimated to be less than the cost proposed by HMRC.

</summary>

* Support for both children and parents: The Welsh Government aims to support the development of children and help parents return to work through high-quality early childhood education and care.
* Simplifying the system and expanding the offer: The government is working on simplifying the early years system and extending the childcare offer to parents in education and training.
* Pathfinder projects: Eight local authorities are testing ways to improve accessibility and take-up of early years services through pathfinder projects.
* Current coverage and eligibility: The childcare offer covers approximately 34,000 children out of 73,000 three and four-year-olds in Wales, with eligibility based on parents' work hours.
* HMRC administration: The Welsh Government has suspended plans to use HMRC to administer the childcare funding due to difficulties with Welsh language standards and the desire for a more flexible system.
* Cost comparison: The initial estimate suggests that the cost of transitioning to a permanent system with local authorities will be less than the cost proposed by HMRC.

<summary>
• The Welsh Government's primary objectives for early childhood education and care are to support both children and parents
• The government aims to simplify the complex early years system and improve accessibility and take-up of services
• The government is planning to expand the childcare offer to include parents in education and training, and is reviewing the longer-term possibility of a universal offer
• Flying Start, a targeted early intervention programme, reaches about 23% of children in Wales, with around 45% of those children living in poverty
  • Flying Start provides a range of services including health visiting, speech and language support, and childcare
  • The programme is evaluated through individual data collection and longitudinal studies to track children's progress
</summary>

• The goal is to extend the benefits of Flying Start to a wider group of children.

* They were accompanied by Huw Morris, group director at SHELL--skills, higher education and lifelong learning--and Marie Knox, deputy director, overseeing European transition
* The committee discussed the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales
* The Welsh Government has been working closely with higher and further education institutions since September 2016 to understand the potential impact of Brexit
* The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales has been conducting specific work on the sector, while the Welsh Government has been focusing on broader issues such as Erasmus+ provision and Horizon 2020
* The number of EU students in Welsh universities has dropped significantly since the Brexit vote, and the Welsh Government is working to mitigate the risk of further losses
* The Welsh Government is also working to ensure the sustainability of the higher and further education sectors beyond Brexit, including exploring the possibility of multi-year funding settlements

<summary>
• Kirsty Williams and Eluned Morgan appeared before the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales
• They were accompanied by Huw Morris, group director at SHELL, and Marie Knox, deputy director overseeing European transition
• Suzy Davies asked about preparedness and the impact of Brexit on higher education, specifically in a 'no deal' scenario
• Huw Morris mentioned ongoing work being done to understand the impact on HE, FE, and apprenticeship providers
• Suzy Davies asked for any formal risk assessments to be shared, but Kirsty Williams mentioned ongoing work with institutions and officials to mitigate risks
• Eluned Morgan discussed the impact on FE, which has a lower number of EU students and staff compared to HE
• The Welsh Government is keeping in touch with FE colleges and ColegauCymru to understand the impact on ESF funding and apprenticeships
• Marie Knox mentioned the European transition team, which provides governance structure for the Welsh Government in relation to European transition
</summary>
• The team includes representatives from various departments, including higher education and further education
• The team leads discussions with the Department for Exiting the European Union, No. 10, and the Joint Ministerial Committee

• Kirsty Williams discussed the drop in EU student applications in Wales and the change in funding for EU students
• She emphasized the importance of attracting international students to maintain a diverse student population and high-quality teaching
• Llyr Gruffydd asked about the sustainability of higher and further education funding beyond Brexit
• Eluned Morgan mentioned the importance of maintaining the range of learning opportunities provided by EU funding and the potential impact of a loss of ERDF funding
• She expressed concern about the lack of multi-annual budgeting from the UK Government and the potential impact on staffing and employment opportunities
• Eluned Morgan also discussed the importance of collaboration with other departments and Cabinet Secretaries to safeguard the interests of the education sectors and the wider economy.

<summary>
• Welcoming of new committee member Suzy Davies and farewell to departing members
• Discussion on the impact of Brexit on higher and further education
• Preparedness and research:
  • Nine sector analyses have been superseded by work from Cardiff University
  • Ongoing work being done to understand potential impact on individual institutions
  • Funding for much of the activity is secured until December 2020
  • Formal risk assessments are not available for scrutiny
• Impact on FE:
  • FE colleges are less reliant on EU students and staff
  • PS15 million a year goes into the FE sector for apprenticeships
  • Concerns about ESF funding and apprenticeships
  • Regional skills partnerships are being developed to respond to employer needs
• Impact on HE:
  • Higher Education Brexit working group has been meeting since September 2016
  • Funding for much of the activity is secured until December 2020
  • Concerns about Erasmus+ provision and Horizon 2020 participation
  • Discussions ongoing with UK Government and EU about potential arrangements
</summary>

	+ Users want to spend money on a better system, including a better remote control

	+ Less important functions include teletext and audio/display settings

	+ Could be more expensive than traditional batteries
	+ Consumer interest and willingness to pay for this feature needs to be determined.

<summary>
• Cabinet Secretary Kirsty Williams discussed the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) for free school meals, looked-after children, and adopted children
• PDG should be used to support individual interventions for free school meal children, but schools can also use it for universal interventions if they demonstrate disproportionate benefits
• PDG should also be used to support more able and talented children, and regional advisers have been appointed to ensure consistent practice
• Challenges include lack of awareness of PDG eligibility and insufficient resources for looked-after and adopted children

• Free school meal eligibility:
    • Over 35% of primary and 23% of secondary schools were unaware that PDG was targeted at looked-after children
    • PDG for looked-after children is held at a regional level, and regional consortia are responsible for its deployment

• Adopted children:
    • Parents of adopted children may not disclose their child's status to schools, making it difficult to track and provide targeted support
    • Discussions are ongoing about creating a dataset to track adopted children and their educational outcomes
</summary>

<summary>

* Cabinet Secretary Kirsty Williams discussed the use of Pupil Development Grant (PDG) in Welsh schools
* PDG is targeted at children eligible for free school meals, but can also be used for universal interventions if it demonstrates disproportionate benefits for FSM children
* PDG should be used to support more able and talented children, not just to bring them up to average
* PDG has been used to improve attendance, reduce exclusions, and support looked-after and adopted children
* PDG has been used for initiatives such as walking buses, attachment disorder training, and nurture groups
* PDG has been regionalized for looked-after children, with regional coordinators deploying the resource strategically
* An external evaluation of the use of PDG for looked-after children is being conducted by ICF consulting
* The Cabinet Secretary is open to adjusting the eligibility of PDG to include children who have been looked after or adopted at any point in the past, but data protection concerns need to be addressed

</summary>

* Discussion on PDG usage in Welsh schools
* Targeted at children eligible for free school meals, but can also be used for universal interventions
* PDG should support more able and talented children
* PDG used for attendance, exclusions, and support for looked-after and adopted children
* Initiatives include walking buses, attachment disorder training, and nurture groups
* Regionalized for looked-after children with regional coordinators
* External evaluation of PDG use for looked-after children being conducted by ICF consulting
* Open to adjusting eligibility for PDG to include children with past looked-after or adopted status, but data protection concerns need to be addressed.

<summary>
• Cabinet Secretary Kirsty Williams, Steve Davies (director of education directorate), and Ruth Conway (deputy director, support for learners division) discussed the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) to improve educational outcomes for children
• PDG should only be used for individual interventions for children eligible for free school meals, but schools can use it for universal interventions if they demonstrate disproportionate benefits for FSM children
• PDG should also be used to support more able and talented children, and examples of good practice include the "window on the world" bus in Pembrokeshire and the use of growth mindset training in Brynteg County Primary School
• Guidance on PDG usage is sufficient, but awareness and consistency need to be improved, and new regional advisers have been appointed to provide strategic advice
• Eligibility for free school meals is the best measure for identifying children in need, but there is a need to explore alternative measures and improve communication between schools and social services regarding adopted children
• PDG has had mixed results in reducing exclusions for looked-after children, and more needs to be done to address the root causes of exclusions and improve support for these children
• Schools Challenge Cymru identified six interconnected lessons for improving educational outcomes, including the importance of strong school leadership, comprehensive tracking systems, and collaborative activity
• The Schools Challenge Cymru programme was time-limited, but investment in regional school improvement capacity has continued to support schools in making improvements
</summary>

<summary>
• Cabinet Secretary Kirsty Williams discussed the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) for vulnerable learners, including looked-after and adopted children
• PDG should be targeted at eligible children, but schools can use it for universal interventions if they demonstrate disproportionate benefits for FSM children
• The use of PDG for more able and talented children is a priority, with examples given of successful initiatives like the "window on the world" bus in Pembrokeshire
• The eligibility for free school meals is the best measure for identifying vulnerable learners in the absence of a better alternative
• The PDG regional advisers will play a crucial role in ensuring consistent practice and strategic advice across the regions
• The impact of PDG on attendance and engagement is being explored, with examples given of successful initiatives like walking buses and breakfast clubs
• The attainment gap for looked-after and adopted children is a concern, with only 35% of primary and 23% of secondary schools aware that PDG is targeted at these groups
• PDG for looked-after children is held at a regional level, with regional PDG coordinators deploying the resource strategically
• An evaluation of the regional allocation of PDG for looked-after children is being conducted by ICF consulting, with results expected later this spring
• Adjusting the eligibility of PDG to include pupils who have been looked after or adopted at any point within a previous given period is being considered
</summary>

<summary>
• Cabinet Secretary Kirsty Williams discussed the progress and future plans for the Schools Challenge Cymru program and the Pupil Development Grant (PDG)
• PDG is targeted at children eligible for free school meals, but can also be used for universal interventions if they have a disproportionate effect on these children
• The eligibility for free school meals is used as a proxy for identifying children in need, but there are concerns about its effectiveness and potential for misuse
• The PDG has been used to support more able and talented children, with examples given of successful initiatives like the "window on the world" bus in Pembrokeshire
• The PDG has been used to address attendance and exclusion issues, with some success in improving attendance through proactive approaches like walking buses and breakfast clubs
• The impact of PDG on attainment has been mixed, with some schools showing significant improvement and others not, leading to concerns about the effectiveness of the program and the need for greater accountability and transparency
• The Welsh Government is exploring ways to make the PDG more flexible and responsive to changing circumstances, including the possibility of an "Ever 2" system and greater collaboration between schools and local authorities
</summary>

• Discussion of progress and future plans for Schools Challenge Cymru and Pupil Development Grant (PDG)
• Targeting of PDG for children eligible for free school meals, but concerns about misuse and effectiveness
• Use of PDG for more able and talented children, with examples of successful initiatives
• Addressing attendance and exclusion issues with PDG, with some success through proactive approaches
• Mixed impact of PDG on attainment, leading to concerns about effectiveness and need for greater accountability and transparency
• Exploring ways to make PDG more flexible and responsive to changing circumstances, including "Ever 2" system and greater collaboration between schools and local authorities
• Cabinet Secretary Kirsty Williams' responses to questions from committee members during a hearing on targeted funding to improve educational outcomes.

* They emphasized the importance of addressing childhood obesity and involving children and young people in the consultation process.
* A target for reducing obesity among children was not explicitly ruled out, but the focus is on evaluating existing programs and considering new investments.
* The consultation process includes engagement with children and young people, schools, and youth ambassadors.
* The strategy aims to create healthy settings, including schools, and improve access to healthy food and physical activity.

* The importance of addressing socioeconomic inequalities and making every contact count was emphasized.

* Discussion about the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy to create a healthy environment for children and young people
* Dr. Frank Atherton, Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, attended the meeting
* Strategy aims to address high prevalence of overweight and obesity among children and young people, with a focus on future generations
* Engagement with children and young people has been ongoing through consultations, school visits, and youth ambassadors
* Discussions included the need for a target to reduce obesity, investment, leadership, and partnership working

* Need to balance deliverability with challenge when considering a target for obesity reduction
* Consultation will ask if Wales should adopt a target and what it might look like
* PS56 million from sugar levy will be used to fund initiatives, but more investment may be needed
* Leadership and drive from the top is essential, with public services boards and local ownership and leadership also important
* Discussions about using the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways near schools and building healthier settings into schools, including sports infrastructure and changing rooms
* Healthy habits can be developed early in life, and schools have a role in promoting physical activity and healthy eating
* The quality of food in packed lunches is a concern, and universal school meals could be considered to ensure all children have access to good-quality food
* Review of clinical obesity pathway for children and young people is underway, focusing on identification, interventions, and support for very overweight children
* First 1,000 days are critical in shaping children's lives, and existing initiatives such as Healthy Child Wales and breastfeeding action plan need to be improved
* Economic factors, such as affordability of healthy food and income poverty, need to be addressed to support low-income families in making healthy choices
* Making every contact count requires availability of people to refer to, and the health system needs to respond by providing more dietetic support and redesigning the pathway.

• Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy to address childhood obesity and the role of children and young people in the strategy.
• They emphasized the importance of engaging children and young people in the consultation process and shared examples of their involvement, such as discussions in schools and a session with youth ambassadors.
• The strategy aims to create a future generation focused approach, while also addressing the current generation's issues with overweight and obesity. They also discussed the potential use of targets, the need for investment, and the importance of partnership working and leadership.

• Graduate students discuss their research
  • Grad E presents results of experiments with mean log magnitude spectral subtraction in the SmartKom system
    • Twelve seconds of speech used to calculate mean
      • Performance drops slightly compared to twelve-second centered window
    • Experiments with shorter windows for mean calculation during testing
      • Performance hurts less than one percent, but not significantly better than training with the same length of time

• Discussion of Wiener filtering
  • Used to minimize difference between noisy signal and clean signal
  • Different approximations and techniques for noise estimation and compensation
    • Spectral subtraction is one approach, but not used in combination with Wiener filtering

<summary>
• Professor B discussed the issue of voice activity detectors in a research project called Aurora
• During a meeting, it was revealed that two leading proposals, French Telecom Alcatel and the team of Professor B, both had voice activity detectors, leading to competition and disagreements
• The group agreed to evaluate the algorithms without voice activity detectors or modify them, but French Telecom objected, fearing their techniques would be copied
• The group discussed the possibility of requiring a larger improvement for the evaluation, but this was not agreed upon
• Professor B suggested experimenting with compressing or modifying the standard deviation of certain components in the model to make them less important in the overall score
</summary>

• Voice activity detectors caused competition and disagreements in the Aurora project
  • French Telecom and Professor B both had voice activity detectors
  • The group agreed to evaluate algorithms without voice activity detectors or modify them
  • French Telecom objected, fearing their techniques would be copied

• Possible solutions discussed to address the issue
  • Require a larger improvement for the evaluation
    • Not agreed upon
  • Professor B suggested compressing or modifying the standard deviation of certain components in the model
    • Make them less important in the overall score
    • Train the model with the original data and modify the variance of the problematic component
    • Divide the features by a larger number to get a smaller contribution in the overall score

<summary>

* Dr. David Blaney, the Chief Executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW), discussed the impact of Brexit on Wales' higher education system during a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
* HEFCW is unable to predict the full extent of the financial impact of Brexit on Welsh universities due to uncertainty surrounding the political relationship between the Welsh and UK governments, as well as the economic impact of Brexit on the UK economy.
* The HE sector in Wales is exposed to sources of income from the EU, including EU students, structural funds, and EU research funding.
* There has been a decrease in EU student applications to Welsh institutions, contrasting with an increase in England.
* The Welsh sector is trying to maintain infrastructure and resources in anticipation of future funding.
* The implementation of the Diamond recommendations is crucial to re-balancing investment in the Welsh higher education sector.
* The sector is also facing pressures from student recruitment, pay and pension costs, and the uncertainty surrounding the review in England of fees and funding.

</summary>

* Impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education:
	+ Uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe
	+ Decrease in EU student applications (8% for Welsh institutions, 2% for English institutions)
	+ Difficulties in collaborating in EU research activities
	+ Financial impact uncertain due to political relationship between Welsh and UK governments and economic impact of Brexit on UK economy

* Pressures on Welsh higher education sector:
	+ Funding position: implementing Diamond recommendations to re-establish funding for higher cost provision, innovation, and research funding
	+ Student recruitment: decreasing applications from Welsh-domiciled and English-domiciled students
	+ Pay and pension costs: potential increase in cost for universities superannuation scheme pension fund
	+ Uncertainty surrounding review in England of fees and funding (Augar review)
	+ Capital expenditure and borrowing for modern facilities and infrastructure
	+ Increasing competition in the UK higher education market
	+ Need to maintain and strengthen research and innovation infrastructure to be competitive in UK-wide research funding.

<summary>
• The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education
• John Griffiths was appointed as temporary Chair
• The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) provided evidence on the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education
• HEFCW identified areas of exposure to EU funding, including EU students and structural funds
• EU students' applications to Welsh institutions have decreased by 8%, contrasting with a 2% increase in England
• Non-EU students' applications have also decreased by 9%
• The financial impact of Brexit on Welsh universities is uncertain, but there are signs of difficulties in collaborative research activities with EU partners
• HEFCW is working with the sector to promote Wales and attract international students, and is also advocating for continued access to EU research funding
</summary>

• HEFCW is concerned about the sustainability of higher education providers in Wales
• The impact of Brexit on the capacity of the higher education system to deliver for Wales is uncertain
• HEFCW is monitoring the financial sustainability of individual institutions and challenging those that are not properly sighted on risks
• The sector is working to find ways to maintain and strengthen the research and innovation infrastructure in Wales
• The Welsh Government is commissioning a report on supporting research and innovation in the transition period
• The sector is also dealing with the reform of tertiary education arrangements in Wales and the uncertainty surrounding the implementation of the Diamond recommendations
• The sector is facing a 'valley of death' with several challenges, including the Brexit deal, investment, and engagement with research councils and charities
• HEFCW is advocating for continued investment in research and innovation to maintain and grow the critical mass in Welsh universities.

<summary>

* The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales.
* John Griffiths was appointed as temporary Chair.
* The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) provided evidence on the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education.
* HEFCW identified the exposure of the sector to sources of income from the EU, including EU students, structural funds, and EU research funding.
* There is uncertainty about the future of these sources of income due to Brexit.
* EU student applications to Welsh institutions have decreased by 8%, contrasting with a 2% increase in England.
* Non-EU student applications have also decreased by 9%.
* The reasons for the decrease in EU applications include the change in student support arrangements and the perceived attractiveness of institutions in England with better-invested campuses.
* HEFCW is working with the sector to promote Wales as a good place to study and to maintain and develop the research and innovation infrastructure.
* The sector is currently managing financial deficits and preparing for the implementation of the Diamond recommendations, which are expected to provide additional funding for higher education in Wales.

</summary>

<summary>
• Impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education:
  • Uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe
  • Decrease in EU student applications and international students
  • Difficulties in collaborating in EU research activities
• Challenges facing the Welsh higher education sector:
  • Funding position: implementing Diamond recommendations and managing deficits
  • Student recruitment: decreasing applications from Welsh and English students
  • Pay and pension costs, capital expenditure, and uncertainty from English review of fees and funding
</summary>

* The team discussed designing a new remote control for televisions using Bluetooth technology.
* They considered keeping the remote control simple with only essential functions and using a touch screen for additional options.
* Decisions included keeping the primary buttons easily accessible, using a partial touch screen for secondary functions, and incorporating a way for the remote to recognize the television type for customized menus.

* Keeping it simple: The team agreed to keep the design simple with easily accessible primary functions and hidden secondary options.
* Touch screen: They considered using a touch screen for secondary functions, but decided on a partial touch screen to keep the design accessible for all users.
* Television recognition: The team discussed incorporating a way for the remote to recognize the television type to provide customized menus.

<summary>
• Deputy Minister Julie Morgan discussed the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill
• Nearly 70% of individuals who responded to the consultation do not support the Bill
• The Bill aims to protect children's rights by prohibiting all forms of physical punishment
• Parents oppose the Bill, believing they understand the difference between child abuse and a light smack
• The United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child recognizes that any physical punishment of children is incompatible with their human rights
• The Bill does not create a new offence, but removes the defence for physical punishment in common assault
• The implementation of the Bill will depend on close working relationships with organizations involved in safeguarding children
• The Welsh Government has committed to funding a high-intensity awareness-raising campaign and a mapping exercise to establish any gaps in parenting support
• The CPS and CAFCASS Cymru have stated they can cope with the potential increase in workload
• The Welsh Government has discussed the costing of the Bill with the Finance Minister and the First Minister's officials
</summary>

* Two versions of a remote control prototype presented: one with LCD display and one without
* Both versions come with a charger and detachable control module
* LCD version has a joystick for navigation and a microphone for speech recognition
* Switch for turning speech recognition on or off
* Cost of LCD version is fifteen dollars, but can be reduced to ten with optimization
* Battery is a single AA battery, rechargeable
* Remote control has a single button with 360-degree movement, acting as a mouse and supporting additional functions
* Marketing prefers simpler design with four buttons for navigation and a cheaper price of four dollars
* Evaluation criteria discussed: fancy look, innovation, and ease of use
* Fancy look: customers want a colorful, spongy remote control
* Innovation: customers want a remote control with a customizable design and the ability to add or remove features as desired
* Ease of use: customers want a remote control that is easy to use and understand, with clear labels and a logical layout
* Speech recognition and LCD display are optional add-ons
* Microsoft-style updates and upgrades are not desired
* Shape of remote control can be customized with skins or different materials, such as sponge or fur
* Project evaluation was satisfactory, with good teamwork and room for creativity
* Leadership was excellent and democratic
* Clear points and prior planning are important for effective meetings
* Celebration suggested with a coffee machine and more snacks.

* Two versions of a remote control prototype were presented: one with an LCD display and one without
* The version without LCD display has a simpler design, is cheaper to produce, and easier to use
* The team discussed the integration of a speech recognition system and parental control modules
* The team considered the possibility of offering optional modules or add-ons for customers, but decided against it due to potential production cost increases and customer segmentation issues.

* LCD display:
  * Adds functionality but increases production cost and complexity
  * May not be necessary if the remote control is easy to use and customizable
* Speech recognition system:
  * Optional module that can be added to the remote control
  * May increase production cost but could also improve user experience
* Parental control module:
  * Optional module that can be added to the remote control
  * May increase production cost but could be useful for families with children
* Optional modules:
  * Could lead to customer segmentation and potential loss of sales
  * May increase production cost due to the need for multiple PCBs and components
* Single PCB with interchangeable skins:
  * Could be a cost-effective solution for offering different designs
  * May not provide the same level of customization as optional modules.

* She expressed gratitude to those keeping schools open and helping children learn at home
* Schools will reopen in a phased manner when it is safe to do so, based on advice from medical and scientific advisers
* The principles for reopening schools include considering the safety and well-being of children and staff, clear communication, and planning for specific groups of children
* Schools are currently open for vulnerable children and children of key workers, with 518 school hubs open each day and 600 vulnerable children attending daily

* Testing will be crucial for the next phase and will be a building block in the Government's response to the pandemic
* The Minister is working with local authorities and schools to ensure vulnerable children attend hubs and receive support
* The Government is providing additional funding for school counselling services to support children's mental health during the pandemic
* Parents are encouraged to contact their child's school for support and advice on home learning
* The Welsh Government is working to ensure all children have access to hardware and connectivity for remote learning
* A-level and GCSE results will be awarded based on teachers' assessments and moderated by Qualifications Wales
* The moratorium on unconditional offers at universities remains in place until 1 May, with ongoing discussions about extending it
* Students living at home will not have their student support payments reduced
* The Welsh Government is continuing to support students and universities during the pandemic, with flexibility in how funding is used.

* Minister Kirsty Williams expressed gratitude to everyone involved in keeping schools open during the pandemic, including teachers, teaching assistants, and parents.

* The number of children attending school hubs is currently low, with around 1% of children in attendance and 85% of those being children of key workers or vulnerable children.
* The Welsh Government is working to ensure that vulnerable children have access to support and services, including counseling and technology.

* Vocational learners are awaiting clarity on assessments, with a focus on ensuring a fair balance between progress and potential performance in exams.
* A-level and GCSE results will be awarded based on teacher assessments and rankings, with moderation to ensure a robust qualifications system.
* The higher education sector is facing challenges due to the pandemic, with a moratorium on unconditional offers in place until May 1st.
* Students are receiving maintenance loans as usual, with discussions ongoing to support those affected by the pandemic.
* The Welsh Government is working closely with universities and the UK government to provide stability and support to the higher education sector.

* Minister Kirsty Williams announced the closure of all schools in Wales starting from the next day due to the coronavirus pandemic
* The decision was made to protect staff and pupils and ensure continuity of education
* Schools will have a new purpose from next week, including supporting vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning
* Free school meal children will continue to receive support, with schools identified as emergency response centers and plans being developed for their provision
* Minister thanked everyone working in education settings for their hard work and urged continued collaboration to face the challenges posed by the coronavirus.

* Supporting and safeguarding the vulnerable:
	+ Schools will play an important part in providing safe and secure places for children of those on the front-line response to dealing with the coronavirus to attend
	+ Work is underway to identify children of key workers and make arrangements for their attendance
	+ Plans are being developed for the provision of free school meals for those in need
* Ensuring continuity of learning:
	+ All maintained schools in Wales already have access to digital tools through the Hwb digital learning platform
	+ A guide on how to use these tools has been developed and is being promoted widely
	+ No easy choices were made, but it was agreed that the best way forward is not to proceed with the summer exam series and learners will be awarded a fair grade based on their work.

<summary>
• Minister Kirsty Williams made an opening statement about the impact of COVID-19 on education in Wales
• Schools will close from tomorrow for statutory education provision, but will have a new purpose to support vulnerable children and ensure continuity of learning
• From next week, schools will help support those most in need, including children of key workers and those with additional learning needs
• All maintained schools in Wales already have access to digital tools for distance learning through the Hwb digital learning platform
• The summer exam series has been cancelled, and learners will be awarded a fair grade based on their work
• The Minister thanked everyone working in education settings for their hard work and urged continued collaboration to face the challenges posed by the coronavirus
• The Minister also addressed questions from Members on practical applications of the new purpose of schools, communication with parents, vulnerable children, and funding for Cylch Meithrin
</summary>

• New purpose of schools:
  • Supporting vulnerable children
  • Providing continuity of learning
  • Supporting children of key workers
  • Identifying and catering to the needs of children with additional learning needs
  • Operating under social distancing guidelines
  • Ensuring the safety and well-being of staff and students

• Communication with parents:
  • Using all available platforms to get messages across
  • Collaborating with schools to have conversations with parents about their needs
  • Anticipating imperfect communication on Monday, but working to build resilience

• Vulnerable children:
  • Including children on the at-risk register
  • Considering young carers and children in difficult home situations
  • Encouraging teachers to use their professional judgment to identify and include children who may not be formally identified as vulnerable

• Cylch Meithrin:
  • Welsh Government will take every step to provide continuity of funding
  • Settings will stay open unless public health changes
  • Discussions ongoing with Julie Morgan about Flying Start childcare and early education

• Exams:
  • All exams cancelled for years 11 and 13

  • Modulation across the UK being discussed to maintain standards

• Universities and colleges:
  • Conversations ongoing with Univers

* Minister Kirsty Williams announced the closure of all schools in Wales starting from the next day due to the coronavirus pandemic
* Reasons for closure include protecting staff and pupils, ensuring continuity of education, and prioritizing public health
* New purpose of schools:
	+ Supporting vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning
	+ Providing emergency childcare for children of key workers
	+ Developing plans for free school meals and additional learning needs
	+ Operating under social distancing guidelines and providing online learning resources
* Minister also announced cancellation of summer exams and plans for alternative grading methods
* Discussions ongoing with universities and colleges regarding potential closures and support for students
* Welsh Government will continue to fund EMA and student maintenance payments
* Concerns raised about mental health and well-being of staff and learners, with plans for check-ins and online resources
* Emergency legislation being considered to provide Welsh Ministers with temporary powers to close schools, direct resources, and relax requirements.

• Witnesses, including Sally Jenkins from ADSS, Alastair Birch from ADEW, and Huw David from WLGA, expressed their support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.
• They emphasized the importance of clarity and the need to uphold the rights of the child, as well as the potential negative consequences of physical punishment on children and the potential pathway to more serious abuse.
• The witnesses acknowledged the need for awareness-raising and training for professionals, as well as the importance of preventative services and support for families.
• They also discussed the potential impact on resources and the need for proper funding and resourcing to ensure successful implementation of the Bill.
• The witnesses emphasized the importance of involving families and carers in the process and ensuring that they are supported.
• They also acknowledged the potential for unintended consequences, such as increased awareness of the UNCRC and a potential focus on positive parenting approaches in schools.
• The witnesses expressed confidence that teachers and others working in educational settings would be clear about how to support the implementation of the Bill, and that the duty to report significant harm would remain in place.
• They also discussed the importance of awareness-raising and training for professionals, as well as the need for preventative services and support for families.

* The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a scrutiny session on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.
* Witnesses included Sally Jenkins from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Alastair Birch from Pembrokeshire County Council representing the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Councillor Huw David from Bridgend County Borough Council as the Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care.
* They expressed their general support for the Bill and explained why they believe the current law is ineffective or unclear.
* The witnesses emphasized the importance of upholding the rights of the child and ensuring clarity in legislation.
* They discussed the potential harm of physical punishment to children and the potential for it to lead to more serious abuse.
* The witnesses also addressed the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment and the importance of awareness raising and training for professionals.
* They acknowledged the potential impact on resources but expressed confidence that the Bill would not significantly increase referrals to social services.
* The witnesses emphasized the importance of a major awareness-raising campaign and support for parents and carers.
* The committee discussed the implementation of the Bill and the role of local authorities in the process.
* The witnesses expressed their commitment to working with Welsh Government on the implementation of the Bill.

<summary>

* Meeting was about discussing various issues related to speech recognition research
* Professor A mentioned the NSF ITR proposal and its upcoming full proposal stage
* Grad B discussed the issue of handling misread digits in transcriptions
	+ Option 1: Throw out and re-read misread digits
	+ Option 2: Change transcripts to match what was actually said
	+ Five or six instances of misread digits out of four thousand lines
* Discussion about the length of filenames for consistency in sorting
	+ Three letters and three numbers for meeting IDs
	+ Same for speaker IDs
	+ Need to assemble a speaker database
* Postdoc F discussed his experience with channel-by-channel transcriptions
	+ Discovered time lags using a more complex interface
	+ Suggested giving transcribers single channel parts and piecing them together later
	+ Wanted to discuss efficiency with Chuck
* PhD C discussed his harmonicity detection algorithm
	+ Calculates instantaneous frequency using FFT
	+ Uses two methods: one based on FFT and another on instantaneous frequency
	+ Struggling to understand why the proposed rule for calculating instantaneous frequency doesn't work
* Postdoc F raised the issue of handling breaths in speech recognition
	+ Discussed the possibility of eliminating breaths from the audio signal
	+ Noted that some applications, like PDA, might not need to handle breaths
	+ More people than just PDA users are interested in the corpus

</summary>

* Discussed final design and project evaluation in the meeting
* Evaluated design based on criteria such as functionality, ease of use, and cost
** Functionality:**
* Design is functional and includes all desired features
* Some concerns about the number of functions and their usefulness
** Ease of use:**
* Design is not very easy to use, especially for older people
* Need to consider the learning curve for users
** Cost:**
* Cost is a concern, especially with the addition of an LCD screen and docking station
* Need to find ways to reduce costs while still meeting requirements
* Considered options such as a flat design and fewer buttons
** Recognizability:**
* Company logo is recognizable, but some concerns about the radio button design
* Need to consider how to make the design more recognizable to the target audience
* Discussed the possibility of creating different covers for different markets
* Project process was evaluated, with some concerns about the lack of financial information early on and the need for more creativity
* Decided to export the design as an image and share it with the team
* Discussed the possibility of reaching younger audiences by creating covers specifically for them
* Celebrated the completion of the project and discussed next steps, including a final presentation and a questionnaire for team members.

<summary>
* Marketing and Industrial Designer discussed two remote control prototypes
* First prototype was a basic design with a surfboard shape and a conventional layout of buttons
* Second prototype was a more advanced design with a minimalist layout, a LCD screen, and speech recognition capabilities
* The group evaluated the two designs based on look and feel, innovation, ease of use, appeal to demographic, and following trends
* The basic design scored higher in look and feel and ease of use, while the advanced design scored higher in innovation and appeal to demographic due to its LCD screen and speech recognition features
</summary>

* Evaluation criteria: look and feel, innovation, ease of use, appeal to demographic, following trends
	+ Look and feel: basic design scored higher due to its conventional shape and feel
	+ Innovation: advanced design scored higher due to its LCD screen and speech recognition features
	+ Ease of use: basic design scored higher due to its familiar layout and simplicity
	+ Appeal to demographic: advanced design scored higher due to its modern features and target audience
	+ Following trends: advanced design scored higher due to its LCD screen and potential for customizable covers
* Discussion of costs and features
	+ Basic design was within budget at eight Euros, but had a conventional layout and limited functionality
	+ Advanced design was outside of budget at sixteen Euros, but had advanced features such as a LCD screen, speech recognition, and a minimalist design
	+ Group discussed ways to reduce the cost of the advanced design, such as using a regular chip instead of an advanced one and reducing the number of buttons
	+ Ultimately, the group decided to focus on the basic design due to its lower cost and higher scores in the evaluation criteria, but kept the advanced design in mind for future possibilities.

* Frasier and Niles go to La Porte D'Argent, a luxurious spa
* They are only allowed in the silver level despite having an invitation
* Frasier and Niles are determined to get into the gold level
* Frasier disguises himself and Niles as Cam Winston and enters the gold level with him
* They discover it's just a regular spa, not the exclusive club they imagined
* Disappointed, they leave and try to find a way to get into the platinum level, which they believe is the real heaven
** Frasier and Niles enter the relaxation grotto in the silver level
** They are both wrapped up and given facials
** Frasier becomes determined to see the platinum level and drags Niles with him
** They kick open a door, expecting to find a solarium, but instead find themselves in an alley behind the building
** They realize they have been tricked and try to get back into the spa
* Roz helps Frasier and Niles get into the gold level by calling Senator Ogden, who owes her a favor
* Frasier and Niles are disappointed to find the gold level is just an ordinary spa
* They leave, determined to find the platinum level
* They stumble upon an alley behind the building instead, thinking it's the platinum level
* Frasier and Niles are disappointed and try to get back into the spa, but are caught and kicked out.

* Lorelai and Rory discuss wedding preparations and Lorelai's decision to wear a veil
* Lorelai struggles to choose between different veil lengths and styles
* Lorelai wears a newspaper veil while seeking Rory's advice
* Rory tries to help Lorelai make a decision, but is distracted by Paris and her own summer school plans
* Paris tries to convince Rory not to attend a Rebuilding Together event, but Rory insists on going
* Paris becomes angry when Rory refuses to listen to her and accuses her of having multiple personalities
* Rory and Paris argue about the importance of the event and Paris's motivations
* Rory eventually agrees to attend the Rebuilding Together event, much to Paris's frustration
* Rory goes to the event and helps build a house, while Paris stays behind and studies
* Lorelai tells Emily about her engagement and is met with a lackluster response, leading to a heated argument
* Lorelai feels hurt and upset by Emily's reaction and leaves the house
* Lorelai goes to Max for support and they discuss their upcoming wedding plans and the challenges of dealing with difficult family dynamics.

* Casey and Ashleigh have a slumber party at Zeta Beta Zeta house for pledges
* Ashleigh tells ghost stories, but Casey tries to take control
* Rebecca finds a chandelier falls down, causing the girls to believe it's a ghost
* Casey and Rebecca argue about the ghost and the purpose of the party

* Casey wants to impress pledges and win their votes
* Ashleigh believes in the existence of the ghost and wants to communicate with it
* Rebecca thinks Casey is only interested in politics and manipulating the pledges
* Casey denies this and insists she cares about the pledges
* Rebecca reveals she found out how Virginia, a former Zeta Beta Zeta member, died
* The girls are shocked and scared, but Casey insists it's just a coincidence
* Rebecca continues to sabotage the party, causing the chandelier to fall again
* Ashleigh suggests a séance to communicate with Virginia
* During the séance, the girls believe they are communicating with the ghost
* Casey tries to end the séance, but Rebecca continues to provoke the girls
* The girls become scared and believe the house is haunted

* The girls find notes that were hidden in the fireplace, revealing that Virginia won the election by one vote
* Casey calls for a new election and Virginia is declared the winner
* The girls are relieved and happy that Virginia is back in her rightful place
* Casey is praised for her leadership and ability to bring the sisterhood together

* George and Callie's marriage is in trouble after George confesses he slept with Izzie
* Callie confronts Izzie in the cafeteria, but Izzie realizes Callie wanted to talk, not fight
* Izzie apologizes for her actions and Callie expresses her anger and hurt
* Will, Ruthie's boyfriend, is devastated when she dies from complications of malnutrition and overtraining
* Bailey performs emergency surgery on Ruthie but is unable to save her
* Richard struggles to convince Camille to undergo aggressive treatment for her cancer
* Meredith and Derek discuss their relationship and Derek proposes marriage

*, George and Callie's marriage: George confesses to Callie that he slept with Izzie, leading to tension and anger
*, Izzie and Callie: Izzie realizes Callie wanted to talk, not fight, and apologizes for her actions
*, Will and Ruthie: Ruthie dies from complications of malnutrition and overtraining, leaving Will devastated
*, Bailey and Ruthie: Bailey performs emergency surgery on Ruthie but is unable to save her
*, Camille and Richard: Richard struggles to convince Camille to undergo aggressive treatment for her cancer
*, Meredith and Derek: Meredith and Derek discuss their relationship and Derek proposes marriage
*, Forgiveness and healing: The importance of forgiveness and moving on from past hurts is a recurring theme throughout the text.

* Veronica and Mac investigate the theft of a genetically altered capuchin monkey named Twenty-five from Hearst College

* In Bronson's house, Veronica discovers rats in cages and takes pictures, but Bronson claims they were abandoned on his doorstep
* Mac tells Veronica that she found leaves in the hard drive of Pauline and Gil Thomas' lab, which they believe may be connected to the theft
* Emmy, a lab assistant, reveals that the leaves are from green tea and that she stole a banana from Twenty-five

* Whitney's mother, Eve, changed her mind about Whitney going to Los Angeles with Chad

* Liz's actions: trying to destroy Eve and T.C.'s marriage, interfering in their family

• Hilary and Devon have a heated argument about her career goals and her role on GC Buzz
  • Hilary wants full control, a higher salary, and a clear title
  • Devon initially refuses to negotiate but later changes his mind
  • Hilary's agent, Barry, reveals she never had any serious job offers
    • Barry thinks Hilary has potential but she wasn't interested in other jobs
    • Hilary manipulated the situation to make Devon grovel

• Jack expresses his love to Ashley and Traci on Christmas Eve
  • Jack acknowledges his mistakes and the importance of family
    • He knows they don't always see eye to eye and makes it difficult for them
    • He is grateful for their presence and the love they share as a family

• Adam cannot talk to Sage, who informs him that Constance is sick and asking for him
   • Constance could be dying, and Adam is urged to visit her
   • Adam dismisses the situation, saying old people get sick
   • Sage insists that Adam needs to make time and visit his grandmother
   • Adam eventually agrees and makes plans to visit

 • Victoria and Billy discuss the christening of their daughter Katie
   • Victoria suggests asking Chelsea to join them
   • Billy is hesitant, as he and Chelsea are not together
   • Victoria proposes the name Katherine Rose Abbott-Newman for their daughter
   • Billy is upset and wants his daughter to have his last name

 • Ashley and Stitch discuss their relationship
   • Ashley suggests they hit the "reset" button and go back to being friends and colleagues
   • Stitch agrees, but Ashley reveals that she knows about their one-night stand
   • Ashley assures Stitch that she doesn't expect anything from him
   • Stitch appreciates Ashley's honesty and understanding

 • Avery and Dylan find Faith's bike at the coffeehouse
   • Faith appears, having run away from her father
   • Dylan and Avery help Faith return home to her parents
   • Nick and Sharon are relieved and grateful that Faith is safe

 • Joe tries to win Jill over to his side in the warehouse development project
   • Jill is opposed to the project and accuses Joe of being a carpet-bagging bastard
   • Colin joins the conversation, revealing that he stands to make money from the project
   • Cane enters the scene and offers to get them a table
   • Jill and Colin discuss their concerns about Victor Newman's involvement in the project

 • Adam learns from Constance that his father's death was not a heart attack but a suicide
   • Constance believes Victor Newman was responsible for the hostile takeover of Adam's father's company
   • Adam promises to make Victor pay for what he did to his father

 • Mariah is asked by Kevin to go to the police station
   • Dylan brings Sharon a Christmas present
   • Victoria calls Billy to discuss Christmas plans
